question.question_text: Who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day? (Vivek Ramaswamy)
question.resolution_criteria: The sub-question for the individual named as the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president of the United States as of November 5, 2024 (election day) shall resolve as **Yes**. All other sub-questions will resolve as **No**.
question.background_info:
The [vice president of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States) is the second-highest officer in the executive branch of the U.S. federal government, after the president of the United States, ranks first in the presidential line of succession, and is indirectly elected together with the president to a four-year term of office by the people of the United States through the Electoral College.

As of August 2023, although Donald Trump is the frontrunner for the Republican Party's nomination for president in 2024, there is [much speculation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection#Media_speculation_about_possible_running_mates) about who the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president will be, with dozens of individuals considered plausible candidates.

An additional complication in the 2024 cycle is that Donald Trump is, as of August 2023, the subject of four [active criminal cases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trial_of_Donald_Trump), one or more of which may go to trial before, during, or after the Republican primaries, making this an especially turbulent and uncertain election cycle, with the potential for late changes to the party's ticket before election day.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on the likelihood of Vivek Ramaswamy being chosen as the 2024 Republican vice-presidential nominee. Key factors considered included his recent rise in visibility and polling numbers following a strong debate performance, as well as endorsements from influential figures like Elon Musk. The historical context of vice-presidential selections was also examined, noting that it is relatively uncommon for primary rivals to be chosen as running mates, especially within the Republican Party. Additionally, the research highlighted that vice-presidential nominees are often more experienced politicians rather than younger, less experienced candidates like Ramaswamy.

The forecasters used various base rates to inform their predictions, with a common base rate being the historical likelihood of primary candidates who do not win the nomination being chosen as vice-presidential nominees, which is approximately 33%. They also considered the impact of endorsements and the strategic importance of vice-presidential selections in modern campaigns. The pros and cons of Ramaswamy's candidacy were weighed, leading to predictions ranging from 23% to 33%.

# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What are the latest developments in the 2024 Republican presidential race?
Answer:
The latest developments in the 2024 Republican presidential race indicate that former President Donald Trump remains the dominant figure, leading among virtually every Republican subgroup, including men, women, various income levels, evangelicals, non-evangelicals, moderates, and conservatives \[[14](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/24/briefing/republican-debate.html#:~:text=Donald%20Trump%20remains%20so%20popular%20among%20Republican%20primary%20voters%20that%20there%20is%20no%20obvious%20path%20for%20any%20of%20the%20other%20candidates%20to%20displace%20him)\]. Despite his stronghold, Trump faces significant legal challenges, including a serious criminal case where he will face charges on March 4, 2024, for allegedly attempting to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election \[[4](https://www.economist.com/interactive/2024-republican-primaries-tracker#:~:text=If%20a%20candidate%20cannot%20make%20a%20mark%20in%20one%20of%20these%20states%2C%20they%20are%20unlikely%20to%20do%20so%20elsewhere)\]\[[6](https://www.economist.com/interactive/2024-republican-primaries-tracker#:~:text=Many%20candidates%20focus%20heavily%20on%20Iowa%20or%20New%20Hampshire%2C%20hoping%20for%20an%20early%20splash%20in%20a%20small%20pond)\].

Vivek Ramaswamy, a health care and tech sector entrepreneur, has declared his candidacy and is positioning himself as a fresh, young, and diverse face in the GOP primary. He is known for his strong stance against the environmental, social, and governance (ESG) movement and "woke"-ism, which may appeal to white-collar Republicans seeking an alternative to Trump \[[10](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/republican-presidential-candidates-gop#:~:text=Vivek%20Ramaswamy%2C%20a%20health%20care%20and%20tech%20sector%20entrepreneur%2C%20conservative%20commentator%20and%20author%20who%20has%20become%20a%20crusader%20in%20the%20culture%20wars%2C%20declared%20his%20candidacy%20in%20the%20Republican%20presidential%20primary%20in%20February)\]\[[12](https://www.npr.org/2023/03/08/1160113954/2024-republican-presidential-candidates-who-is-running-tracker?utm_campaign=politics&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_term=nprnews#:~:text=Vivek%20Ramaswamy%20%20Announced%3A%20Feb)\]. However, Ramaswamy is not well-known, is very young for a presidential candidate, and lacks a solid base of support, which could hinder his chances of breaking through as a major candidate \[[12](https://www.npr.org/2023/03/08/1160113954/2024-republican-presidential-candidates-who-is-running-tracker?utm_campaign=politics&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_term=nprnews#:~:text=Vivek%20Ramaswamy%20%20Announced%3A%20Feb)\].
## Q1: What recent news is there about Vivek Ramaswamy's candidacy and political activities?
Answer:
Recent news about Vivek Ramaswamy's candidacy and political activities includes several key developments:

1. **Debate Performance and Polling**: Ramaswamy's strong performance in the first GOP presidential debate on August 23, 2023, has significantly boosted his visibility and polling numbers. He has been noted for his pugnacious style and deeply conservative policy positions, which have resonated with a segment of the Republican primary electorate. As a result, he has climbed in the polls and is now often placed second after former President Donald Trump in many surveys \[[3](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/stronger-us-india-relationship-could-help-america-declare-independence-from-china-vivek-ramaswamy/article67240938.ece#:~:text=His%20polling%20numbers%20have%20gone%20up%20after%20the%20maiden%20presidential%20debate%20in%20Milwaukee%2C%20Wisconsin%20on%20August%2023)\]\[[5](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/who-is-vivek-ramaswamy-republican-presidential-hopeful-2023-08-23/#:~:text=Ramaswamy%27s%20strong%2C%20pugnacious%20performance%20in%20the%20first%20debate%20last%20month%2C%20when%20he%20laid%20out%20an%20agenda%20even%20further%20to%20the%20right%20of%20Trump%20on%20some%20issues%2C%20earned%20him%20a%20lot%20of%20attention%2C%20as%20well%20as%20criticism%2C%20and%20boosted%20him%20in%20some%20Republican%20primary%20opinion%20polls)\]\[[7](https://www.politico.com/news/2023/08/24/ramaswamys-debate-performance-fuels-veepstakes-talk-00112817#:~:text=Ramaswamy%20is%20only%2038%2C%20and%20the%20son%20of%20Indian%20immigrants)\].

2. **Endorsements and Support**: Elon Musk, the world's wealthiest man and owner of X (formerly Twitter), Tesla, and SpaceX, has expressed some praise for Ramaswamy, calling him a "very promising candidate" on August 17, 2023. Additionally, Musk has suggested that Ramaswamy should be the GOP nominee's running mate, which has fueled speculation about Ramaswamy's potential vice-presidential candidacy \[[2](https://www.politico.com/news/2023/08/26/vivek-ramaswamy-elon-musk-presidential-advisor-00113111#:~:text=Musk%2C%20who%20has%20suggested%20he%20will%20support%20Ron%20DeSantis%20and%20collaborated%20with%20the%20Florida%20governor%20on%20his%20campaign%20launch%2C%20is%20the%20richest%20man%20in%20the%20world%20and%20already%20holds%20a%20wide-ranging%20array%20of%20political%20power%20with%20his%20ownership%20of%20X%2C%20Tesla%20and%20SpaceX)\]\[[4](https://www.businessinsider.com/ramaswamy-thinks-college-applicants-should-be-judged-on-fitness-2023-8#:~:text=Insider%20previously%20reported%20that%20the%20world%27s%20wealthiest%20man%2C%20Twitter%2C%20Tesla%2C%20and%20SpaceX%20owner%20Elon%20Musk%2C%20said%20he%20thinks%20Ramaswamy%20should%20be%20the%20the%20GOP%20nominee%27s%20running%20mate)\]\[[6](https://www.businessinsider.com/ramaswamy-thinks-college-applicants-should-be-judged-on-fitness-2023-8#:~:text=Ramaswamy%20has%20a%20long%20ways%20to%20go%20to%20catch%20up%20to%20Trump%20in%20the%20polls%2C%20but%20he%27s%20also%20being%20floated%20online%20for%20another%20possible%20position%20in%20the%20White%20House%3A%20vice%20president)\].

3. **Policy Positions and Public Statements**: Ramaswamy has positioned himself as a staunch defender of Trump and has advocated for policies that are even further to the right of Trump on some issues. He has also emphasized the importance of a strong U.S.-India relationship and has been vocal about his nationalist views and anti-woke stance \[[5](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/who-is-vivek-ramaswamy-republican-presidential-hopeful-2023-08-23/#:~:text=Ramaswamy%27s%20strong%2C%20pugnacious%20performance%20in%20the%20first%20debate%20last%20month%2C%20when%20he%20laid%20out%20an%20agenda%20even%20further%20to%20the%20right%20of%20Trump%20on%20some%20issues%2C%20earned%20him%20a%20lot%20of%20attention%2C%20as%20well%20as%20criticism%2C%20and%20boosted%20him%20in%20some%20Republican%20primary%20opinion%20polls)\]\[[10](https://www.npr.org/2023/08/28/1196283078/vivek-ramaswamy-republican-primary-trump#:~:text=%22%20%20Ramaswamy%20has%20positioned%20himself%20as%20his%20party%27s%20next%20Donald%20Trump%2C%20though%20younger%20and%20further%20to%20the%20right)\]\[[13](https://www.npr.org/2023/08/28/1196283078/vivek-ramaswamy-republican-primary-trump#:~:text=The%2038-year-old%20entrepreneur%20has%20positioned%20himself%20as%20a%20political%20outsider%20and%20%22anti-woke%22%20crusader%20since%20entering%20the%20race%20in%20February)\].

These developments highlight Ramaswamy's rising profile within the Republican primary race and his potential as a vice-presidential candidate.
## Q2: What are Donald Trump's current standings in the Republican primaries and how do his legal issues impact his campaign?
Answer:
As of now, Donald Trump remains a dominant figure in the Republican primaries, consistently leading in various polls. For instance, a recent Rasmussen Reports survey shows Trump leading Kamala Harris by 5 percentage points, with 49% of voters favoring Trump compared to 44% for Harris \[[6](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/biden_administration/election_2024_trump_49_harris_44#:~:text=Voters%20would%20vote%20for%20Trump%2C%20while%2044%25%20would%20vote%20for%20Harris)\]\[[7](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/biden_administration/election_2024_trump_49_harris_44_rfk_jr_3#:~:text=Voters%20would%20vote%20for%20Trump%2C%20while%2044%25%20would%20vote%20for%20Harris)\]. This indicates strong support within the Republican base, which is crucial for his primary campaign.

However, Trump's legal issues could significantly impact his campaign. According to a Rolling Stone article, there is growing concern among Republicans about Trump's standing in traditionally red states, which are performing worse than expected in polls \[[1](https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/trump-republicans-worry-red-state-polls-1235080588/#:~:text=With%2075%20percent%20of%20all%20voters%20telling%20us%20the%20country%20is%20on%20the%20wrong%20track%20in%20our%20latest%20survey%E2%80%A6we%20have%20a%20lot%20of%20advantages%20to%20win%20this%20race)\]. This suggests that his legal troubles might be eroding his support base, potentially making him a less viable candidate in the general election. The combination of strong primary support but potential vulnerabilities in the general election context is a critical factor to consider when forecasting his chances of securing the Republican nomination and his choice of Vice President.
## Q3: What have key Republican figures and potential presidential nominees said about their choice of running mate?
Answer:
Key Republican figures and potential presidential nominees have made various statements regarding their choice of running mate, though specific endorsements or rejections of Vivek Ramaswamy are sparse. 

Elon Musk, a significant influencer within conservative circles, has publicly stated that he believes Vivek Ramaswamy should be the GOP nominee's running mate \[[11](https://www.businessinsider.com/ramaswamy-thinks-college-applicants-should-be-judged-on-fitness-2023-8#:~:text=Insider%20previously%20reported%20that%20the%20world%27s%20wealthiest%20man%2C%20Twitter%2C%20Tesla%2C%20and%20SpaceX%20owner%20Elon%20Musk%2C%20said%20he%20thinks%20Ramaswamy%20should%20be%20the%20the%20GOP%20nominee%27s%20running%20mate)\]. This endorsement could be influential given Musk's substantial following and impact on public opinion.

Additionally, Ramaswamy himself has expressed a willingness to collaborate with high-profile figures, indicating he would consider Elon Musk as a potential adviser if he were to make it to the White House \[[11](https://www.businessinsider.com/ramaswamy-thinks-college-applicants-should-be-judged-on-fitness-2023-8#:~:text=Insider%20previously%20reported%20that%20the%20world%27s%20wealthiest%20man%2C%20Twitter%2C%20Tesla%2C%20and%20SpaceX%20owner%20Elon%20Musk%2C%20said%20he%20thinks%20Ramaswamy%20should%20be%20the%20the%20GOP%20nominee%27s%20running%20mate)\]. This openness to collaboration with influential figures might make him a more attractive running mate for some candidates.

However, there is no direct evidence from the search results indicating that key Republican figures or potential presidential nominees have explicitly stated their preferences for or against Ramaswamy as a running mate. The broader context of the Republican primary race, with its divisions between Trump loyalists and those seeking alternatives, suggests that the choice of a running mate will be strategic, aiming to unify the party and appeal to a broad voter base \[[3](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=Figure%20that%20roughly%20a%20third%20of%20Republicans%20are%20Only%20Trumpers)\]\[[7](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=True%2C%20the%20plurality%20of%20the%20Republican%20base%20loves%20him%2C%20but%20many%20Republicans%20do%20not)\]\[[15](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=They%20don%E2%80%99t%20want%20to%20see%20Trump%20bad-mouthed%2C%20but%20if%20the%20Republican%20Party%20were%20to%20coalesce%20around%20another%20candidate%20with%20a%20path%20to%20victory%2C%20they%20would%20rally%20to%20the%20cause)\].

## Q6: Has Vivek Ramaswamy made any public statements or comments about his interest in the vice presidency?
Answer:
Based on the search results, there is no direct evidence that Vivek Ramaswamy has made any public statements or comments about his interest in the vice presidency. The available sources primarily discuss his presidential campaign, his policy positions, and his interactions with other candidates.

For instance, Ramaswamy has been actively participating in the Republican presidential debates and has seen a rise in polling numbers, placing him second after former President Donald Trump in some polls \[[1](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/stronger-us-india-relationship-could-help-america-declare-independence-from-china-vivek-ramaswamy/article67240938.ece#:~:text=His%20polling%20numbers%20have%20gone%20up%20after%20the%20maiden%20presidential%20debate%20in%20Milwaukee%2C%20Wisconsin%20on%20August%2023)\]. He has also been vocal about various policy issues, including U.S.-India relations and his vision for America's foreign policy \[[1](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/stronger-us-india-relationship-could-help-america-declare-independence-from-china-vivek-ramaswamy/article67240938.ece#:~:text=His%20polling%20numbers%20have%20gone%20up%20after%20the%20maiden%20presidential%20debate%20in%20Milwaukee%2C%20Wisconsin%20on%20August%2023)\]\[[3](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/stronger-us-india-relationship-could-help-america-declare-independence-from-china-vivek-ramaswamy/article67240938.ece#:~:text=relationship%2C%20which%20has%20been%20a%20hallmark%20of%20multiple%20presidential%20administrations%20across%20the%20political%20aisle%20since%20the%20start%20of%20the%20Bill%20Clinton%20Administration)\]\[[8](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/stronger-us-india-relationship-could-help-america-declare-independence-from-china-vivek-ramaswamy/article67240938.ece#:~:text=During%20the%20first%20Republican%20presidential%20debate%2C%20his%20fellow%20Indian-American%20challenger%20Haley%20told%20him%20that%20he%20had%20no%20foreign%20policy%20experience)\].

However, none of the sources explicitly mention Ramaswamy expressing interest in the vice presidency. Therefore, it can be concluded that there is no public record of him making statements about his interest in the vice presidency based on the provided search results.
## Q7: Who are the other leading contenders for the Republican vice presidential nomination and what are their chances according to recent analyses and polls?
Answer:
In the context of the 2024 Republican vice presidential nomination, several key contenders have emerged alongside Vivek Ramaswamy. 

1. **Mike Pence**: Despite his low polling numbers and struggles to gain traction in the Republican presidential debates, Pence is considered a potential candidate due to his experience and solid conservative credentials. He is seen as a figure who could help the party move past Trump without causing a split, appealing to the "Anybody But Trump" faction within the GOP \[[6](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=His%20polling%20is%20in%20the%20single%20digits)\]\[[9](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=Pence%3F%20Seriously%3F%20His%20polling%20is%20in%20the%20single%20digits)\]\[[12](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=Non-Trumpy%20Republicans%20just%20aren%E2%80%99t%20impressed)\].

2. **J.D. Vance**: The Ohio Senator and author of "Hillbilly Elegy" is another notable contender. Vance has a strong appeal to social conservatives due to his focus on traditional family values and his stance on economic issues. However, his complicated relationship with religion and recent support for keeping the abortion pill mifepristone legal may affect his standing with the GOP's religious base \[[5](https://www.americamagazine.org/politics-society/2024/07/16/five-faith-facts-jd-vance-trump-vp-248368#:~:text=Vance%20will%20be%20his%20running%20mate%20as%20he%20seeks%20reelection)\]\[[7](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2022/08/24/ohio-senate-race-j-d-vance-focuses-on-conservative-family-issues/10204420002/#:~:text=%22%20Vance%20is%20campaigning%20on%20the%20economy%20and%20inflation%20like%20many%20other%20Republicans%20as%20he%20seeks%20to%20replace%20retiring%20U)\].

3. **Ron DeSantis**: The Florida Governor is also a significant figure in the race. Known for his strong conservative policies and high-profile governorship, DeSantis has been actively campaigning and is considered a top contender for the presidential nomination, which could position him well for the vice-presidential slot if he does not secure the top spot \[[15](https://www.sltrib.com/opinion/2023/04/28/president-mike-pence-not-likely/#:~:text=In%20the%20span%20of%20a%20week%2C%20Utah%20has%20hosted%20two%20of%20the%20top%20Republican%20contenders%20for%20president%20in%202024%20%E2%80%94%20and%20the%20contrast%20in%20styles%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20be%20more%20stark)\].

These candidates represent a range of ideologies and strategies within the Republican Party, each with their own strengths and potential drawbacks. Their chances will likely evolve as the primary season progresses and as they navigate the complex dynamics of the GOP electorate.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What were the characteristics of previous Republican vice presidential nominees over the past 50 years?
Answer:
Over the past 50 years, the characteristics of Republican vice presidential nominees have evolved significantly, particularly since the mid-1970s. Initially, vice presidential nominations were decided at the end of presidential nominating conventions. However, the increased importance and visibility of the vice presidency during the Cold War and especially from the mid-1970s led to a more diligent pre-convention selection process \[[1](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-republican-veepstakes-part-one-donald-trump-chooses-an-apprentice/#:~:text=Until%20the%20mid-1970s%2C%20vice%20presidential%20nominations%20were%20considered%2C%20decided%2C%20and%20announced%20at%20the%20end%20of%20presidential%20nominating%20conventions%20only%20after%20a%20presidential%20candidate%20was%20nominated)\]\[[2](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-republican-veepstakes-part-one-donald-trump-chooses-an-apprentice/#:~:text=An%20exhausted%20and%20jubilant%20nominee%20gathered%20with%20some%20of%20his%20campaign%20team%20and%20party%20leaders%20on%20the%20convention%E2%80%99s%20final%20morning%20to%20discuss%20the%20ticket%E2%80%99s%20second%20spot)\]. This shift allowed presidential candidates to announce their running mates before the convention, a practice that began with Walter F. Mondale's 1984 selection of Rep. Geraldine Ferraro and was followed by Republicans in 1996 when Bob Dole announced Jack Kemp a day before the convention \[[3](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-republican-veepstakes-part-one-donald-trump-chooses-an-apprentice/#:~:text=The%20increased%20importance%20and%20visibility%20of%20the%20vice%20presidency%2C%20initially%20during%20the%20Cold%20War%20and%20especially%20from%20the%20mid-1970s%2C%20encouraged%20greater%20attention%20to%20running%20mate%20selection)\]\[[4](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-republican-veepstakes-part-one-donald-trump-chooses-an-apprentice/#:~:text=Walter%20F)\].

Modern vice presidential selections are influenced by three main variables: the presidential candidate orchestrating the process, the pool of available selectees, and the political context. The selection process often involves publicized interviews and strategic choices aimed at complementing the presidential candidate and addressing current political needs \[[5](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-republican-veepstakes-part-one-donald-trump-chooses-an-apprentice/#:~:text=Some%20vice%20presidential%20selection%20processes%2C%20especially%20in%20the%20immediate%20post-Watergate%20period%2C%20involved%20publicized%20interviews%20with%20contenders%20in%20order%20to%20promote%20transparency)\]\[[9](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-republican-veepstakes-part-one-donald-trump-chooses-an-apprentice/#:~:text=Since%20the%20shift%20to%20pre-convention%20announcements%2C%20vice%20presidential%20rollouts%20have%20occurred%20between%201%20and%2020%20days%20before%20the%20convention%20begins)\]. For example, candidates like Michael Dukakis and Mitt Romney have campaigned with various vice presidential candidates in a respectful manner, avoiding making a spectacle of the process \[[10](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-republican-veepstakes-part-one-donald-trump-chooses-an-apprentice/#:~:text=Nominees%20like%20Michael%20Dukakis%20and%20Mitt%20Romney%20campaigned%20with%20various%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20but%20in%20a%20respectful%20fashion%2C%20and%20they%20and%20other%20presidential%20candidates%20have%20been%20fairly%20complimentary%20about%20prospects%20and%20not%20revealed%20their%20thinking%20until%20they%20were%20ready%20to%20announce%20their%20selection)\]. This strategic and often secretive approach underscores the importance of the vice presidential pick in modern campaigns.
## Q1: What is the historical likelihood of a primary candidate who does not win the nomination being chosen as the vice-presidential nominee?
Answer:
The historical likelihood of a primary candidate who does not win the nomination being chosen as the vice-presidential nominee is relatively low. Since 1960, only eight out of 24 first-time vice-presidential candidates had previously run for president, indicating that approximately one-third of vice-presidential nominees had sought the presidency in prior years \[[3](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20have%20come%20from%20those%20who%20did%20not%20seek%20the%20presidency%20that%20year)\]\[[8](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Occasionally%2C%20the%20running%20mate%20sought%20the%20presidential%20nomination%20previously)\]. This trend is particularly pronounced in the Republican Party, where it is uncommon for the presidential nominee to choose one of their rivals as a running mate \[[7](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/2024-gop-rivals-teaming-up-on-the-ticket-dont-count-on-it/#:~:text=%E2%80%94%20History%20suggests%20that%20whoever%20wins%20the%20Republican%20presidential%20nomination%20is%20unlikely%20to%20choose%20one%20of%20their%20rivals%20for%20the%20nomination%20as%20his%20or%20her%20running%20mate)\]. 

In summary, while it is not unheard of for a primary candidate to be selected as the vice-presidential nominee, it is relatively rare, especially within the Republican Party. This historical context suggests that the likelihood of Vivek Ramaswamy, or any other primary candidate who does not win the nomination, being chosen as the vice-presidential nominee is low.
## Q2: How often have vice-presidential nominees been chosen from among the top contenders in the primary race?
Answer:
The search results provided do not directly address the historical frequency of vice-presidential nominees being chosen from among the top contenders in the primary race. However, based on historical data and expert analysis, we can provide some context.

Historically, vice-presidential nominees are often chosen for strategic reasons, such as balancing the ticket geographically, ideologically, or demographically, rather than solely based on their performance in the primary race. For example, Joe Biden, who was not a top contender in the 2008 Democratic primary, was chosen as Barack Obama's running mate to add experience and appeal to working-class voters \[[1](https://www.sltrib.com/news/nation-world/2019/04/25/former-vice-president-joe/#:~:text=That%27s%20why%20today%20I%27m%20announcing%20my%20candidacy%20for%20president%20of%20the%20United%20States)\]\[[2](https://www.sltrib.com/news/nation-world/2019/04/25/former-vice-president-joe/#:~:text=%22We%20need%20to%20get%20more%20pragmatic%20and%20understand%20that%20Joe%20Biden%20is%20the%20only%20real%20chance%20to%20win%20in%202020%2C%22%20said%20Dick%20Harpootlian%2C%20former%20chairman%20of%20the%20South%20Carolina%20Democratic%20Party)\]. Similarly, in 1980, George H.W. Bush, who was a strong contender in the Republican primary, was chosen by Ronald Reagan to balance the ticket ideologically and geographically \[[3](https://www.washingtonpost.com/history/2024/08/07/minnesota-vice-president-walz-humphrey-mondale/?utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=wp_main&utm_source=twitter#:~:text=In%20a%202010%20documentary%2C%20%E2%80%9CHubert%20H)\].

In summary, while top contenders in the primary race are sometimes chosen as vice-presidential nominees, it is not a consistent rule. The selection often depends on broader strategic considerations.

## Q3: How frequently have outsider candidates with similar profiles to Vivek Ramaswamy (e.g., business background, limited political experience) been selected as vice-presidential nominees?
Answer:
Outsider candidates with business backgrounds and limited political experience have historically been rare choices for vice-presidential nominees. Here are a few relevant examples:

- **Arthur Sewall (1896)**: Sewall was a businessman and industrialist with no significant political experience before being selected as William Jennings Bryan's running mate. His selection was partly to balance the ticket geographically and ideologically \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Sewall#:~:text=His%20selection%20is%20believed%20to%20have%20been%20an%20effort%20to%20win%20votes%20among%20conservative%20and%20New%20England%20members%20of%20the%20party%20who%20were%20disturbed%20by%20the%20populist%20aspects%20of%20William%20Jennings%20Bryan)\].
- **Henry Gassaway Davis (1904)**: Davis was primarily chosen for his ability to fund the campaign. Although he had some political experience, his selection was more about financial support than political acumen \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Gassaway_Davis#:~:text=%20The%201904%20Democratic%20National%20Convention%20nominated%20a%20ticket%20of%20Alton%20B)\]\[[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Gassaway_Davis#:~:text=Davis%20was%20chosen%20primarily%20for%20his%20ability%20to%20provide%20funding%20to%20the%20campaign)\].
- **Garret A. Hobart (1896)**: Hobart was a businessman-turned-politician who had served on his party's national committee. His business background was significant, but he also had some political experience \[[8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garret_Hobart#:~:text=With%20New%20Jersey%20a%20key%20state%20in%20the%20upcoming%20election%2C%20McKinley%20and%20his%20close%20adviser%2C%20future%20senator%20Mark%20Hanna%2C%20decided%20to%20have%20the%20convention%20select%20Hobart)\]\[[10](https://njh.libraries.rutgers.edu/index.php/njh/article/view/1019#:~:text=Until%20recent%20decades%2C%20American%20vice%20presidents%20were%20relatively%20obscure%2C%20little-known%20men%20who%20had%20minimal%20impact%20upon%20the%20politics%20and%20policies%20of%20the%20administrations%20they%20served)\].

These examples suggest that while it is not unprecedented for outsider candidates with business backgrounds to be selected, it is relatively uncommon. The primary reasons for their selection often include financial support or balancing the ticket rather than purely their business credentials. This historical context might suggest a lower probability for Vivek Ramaswamy, who has a similar profile, to be selected as the 2024 Republican vice-presidential nominee.
## Q4: What are the typical polling thresholds or indicators that have historically predicted a vice-presidential nomination?
Answer:
Historically, vice-presidential nominations have been influenced by several key factors, though specific polling thresholds are less clear-cut compared to presidential nominations. One significant indicator is the "vice presidential bounce," where non-incumbent presidential candidates have received a boost in the polls after announcing their running mates. This bounce has ranged from 3 to 9 points, averaging around 5 points, and is separate from the usual convention bounce \[[4](https://web.archive.org/web/20080912151830/http://www.gallup.com/poll/109381/Candidates-Gotten-Small-Poll-Bounce-After-Naming-VP.aspx#:~:text=Since%201996%2C%20Gallup%20has%20conducted%20polls%20in%20the%20small%20window%20of%20time%20after%20the%20announcement%20of%20a%20presidential%20candidate%27s%20running%20mate%20but%20before%20the%20convention%20has%20taken%20place)\]\[[12](https://web.archive.org/web/20080912151830/http://www.gallup.com/poll/109381/Candidates-Gotten-Small-Poll-Bounce-After-Naming-VP.aspx#:~:text=Gallup%20election%20trends%20suggest%20that%20recent%20non-incumbent%20presidential%20candidates%20have%20received%20a%20boost%20in%20the%20polls%20after%20naming%20their%20vice%20presidential%20running%20mates%2C%20ranging%20from%203%20to%209%20points%20%28and%20averaging%205%20points%29)\]. 

Additionally, the announcement of a vice-presidential candidate tends to dominate news cycles with positive coverage, which can temporarily increase a candidate's visibility and support \[[6](https://web.archive.org/web/20080912151830/http://www.gallup.com/poll/109381/Candidates-Gotten-Small-Poll-Bounce-After-Naming-VP.aspx#:~:text=Even%20though%20it%20is%20unclear%20whether%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20materially%20aid%20a%20presidential%20candidate%27s%20election%20fortunes%2C%20the%20vice%20presidential%20announcements%20are%20among%20the%20most%20talked%20about%20and%20anticipated%20events%20of%20the%20campaign)\]. However, the long-term impact of these announcements on election outcomes remains debatable. Historically, vice-presidential candidates have often been chosen for their experience and ability to balance the ticket, as seen with nominees like Walter Mondale, George H.W. Bush, and Al Gore \[[15](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Starting%20in%201948%2C%20the%20vice%20presidential%20candidate%20as%20often%20as%20not%20has%20been%20the%20more%20experienced%20member%20of%20the%20ticket%20in%20high%20government%20office%2C%20including%20recent%20nominees%20such%20as%20Walter%20F)\].

These insights suggest that while a vice-presidential announcement can provide a short-term polling boost, it is the strategic selection of a candidate with complementary strengths and experience that has historically been a more reliable indicator of a successful vice-presidential nomination.
## Q5: How often has the vice-presidential nominee been a candidate who performed well in early debates?
Answer:
The search results do not directly address the specific question of how often vice-presidential nominees have been candidates who performed well in early debates. However, we can infer some relevant information from historical examples of vice-presidential candidates and their debate performances.

1. **Dan Quayle (1988)**: Dan Quayle was selected as George H.W. Bush's running mate despite facing significant criticism, including from within his own party. His debate performance in 1988 against Lloyd Bentsen is often remembered for Bentsen's famous retort, "Senator, you're no Jack Kennedy" \[[3](https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/vice-presidential-debate-omaha-nebraska#:~:text=The%20candidates%20are%20Senator%20Dan%20Quayle%2C%20the%20Republican%20nominee%2C%20and%20Senator%20Lloyd%20Bentsen%2C%20the%20Democratic%20nominee)\]\[[4](https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/vice-presidential-debate-omaha-nebraska#:~:text=Both%20George%20Bush%20and%20Michael%20Dukakis%20said%20their%20selections%20of%20a%20running%20mate%20would%20reveal%20a%20lot%20about%20themselves)\]\[[7](https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/vice-presidential-debate-omaha-nebraska#:~:text=Just%20last%20week%20former%20Secretary%20of%20State%20Haig%20said%20that%20your%20pick%20was%20the%20dumbest%20call%20George%20Bush%20could%20have%20made)\]. This suggests that Quayle's debate performance was not a significant factor in his selection.

2. **Al Gore (1992)**: Al Gore, who was Bill Clinton's running mate, had a notable debate performance against Dan Quayle and James Stockdale in 1992. The debate featured sharp exchanges, particularly between Quayle and Gore, indicating that Gore was a strong debater \[[1](https://www.c-span.org/video/?33086-1/1992-vice-presidential-candidates-debate#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Dan%20Quayle%2C%20Senator%20Al%20Gore%20%28D-TN%29%2C%20and%20Vice%20Admiral%20James%20Stockdale%2C%20the%20running%20mate%20of%20independent%20presidential%20candidate%20H)\]\[[8](https://www.c-span.org/video/?33086-1/1992-vice-presidential-candidates-debate#:~:text=The%20debate%20was%20moderated%20by%20Hal%20Bruno%20and%20was%20conducted%20in%20a%20discussion%20format)\]\[[13](https://www.c-span.org/video/?33086-1/1992-vice-presidential-candidates-debate#:~:text=The%20candidates%27%20responses%20to%20questions%20were%20followed%20by%20discussion%20periods%20in%20which%20the%20candidates%20could%20directly%20address%20one%20another)\]. However, it is unclear if this performance was a decisive factor in his selection as the vice-presidential nominee.

3. **Walter Mondale (1976)**: Walter Mondale, who was Jimmy Carter's running mate, participated in a vice-presidential debate against Bob Dole in 1976. The debate was a significant event, but there is no clear evidence that Mondale's debate performance was a key factor in his selection \[[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UmeWszwFRSI&feature=youtu.be#:~:text=The%20vice%20presidential%20debate%20consisted%20of%20Sen)\].

From these examples, it appears that while debate performance can be a notable aspect of a vice-presidential candidate's public profile, it is not consistently a decisive factor in their selection. Historical data does not provide a clear pattern indicating that performing well in early debates significantly increases the likelihood of being chosen as a vice-presidential nominee.
## Q6: What is the impact of endorsements (e.g., from influential figures like Elon Musk) on the selection of a vice-presidential nominee?
Answer:
Endorsements from influential figures like Elon Musk can have a significant impact on the selection of a vice-presidential nominee, though the effect is nuanced. Historically, endorsements have been shown to provide a measurable boost to candidates, but this is often because endorsed candidates already possess qualities that make them strong contenders, such as better fundraising abilities and public speaking skills \[[1](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2015/07/23/this-is-the-endorsement-that-actually-helps-a-candidate-win/#:~:text=The%20key%20is%20to%20figure%20out%20what%20the%20endorsement%20does%20for%20these%20candidates%20on%20top%20of%20all%20their%20other%20advantages)\]\[[9](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2015/07/23/this-is-the-endorsement-that-actually-helps-a-candidate-win/#:~:text=But%20that%E2%80%99s%20because%20candidates%20who%20get%20endorsements%20tend%20to%20be%20better%20candidates%20to%20begin%20with%20%E2%80%94%20they%E2%80%99re%20better%20fundraisers%2C%20better%20public%20speakers%2C%20are%20better%20fits%20for%20their%20districts%2C%20etc)\]. 

In the context of vice-presidential selections, endorsements can generate substantial media coverage and a temporary "bounce" in the polls. For instance, Gallup data indicates that vice-presidential announcements can lead to an average 5-point increase in a candidate's support, although this effect is often short-lived and overtaken by other campaign events \[[5](https://news.gallup.com/poll/109381/Candidates-Gotten-Small-Poll-Bounce-After-Naming-VP.aspx#:~:text=Even%20though%20it%20is%20unclear%20whether%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20materially%20aid%20a%20presidential%20candidate%27s%20election%20fortunes%2C%20the%20vice%20presidential%20announcements%20are%20among%20the%20most%20talked%20about%20and%20anticipated%20events%20of%20the%20campaign)\]\[[8](https://news.gallup.com/poll/109381/Candidates-Gotten-Small-Poll-Bounce-After-Naming-VP.aspx#:~:text=Since%201996%2C%20Gallup%20has%20conducted%20polls%20in%20the%20small%20window%20of%20time%20after%20the%20announcement%20of%20a%20presidential%20candidate%27s%20running%20mate%20but%20before%20the%20convention%20has%20taken%20place)\]. Therefore, while an endorsement from a high-profile figure like Elon Musk could provide a temporary boost and significant media attention, it is unlikely to be the sole determining factor in the selection of a vice-presidential nominee.
## Q7: How often have younger candidates been selected as vice-presidential nominees compared to more experienced politicians?
Answer:
Historically, vice-presidential nominees have often been more experienced politicians rather than younger candidates. The selection process for vice-presidential candidates tends to prioritize political experience and the ability to balance the ticket, rather than youth or novelty. For instance, the vice presidency has been perceived as a political dead end until recently, and the selection process has been more about eligibility and selection rather than active candidacy \[[6](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.2307/3234219#:~:text=The%20vice%20presidency%2C%20until%20recently%20widely%20perceived%20as%20a%20political%20dead%20end%2C%20appears%20to%20have%20emerged%20as%20the%20surest%20route%20to%20a%20presidential%20nomination)\]\[[10](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.2307/3234219#:~:text=%22%202%20Consequently%2C%20the%20attractiveness%20of%20the%20vice%20presidential%20nomination%20to%20politicians%20with%20presidential%20aspirations%20has%20risen%20significantly)\]. 

Moreover, the attractiveness of the vice-presidential nomination has increased for politicians with presidential aspirations, which often means selecting individuals with substantial political experience \[[6](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.2307/3234219#:~:text=The%20vice%20presidency%2C%20until%20recently%20widely%20perceived%20as%20a%20political%20dead%20end%2C%20appears%20to%20have%20emerged%20as%20the%20surest%20route%20to%20a%20presidential%20nomination)\]. This trend suggests that younger, less experienced candidates like Vivek Ramaswamy might face challenges in being selected as a vice-presidential nominee compared to more seasoned politicians.

question.question_text: Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Jeff Jackson)
question.resolution_criteria:
If Joe Biden is not the Democratic Party's nominee for President in 2024, this group question will resolve as **Yes** for the person who is the Democratic Party's nominee for Vice President on November 5, 2024 (Election Day). All other choices will resolve as **No**.

If Joe Biden is the Democratic presidential nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, then this question will be **annulled**.
question.fine_print:
This is a group question rather than multiple choice, which means each individual option is like its own Yes or No question. Please note that as a forecaster this means two things: 

1. You do not have to assign probabilities to every choice.
2. Your predictions do not have to sum up to 100%.

More choices might be added later, depending on credible reporting that someone is in serious contention for VP.
question.background_info:
In the wake of what the New York Times [described](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/30/us/politics/biden-campaign-debate-scramble.html) as a "disastrous" presidential debate with Donald Trump on June 28, 2024, Joe Biden's candidacy was left in a suddenly-precarious position, according to the Times. Metaculus forecasters on June 30, 2024 [assessed](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/) only an 80% chance of Biden being the Democratic presidential nominee, despite Biden having won 3,894 [pledged delegates](https://apnews.com/hub/ap-election-2024-delegate-tracker) to the Democratic National Convention (which is 98.9% of all delegates; 1,976 are needed for nomination).  

According to a [CNN analysis](https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/28/politics/election-biden-presidential-race-what-matters/index.html), if President Biden withdrew himself from contention, the assumption would be that his running mate Kamala Harris would be favorite to replace him at the top of the ticket, due to the delegates being pledged to vote for Biden and approved by the Biden-Harris campaign. Should Harris be the presidential nominee, according to [Politico](https://www.politico.com/news/2024/06/28/can-democrats-replace-biden-00165684): 

>Even if Harris coasted to the nomination, she would need a vice presidential candidate of her own, and there would still be a fight among the party’s future stars to be her running mate.

>Any of Democrats’ rising stars would be a possibility, though Newsom would be particularly unlikely. Unless either changed their residency, a Harris-Newsom ticket would be ineligible for California’s 54 electoral votes — and there’s no realistic path to a Democratic victory without them.

See also The National Interest: [Who Would 'President' Kamala Harris Pick for Vice President?](https://nationalinterest.org/blog/reboot/who-would-president-kamala-harris-pick-vice-president-209064)

In modern times, the Democratic Party typically features its vice presidential nominee's acceptance speech on Day 3 of the convention (Kamala Harris example [here](https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/dnc-2020-day-3/index.html)), which [would be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention) August 21, 2024. Possibly the decision on the ticket would be officially made in a [virtual roll call](https://ohiocapitaljournal.com/2024/06/21/exclusive-dnc-moves-ahead-on-all-virtual-roll-call-for-biden-presidential-nomination/) before the convention. However, this question will resolve based on who the nominee actually is on Election Day, since a vice presidential nominee can still withdraw after the convention, for example [Thomas Eagleton](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/04/157670201/the-thomas-eagleton-affair-haunts-candidates-today) in 1972.

explanation:
# SUMMARY
*Question*: Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Jeff Jackson)

*Final Prediction*: 20.0%

*Total Cost*: $1.04

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 20.0%] Chose a base rate of 0.1 due to the historical likelihood of an incumbent vice president becoming the vice presidential nominee being relatively low. Adjusted up for Harris's strong position and down for Jackson's lack of visibility.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 12.0%] Chose a base rate of 0.02 based on the historical likelihood of an incumbent vice president becoming the vice presidential nominee. Adjusted up for Harris's strong position and down for Jackson's lack of visibility.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 39.0%] Chose a base rate of 0.39 based on the typical rate of a question resolving positively. Adjusted up for Harris's strong position and down for Jackson's lack of visibility.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 44.0%] Chose a base rate of 0.39 based on the typical rate of a question resolving positively. Adjusted up for Harris's strong position and down for Jackson's lack of visibility.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 5.0%] Chose a base rate of 0.1 based on the historical likelihood of an incumbent vice president becoming the vice presidential nominee. Adjusted down for Jackson's lack of visibility.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on the likelihood of Jeff Jackson becoming the Democratic vice presidential nominee if Joe Biden is no longer the presidential nominee in 2024. The forecasters considered various factors, including the current status of Joe Biden's candidacy, Kamala Harris's position as the de facto Democratic presidential nominee, and historical trends in vice presidential selections. They also examined the potential base rates for such a scenario, the pros and cons of Harris's and Jackson's candidacies, and the influence of endorsements and media coverage.

Key findings include the low historical likelihood of an incumbent vice president becoming the vice presidential nominee if the incumbent president is no longer running, the strategic considerations in selecting vice presidential nominees from key battleground states, and the importance of political experience and party support. The forecasters also noted the lack of public statements or actions by Jeff Jackson suggesting he is in contention for the vice presidential nomination, as well as the absence of recent news stories or analyses mentioning him as a potential candidate.

## Possible Base Rates
- The historical likelihood of an incumbent vice president becoming the vice presidential nominee if the incumbent president is no longer running is relatively low, occurring only twice in U.S. history [S1.Q0]

# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What is the current status of Joe Biden’s presidential candidacy as of today?
Answer:
As of today, Joe Biden has not formally declared his candidacy for a second term in the 2024 presidential election, but he is widely expected to run. Despite concerns about his age and approval ratings, Biden has frequently dismissed suggestions that he might pull out of the race. He has positioned himself as a protector of democracy and a stabilizing force after the Trump administration, highlighting bipartisan accomplishments such as a major infrastructure bill \[[4](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/joe-biden/biden-says-plan-running-2024-no-announcement-yet-rcna78921#:~:text=Biden%20is%20the%20oldest%20U)\]\[[6](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2023/us/politics/presidential-candidates-2024.html#:~:text=%20%E2%80%9CTwo%20years%20ago%2C%20our%20democracy%20faced%20its%20greatest%20threat%20since%20the%20Civil%20War)\]\[[8](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2023/us/politics/presidential-candidates-2024.html#:~:text=While%20President%20Biden%20has%20not%20formally%20declared%20his%20candidacy%20for%20a%20second%20term%2C%20and%20there%20has%20been%20much%20hand-wringing%20among%20Democrats%20over%20whether%20he%20should%20given%20his%20age%2C%20he%20is%20widely%20expected%20to%20run)\]. 

However, there are some indications that Biden might reconsider his candidacy. Franklin Foer, author of *The Last Politician: Inside Joe Biden's White House and the Struggle for America's Future*, mentioned that it "wouldn't be a total shock" if Biden drops out of the presidential race by the end of the year \[[1](https://www.newsweek.com/joe-biden-2024-election-odds-pull-out-race-1824616#:~:text=Biden%20has%20frequently%20hit%20back%20at%20those%20who%20say%20he%20should%20not%20run%20for%20president%20again%20next%20year%2C%20as%20numerous%20polls%20suggest%20Democratic%20voters%20are%20concerned%20about%20the%20age%20of%20the%2080-year-old%20incumbent%2C%20as%20well%20as%20his%20far%20from%20ideal%20approval%20ratings)\]\[[2](https://www.newsweek.com/joe-biden-2024-election-odds-pull-out-race-1824616#:~:text=Joe%20Biden%20is%20more%20than%20likely%20to%20be%20the%20Democratic%20candidate%20for%20the%202024%20election%20as%20the%20president%20dismisses%20suggestions%20that%20he%20could%20pull%20out%20of%20the%20race%2C%20bookmakers%20have%20said)\]\[[14](https://www.newsweek.com/joe-biden-2024-election-odds-pull-out-race-1824616#:~:text=On%20Sunday%2C%20Franklin%20Foer%2C%20the%20author%20of%20The%20Last%20Politician%3A%20Inside%20Joe%20Biden%27s%20White%20House%20and%20the%20Struggle%20for%20America%27s%20Future%2C%20told%20NBC%20News%27%20Meet%20the%20Press%20that%20it%20%22wouldn%27t%20be%20a%20total%20shock%22%20if%20Biden%20drops%20out%20of%20the%20presidential%20race%20by%20the%20end%20of%20the%20year)\]. Additionally, Biden's odds of winning the nomination have slightly decreased according to betting markets, moving from a 76.9% probability to 73.3% over recent months \[[9](https://www.newsweek.com/joe-biden-2024-election-odds-pull-out-race-1824616#:~:text=%22%20According%20to%20Paddy%20Power%2C%20Biden%27s%20odds%20of%20winning%20the%20nomination%20moved%20from%203/10%20%2876)\]. 

In summary, while Biden is currently expected to run for re-election, there are notable uncertainties and discussions within the Democratic Party about his potential withdrawal.
## Q1: What are the latest updates on Kamala Harris possibly becoming the Democratic presidential nominee?
Answer:
Kamala Harris has become the de facto Democratic presidential nominee following Joe Biden's decision to step aside and endorse her. This endorsement has led to a surge in support and enthusiasm among Democrats, with Harris now leading Donald Trump by 4 points in an average of national polls (49.5% to 45.5%) \[[7](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4851390-kamala-harris-donald-trump-chance-of-winning-white-house-survey/#:~:text=Harris%20has%20opened%20up%20a%204-point%20lead%20on%20the%20former%20president%20in%20an%20average%20of%20national%20polls%20from%20The%20Hill/Decision%20Desk%20HQ%2C%20with%20the%20vice%20president%20garnering%2049)\]. Despite this, Harris is underperforming compared to where Hillary Clinton was at this point in the 2016 election and even compared to the 2020 Biden-Harris ticket \[[5](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/08/28/harris-polling-clinton-biden-obama/?utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=wp_politics&utm_source=twitter#:~:text=Hillary%20Clinton%2C%20former%20secretary%20of%20state%20and%202016%20Democratic%20nominee%2C%20speaks%20during%20the%20first%20day%20of%20the%20Democratic%20National%20Convention%20on%20Aug)\].

Harris and her running mate, Tim Walz, are actively campaigning in key battleground states like Georgia and North Carolina, with a focus on building momentum and addressing lingering questions from the media and public \[[2](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/aug/27/harris-walz-interview-cnn#:~:text=Kamala%20Harris%20and%20Tim%20Walz%20will%20sit%20for%20their%20first%20interview%20as%20the%20Democratic%20ticket%20on%20Thursday%2C%20after%20weeks%20of%20demands%20from%20Republicans%20and%20members%20of%20the%20media%20for%20the%20nominees%20to%20open%20themselves%20up%20to%20questions)\]\[[13](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/28/us/politics/harris-georgia-trump.html#:~:text=When%20we%20have%20confirmed%20access%2C%20the%20full%20article%20content%20will%20load)\]. Harris is set to give her first formal interview as the Democratic nominee, which is expected to address many of these questions and could further influence public perception and support \[[1](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/aug/27/harris-walz-interview-cnn#:~:text=%E2%80%9CThere%20are%20a%20lot%20of%20questions%20that%20have%20been%20lingering%20out%20there%20for%20her%20to%20answer%20as%20we%20go%20into%20this%20fall%20campaign%2C%E2%80%9D%20David%20Chalian%2C%20CNN%E2%80%99s%20political%20director%2C%20said%20after%20announcing%20the%20interview%20on%20the%20network%20Tuesday)\]\[[2](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/aug/27/harris-walz-interview-cnn#:~:text=Kamala%20Harris%20and%20Tim%20Walz%20will%20sit%20for%20their%20first%20interview%20as%20the%20Democratic%20ticket%20on%20Thursday%2C%20after%20weeks%20of%20demands%20from%20Republicans%20and%20members%20of%20the%20media%20for%20the%20nominees%20to%20open%20themselves%20up%20to%20questions)\].

## Q2: What recent news has there been about potential vice presidential picks if Kamala Harris becomes the nominee?
Answer:
Recent news indicates that Vice President Kamala Harris has begun the process of vetting potential running mates in anticipation of her possible nomination for President in 2024. Key contenders on her shortlist include Minnesota Governor Tim Walz and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, both of whom are noted for their ability to raise substantial campaign funds \[[1](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/29/harris-vp-shortlist-can-raise-big-money.html#:~:text=Tim%20Walz%20and%20Transportation%20Secretary%20Pete%20Buttigieg%2C%20among%20others%2C%20according%20to%20NBC%20News)\]\[[3](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/29/harris-vp-shortlist-can-raise-big-money.html#:~:text=Her%20associated%20committees%20must%20file%20federal%20disclosures%20by%20Oct)\]. Additionally, Illinois Governor JB Pritzker is being considered due to his business experience, policy achievements, and significant self-financing capabilities, which could be advantageous for Harris' campaign \[[8](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2024-election/pros-cons-harris-vp-list-contenders-balance-ticket-rcna164866#:~:text=Illinois%20Gov)\]. 

The focus on candidates who can bolster campaign finances is crucial, as Harris' political operation has already raised over $200 million since President Joe Biden endorsed her \[[1](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/29/harris-vp-shortlist-can-raise-big-money.html#:~:text=Tim%20Walz%20and%20Transportation%20Secretary%20Pete%20Buttigieg%2C%20among%20others%2C%20according%20to%20NBC%20News)\]. This financial momentum is essential to counter the substantial fundraising efforts of former President Donald Trump, who continues to draw significant financial support \[[4](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/29/harris-vp-shortlist-can-raise-big-money.html#:~:text=Trump%27s%20running%20mate%20Sen)\].

## Q3: What are the predictions on Metaculus regarding the Democratic vice presidential nominee if Joe Biden is not the presidential nominee?
Answer:
Based on the available information, there are no direct predictions on Metaculus specifically addressing who the Democratic vice presidential nominee will be if Joe Biden is no longer the presidential nominee in 2024. However, some relevant context can be drawn from related discussions and data points:

1. **Kamala Harris**: Vice President Kamala Harris is often speculated to be a likely candidate for the 2024 presidential race. Despite her net -10% approval rating from January to June 2022, she remains a prominent figure in early polling \[[3](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%2C%20often%20speculated%20as%20being%20likely%20to%20run%20in%202024%2C%20has%20had%20a%20net%20-10%25%20approval%20rating%20from%20January%20to%20June%202022)\]. This suggests that if Biden is not the nominee, Harris could be a strong contender for the vice-presidential slot, especially if she does not secure the presidential nomination.

2. **General Uncertainty**: The New York Times reported in June 2022 that many top Democratic officials expressed concerns about a Biden re-election campaign and uncertainty about selecting an alternative nominee \[[1](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=The%20New%20York%20Times%20reported%20in%20June%202022%20that%20many%20top%20Democrat%20officials%20expressed%20%28off%20the%20record%29%20concerns%20about%20a%20Biden%20re-election%20campaign%2C%20and%20uncertainty%20about%20selecting%20an%20alternative%20nominee)\]\[[3](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%2C%20often%20speculated%20as%20being%20likely%20to%20run%20in%202024%2C%20has%20had%20a%20net%20-10%25%20approval%20rating%20from%20January%20to%20June%202022)\]. This indicates a broader uncertainty within the party, which could influence the selection of both presidential and vice-presidential nominees.

3. **Lack of Other Candidates**: As of June 2022, no other Democratic candidates had expressed intent to run, and no candidate besides Harris stood out in early polling \[[3](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%2C%20often%20speculated%20as%20being%20likely%20to%20run%20in%202024%2C%20has%20had%20a%20net%20-10%25%20approval%20rating%20from%20January%20to%20June%202022)\]. This lack of clear alternatives could mean that the vice-presidential nominee might come from a smaller pool of well-known figures within the party.

In summary, while there is no specific prediction on Metaculus about the Democratic vice-presidential nominee if Biden is not the presidential nominee, Kamala Harris appears to be a significant figure in the discussions, and the general uncertainty within the party could play a crucial role in the selection process.
