She is also the most in-demand speaker at Democratic fundraising events, which underscores her importance and popularity within the party \[[10](https://www.thedailybeast.com/its-time-to-give-kamala-harris-her-due#:~:text=It%20is%20a%20subject%20that%20is%20especially%20significant%20to%20many%20voters%20given%20President%20Biden%E2%80%99s%20age%2C%20and%20it%20is%20one%20that%20should%20be%20addressed%20directly)\]\[[15](https://www.thedailybeast.com/its-time-to-give-kamala-harris-her-due#:~:text=The%20New%20York%20Times%20ran%20a%20major%20piece%20entitled%2C%20%E2%80%9CKamala%20Harris%20Takes%20on%20a%20Forceful%20New%20Role%20in%20the%202024%20Campaign)\].
- **Campaign Activity**: Harris has been actively shaping her public image and addressing key issues, such as workers' rights and voting rights, which resonate with the Democratic base. Her proactive approach in communicating her record and values has helped counter misinformation and build a stronger connection with voters \[[8](https://www.teenvogue.com/story/symone-sanders-townsend-vice-president-harris?utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=dhtwitter&utm_content=null#:~:text=Addressing%20the%20United%20Auto%20Workers%20at%20a%20recent%20rally%2C%20she%20spoke%20extensively%20about%20her%20record%20of%20walking%20picket%20lines%20and%20advocating%20to%20protect%20worker%E2%80%99s%20rights)\]\[[10](https://www.thedailybeast.com/its-time-to-give-kamala-harris-her-due#:~:text=It%20is%20a%20subject%20that%20is%20especially%20significant%20to%20many%20voters%20given%20President%20Biden%E2%80%99s%20age%2C%20and%20it%20is%20one%20that%20should%20be%20addressed%20directly)\].

These factors collectively suggest that Kamala Harris is the frontrunner for the Democratic vice presidential nomination if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President in 2024.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What is the historical likelihood of an incumbent vice president becoming the vice presidential nominee if the incumbent president is no longer running?
Answer:
The historical likelihood of an incumbent vice president becoming the vice presidential nominee if the incumbent president is no longer running is relatively low. Historically, this scenario has only occurred twice: in 1808 with George Clinton and in 1828 with John C. Calhoun, both of whom were re-elected as vice presidents with new presidents-elect \[[3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President-elect_of_the_United_States#:~:text=No%20president%20has%20sought%20reelection%20with%20a%20running%20mate%20different%20than%20their%20incumbent%20vice%20president%20since%20Gerald%20Ford%20did%20so%20unsuccessfully%20in%201976)\]\[[13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President-elect_of_the_United_States#:~:text=%20It%20is%20possible%20for%20an%20incumbent%20vice%20president%20to%20win%20reelection%20as%20the%20running%20mate%20of%20a%20new%20president-elect%2C%20in%20which%20case%20there%20would%20be%20a%20United%20States%20presidential%20transition%20with%20the%20election%20of%20a%20new%20president-elect%2C%20but%20there%20would%20be%20no%20vice%20president-elect)\]. 

Additionally, vice presidential candidates generally come from those who did not seek the presidency that year, and only a minority of vice presidential nominees had previously run for president \[[2](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20have%20come%20from%20those%20who%20did%20not%20seek%20the%20presidency%20that%20year)\]\[[8](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Occasionally%2C%20the%20running%20mate%20sought%20the%20presidential%20nomination%20previously)\]. This suggests that the selection of an incumbent vice president as the vice presidential nominee in the absence of the incumbent president is not a common occurrence.
## Q1: In past U.S. elections, how often has the vice presidential nominee been a former presidential candidate or a sitting senator?
Answer:
In past U.S. elections, the vice presidential nominee has often been a former presidential candidate or a sitting senator. Specifically, there have been several instances where vice presidential candidates had previously sought their party's presidential nomination. For example, Hubert Humphrey, who was Lyndon B. Johnson's running mate in 1964, had unsuccessfully sought the Democratic presidential nomination in 1952 and 1960 \[[9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey#:~:text=He%20unsuccessfully%20sought%20his%20party%27s%20presidential%20nomination%20in%201952%20and%201960)\]. Additionally, Thomas A. Hendricks, who was Grover Cleveland's running mate in 1884, had previously been the Democratic vice presidential candidate in 1876 \[[13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_A._Hendricks#:~:text=%20Hendricks%2C%20a%20lifelong%20Democrat%2C%20was%20his%20party%27s%20candidate%20for%20U)\].

Moreover, it is common for sitting senators to be chosen as vice presidential nominees. For instance, Senator Edmund Muskie was chosen as Hubert Humphrey's running mate in 1968 \[[8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey#:~:text=After%20Lyndon%20B)\]. This trend indicates that individuals with significant political experience, either as former presidential candidates or sitting senators, are frequently considered for the vice presidential nomination.
## Q2: How frequently do political parties choose vice presidential nominees who are not widely known or discussed in the media?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Jeff Jackson)," it is important to understand the historical and current practices of vice presidential selection.

Historically, vice presidential nominees were selected by party members through the 1950s, often as a compromise without necessarily any recommendation by the leading presidential candidate. This practice changed in the 1960s when leading presidential candidates began to quasi-unilaterally select their running mates, a practice that has become the standard \[[1](https://thefederalist.com/2016/07/22/presidential-candidates-shouldnt-get-to-pick-their-veeps-2/#:~:text=The%20delegates%20have%20been%20accepting%20these%20without%20making%20any%20other%20nominations%20or%20even%20much%20debate%2C%20thereby%20effectively%20rendering%20the%20vice%20presidential%20nomination%20a%20quasi-unilateral%20selection%20by%20the%20leading%20presidential%20candidate%20instead%20of%20the%20choice%20of%20the%20delegates)\]\[[4](https://thefederalist.com/2016/07/22/presidential-candidates-shouldnt-get-to-pick-their-veeps-2/#:~:text=Convention%20delegates%2C%20who%20represent%20the%20members%20of%20their%20party%2C%20customarily%20had%20chosen%20their%20party%E2%80%99s%20vice%20presidential%20nominees%20through%20the%201950s%20in%20the%20best%20interest%20of%20their%20party%E2%80%94often%20as%20a%20compromise%E2%80%94without%20necessarily%20any%20recommendation%20by%20the%20leading%20presidential%20candidate)\]\[[10](https://thefederalist.com/2016/07/22/presidential-candidates-shouldnt-get-to-pick-their-veeps-2/#:~:text=Leaving%20the%20vice%20presidential%20selection%20to%20the%20total%20discretion%20of%20the%20delegates%20is%20more%20representative%20of%20the%20party%20membership%20than%20a%20unilateral%20choice%20by%20the%20leading%20presidential%20candidate)\]. This shift means that the selection process is now highly personal and idiosyncratic to the presidential candidate, who determines the criteria and decision-making process \[[6](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=The%20process%20by%20which%20a%20vice%20presidential%20selection%20is%20made%20is%20highly%20personal%20to%20the%20presidential%20candidate%E2%80%94and%20it%20is%20fair%20to%20say%20that%20it%20can%20be%20idiosyncratic)\]\[[14](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=Vice%20presidents%20must%20be%20of%20presidential%20timber%2C%20able%20to%20step%20into%20the%20nation%E2%80%99s%20highest%20office)\]. 

Given this context, it is less common for political parties to choose vice presidential nominees who are not widely known or discussed in the media, as the selection is typically a strategic decision made by the presidential candidate to balance the ticket and appeal to specific constituencies \[[9](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=In%20the%20upcoming%20months%2C%20the%20presidential%20nominees%20of%20each%20political%20party%20will%20make%20one%20of%20their%20most%20consequential%20decisions%20on%20the%20campaign%20trail%3A%20the%20selection%20of%20a%20running%20mate)\]\[[13](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=Of%20course%2C%20politics%20will%20play%20a%20role%20in%20the%20selection)\]. Therefore, the likelihood of an obscure or lesser-known figure being chosen as the vice presidential nominee is relatively low under the current selection practices.
## Q3: What are the success rates of vice presidential picks who were governors at the time of their selection?
Answer:
The success rates of vice presidential picks who were governors at the time of their selection are relatively low in modern times. Historically, 16 out of 49 vice presidents (33%) had previously been governors, but this trend has diminished significantly in recent decades. Since Calvin Coolidge ascended to the presidency in 1923, only three of the 18 vice presidents have been former governors \[[4](https://governors.rutgers.edu/governors-and-the-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Sixteen%20of%20them%20%2833%25%29%20were%20previously%20governors%2C%20including%20George%20Clinton%2C%20who%20served%20from%201805%20to%201812%20as%20the%20number%20two%20to%20two%20presidents%20%28Thomas%20Jefferson%20and%20James%20Madison%29%20and%20Nelson%20Rockefeller%2C%20who%20was%20appointed%20to%20the%20office%201974)\]. This indicates that while governors have been a source for vice presidential candidates, their selection has become less common over time.

Moreover, the success rate of governors as vice presidential picks is not particularly high. For instance, only six teams of governors or former governors have been victorious, with the last such victory occurring in 1912 \[[1](https://www.nj.com/njv_guest_blog/2012/07/governors_becoming_vice_presid.html#:~:text=One%2C%20Spiro%20Agnew%20%28Maryland%29%2C%20was%20elected%20and%20re-elected%20in%201968%20and%201972%2C%20and%20the%20other%2C%20Rockefeller%20%28New%20York%29%2C%20was%20appointed%20in%201974)\]. This historical context suggests that the likelihood of a governor being selected and successfully elected as vice president is relatively low, especially in the modern political landscape.
## Q4: How often have vice presidential nominees been selected from key battleground states in the last 40 years?
Answer:
In the last 40 years, the selection of vice-presidential nominees from key battleground states has been a strategic consideration for both major political parties, including the Democratic Party. However, specific instances of such selections are relatively rare and context-dependent.

- **Tim Kaine (2016)**: Hillary Clinton selected Tim Kaine, a senator from Virginia, a key battleground state, as her running mate. Virginia had been a swing state in recent elections, and Kaine's selection was seen as a move to secure its electoral votes.
- **Al Gore (1992)**: Bill Clinton chose Al Gore from Tennessee, which was considered a battleground state at the time. This selection was part of a broader strategy to appeal to Southern voters and present a centrist ticket.

These examples illustrate that while selecting a vice-presidential nominee from a battleground state can be a strategic move, it is not a consistent trend. The decision often depends on various factors, including the political landscape, the candidates' profiles, and the overall campaign strategy.

For further context, the selection of vice-presidential candidates has historically been influenced by a range of considerations beyond just geographic strategy, such as balancing the ticket ideologically, appealing to specific demographics, and complementing the presidential candidate's strengths and weaknesses \[[3](https://ideas.time.com/2012/08/06/through-the-looking-glass-of-veep-picks/#:~:text=They%20were%20the%20nominees%20of%20the%20Democratic%20Party%20for%20President%20and%20Vice%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States%2C%20and%20they%20were%20players%20in%20a%20drama%20that%20would%20soon%20force%20the%20No)\]\[[10](https://ideas.time.com/2012/08/06/through-the-looking-glass-of-veep-picks/#:~:text=The%20story%20of%20Thomas%20Eagleton%E2%80%99s%20brief%20nomination%20as%20George%20McGovern%E2%80%99s%20running%20mate%20looms%20large%20in%20political%20memory%20because%20of%20the%20revelation%20in%20the%20days%20after%20the%20Democratic%20National%20Convention%20in%20Miami%20in%201972%20that%20he%20had%20undergone%20electric-shock%20therapy%20to%20combat%20depression%20%E2%80%94%20a%20fact%20kept%20from%20McGovern%20and%20thus%20from%20the%20Democratic%20delegates)\].
## Q5: What is the historical success rate of vice presidential nominees with military backgrounds or significant experience in national defense?
Answer:
The historical success rate of vice presidential nominees with military backgrounds or significant experience in national defense is not explicitly detailed in the sources provided. However, we can infer some relevant insights from the broader context of political experience and military service among U.S. presidents and vice presidents.

- **Military Service Among Presidents**: Of the 45 men elected president of the United States, 31 have had prior military service, indicating a significant historical preference for leaders with military backgrounds \[[7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_military_service#:~:text=Of%20the%2045%20men%20elected%20president%20of%20the%20United%20States%2C%2031%20have%20had%20prior%20military%20service%2C%20while%20only%2014%20have%20had%20no%20prior%20military%20service)\]. This suggests that military experience can be a valuable asset in a political career, potentially enhancing a candidate's appeal.

- **Vice Presidential Nominees**: While specific data on vice presidential nominees with military backgrounds is not provided, it is noted that senators are the most common source of first-time vice presidential nominees, followed by high executive branch officials, governors, and members of the House \[[1](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=The%20average%20for%20the%20last%2014%20first-time%20running%20mates%20is%2014%20years)\]. This implies that political experience, rather than military service alone, is a key factor in vice presidential selections.

- **Public Perception**: After the American Civil War, whether a politician had fought greatly influenced the public's perception of his appropriateness for the presidency. This influence diminished over time but highlights the historical importance of military service in political candidacies \[[15](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_military_service#:~:text=Their%20service%20ranks%20range%20from%20private%20in%20a%20state%20militia%20to%20the%20general%20of%20the%20army)\].

In summary, while military service has historically been a significant factor for presidential candidates, the selection of vice presidential nominees tends to prioritize political experience. This context suggests that while a military background can be beneficial, it is not the primary criterion for vice presidential selection.
## Q6: In the past 50 years, how often have vice presidential nominees been endorsed or significantly supported by influential party figures or former presidents?
Answer:
In the past 50 years, vice presidential nominees have often been endorsed or significantly supported by influential party figures or former presidents. For instance, starting with Richard Nixon in 1960, every elected vice president except Dan Quayle has led in a majority of the Gallup polls measuring the party rank and file's pre-convention preferences for president. This indicates a strong trend of vice presidents being the presumptive front-runners for their party's presidential nomination, often with substantial backing from influential party members \[[12](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Vice%20presidents%20have%20become%20the%20presumptive%20front-runners%20for%20their%20party%27s%20presidential%20nomination)\]. Additionally, the roles and resources of the vice presidency have grown in recent years, further solidifying their position within the party \[[12](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Vice%20presidents%20have%20become%20the%20presumptive%20front-runners%20for%20their%20party%27s%20presidential%20nomination)\].

Moreover, historical examples show that vice presidential candidates have frequently been chosen to bring balance to the ticket or to unify different wings of the party, often with the endorsement of party bigwigs. For example, Walter F. Mondale in 1976, George H.W. Bush in 1980, and Al Gore in 1992 were all vice presidential candidates with significant political experience and backing from influential figures within their parties \[[11](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Starting%20in%201948%2C%20the%20vice%20presidential%20candidate%20as%20often%20as%20not%20has%20been%20the%20more%20experienced%20member%20of%20the%20ticket%20in%20high%20government%20office%2C%20including%20recent%20nominees%20such%20as%20Walter%20F)\]. This pattern underscores the importance of endorsements and support from influential party figures in the selection of vice presidential nominees.
## Q7: How often have vice presidential nominees been chosen based on their fundraising capabilities and ability to generate substantial campaign funds?
Answer:
In the context of selecting vice presidential nominees, historical data and expert insights suggest that fundraising capabilities and the ability to generate substantial campaign funds are not primary factors in the selection process. According to a report by the Bipartisan Policy Center, the selection of a vice presidential nominee is influenced more by political considerations, such as providing electoral benefits in a particular state or with an important constituency, rather than their fundraising prowess \[[8](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=We%20have%20been%20advisors%20to%20presidential%20campaigns%3A%20legal%20advisors%2C%20campaign%20managers%2C%20communications%20experts%2C%20and%20political%20party%20representatives)\]\[[13](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=In%20the%20upcoming%20months%2C%20the%20presidential%20nominees%20of%20each%20political%20party%20will%20make%20one%20of%20their%20most%20consequential%20decisions%20on%20the%20campaign%20trail%3A%20the%20selection%20of%20a%20running%20mate)\]. 

While campaign finance regulations and public funding guidelines are stringent for presidential candidates, there is no specific emphasis on the vice presidential candidate's individual fundraising capabilities in the selection process \[[1](https://www.fec.gov/help-candidates-and-committees/understanding-public-funding-presidential-elections/additional-recordkeeping-publicly-funded-presidential-candidates/#:~:text=Presidential%20candidates%20seeking%20their%20party%27s%20nomination%20can%20qualify%20to%20receive%20matching%20funds%20by%20raising%20over%20%245%2C000%20in%20each%20of%2020%20states%20%28that%20is%2C%20over%20%24100%2C000%29)\]\[[2](https://www.fec.gov/help-candidates-and-committees/understanding-public-funding-presidential-elections/public-funding-vice-presidential-candidates/#:~:text=To%20be%20eligible%20to%20receive%20a%20public%20funding%20grant%20for%20the%20general%20election%2C%20the%20candidates%20must%20agree%20to%20limit%20spending%20to%20the%20amount%20of%20the%20grant%20and%20may%20not%20accept%20private%20contributions%20for%20the%20campaign)\]. The focus remains on strategic political advantages rather than financial contributions.

question.question_text: If these candidates are nominated, will they win the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Tim Scott (R))
question.resolution_criteria:
Each listed candidate will be **Annulled** if they do not win the nomination of the party they are campaigning for.  Candidates will be considered to be nominated by either the Democratic or Republican parties if they recieve that party's nomination on Election Day 2024; candidates continuing to campaign as write-in candidates or under third-party bids will be **Annulled**.

For only the remaining 2 candidates who recieve either the Democratic or Republican nomination, they will resolve as **Yes** if they win the US Presidential Election, or **No** if they do not win the election.  Winners will be determined by winning at least 270 Electoral College votes, as certified by US Congress.  This question may resolve early after winners have been projected by major news outlets; however, the final determination will be solely by the certification by Congress if results differ.
question.background_info:
As of June 2023, incumbent US president Joe Biden has [declared](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/joe-biden-running-reelection-2024-setting-trump-rematch/story?id=98801535) that he will seek the Democratic Party's nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  On the Republican side, frontrunners include former US President [Donald Trump](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/donald-trump-announces-2024-re-election-run-president) and Florida Governor [Ron DeSantis](https://apnews.com/article/ron-desantis-2024-presidential-election-live-updates-0495d567326db1e760179d01f1f7c45e).

Because both parties use (mostly) [first-past-the-post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-past-the-post_voting) to select their candidates, major candidates tend to keep momentum, with little opportunity for smaller candidates to be seriously considered.

# SUMMARY
*Question*: If these candidates are nominated, will they win the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Tim Scott (R))

*Final Prediction*: 0.5%

*Total Cost*: $0.95

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 0.5%] Chose a base rate of 0.01% for Republican primary candidates polling under 5% nationally in August, adjusted up for financial backing and engagement in key states, but adjusted down for low polling, lack of endorsements, debate struggles, and campaign suspension.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 0.3%] Chose a base rate of 0.01% for Republican primary candidates polling under 5% nationally in August, adjusted up for financial backing and engagement, but adjusted down for lack of endorsements, debate struggles, donor concerns, campaign suspension, and low prediction market odds.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 1.0%] Chose a base rate of 0.01% for Republican primary candidates polling under 5% nationally in August, adjusted slightly up for financial backing and engagement, but kept close to the base rate due to low polling, lack of endorsements, debate struggles, and campaign suspension.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 0.5%] Chose a base rate of 0.01% for Republican primary candidates polling under 5% nationally in August, adjusted slightly up for financial backing and engagement, but adjusted down for low polling, lack of endorsements, debate struggles, and campaign suspension.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 1.0%] Chose a base rate of 0.01% for Republican primary candidates polling under 5% nationally in August, adjusted up for financial backing and engagement, but adjusted down for low polling, lack of endorsements, debate struggles, and campaign suspension.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on Tim Scott's chances of winning the 2024 US Presidential Election if he secures the Republican nomination. As of August 2024, Scott is polling very low in the Republican primary, with no major endorsements from key Republican figures. His campaign has significant financial backing from Larry Ellison and has been active in key early primary states like Iowa. However, Scott has struggled to qualify for debates and faces higher thresholds for future debates. Prediction market odds for Scott winning the Republican nomination and the general election are very low, and political analysts have mixed views on his chances, with many seeing his campaign as struggling.

Scott's campaign faced significant setbacks, including the suspension of his campaign in November 2023. Historical data indicates that candidates with low polling numbers, even with significant financial resources, face substantial challenges in winning the nomination. Candidates who fail to qualify for early debates but gain traction later generally do not win the nomination. The likelihood of a candidate polling under 5% nationally in August of the election year winning the nomination is extremely low, likely under 1%.

## Possible Base Rates
- The percentage of Republican primary candidates who were polling under 5% nationally in August of the election year and went on to win the nomination is very low, likely under 1% [S2.Q0]
- The percentage of Republican primary candidates who did not receive major endorsements or support from key Republican figures and went on to win the nomination is likely very close to 0% [S2.Q1]
- Candidates with significant financial backing but low polling numbers have historically struggled to win the Republican nomination [S2.Q2]
- Candidates who fail to qualify for early debates but gain traction later have a low likelihood of winning the nomination in the current political climate [S2.Q3]
- The percentage of Republican primary candidates who were not leading in prediction markets in August of the election year and went on to win the nomination is relatively rare [S2.Q4]
- Candidates with grassroots support but low initial polling numbers rarely succeed in the primaries unless they gain significant institutional backing [S2.Q6]
- Candidates who suspended their campaigns early in the race and re-entered successfully are rare [S2.Q7]

## Pros
- Tim Scott has significant financial backing from Larry Ellison [S1.Q1]
- Scott has been actively engaging with voters in key early primary states like Iowa [S1.Q1]
- Scott has launched a significant $8 million ad blitz in key early GOP nominating states [S1.Q2]

## Cons

- Scott has not received major endorsements or support from key Republican figures recently [S1.Q1]

# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What are the current polling numbers for Tim Scott in the Republican primary as of August 2024?
Answer:
As of August 2024, there is no specific polling data available for Tim Scott in the Republican primary from the provided search results. The search results primarily focus on the general election matchups between Donald Trump, Kamala Harris, and other candidates, as well as issues important to voters. 

For example, Rasmussen Reports indicates that in a hypothetical general election matchup, Donald Trump leads Kamala Harris with 49% to 44%, with RFK Jr. at 3% \[[2](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/biden_administration/election_2024_trump_49_harris_44_rfk_jr_3#:~:text=We%20conduct%20public%20opinion%20polls%20on%20a%20variety%20of%20topics%20to%20inform%20our%20audience%20on%20events%20in%20the%20news%20and%20other%20topics%20of%20interest)\]\[[4](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/biden_administration/election_2024_trump_49_harris_44_rfk_jr_3#:~:text=Four%20percent%20%284%25%29%20say%20they%E2%80%99d%20vote%20for%20some%20other%20candidate%20and%20three%20percent%20%283%25%29%20are%20undecided)\]\[[5](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/biden_administration/election_2024_trump_49_harris_44_rfk_jr_3#:~:text=Voters%20would%20vote%20for%20Trump%2C%20while%2044%25%20would%20vote%20for%20Harris)\]. Additionally, Ipsos reports that the race between Trump and Harris is very close in swing states, with Harris receiving 42% of the vote share and Trump 40%, indicating a tight race \[[1](https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/ipsos-2024-us-swing-state-election-survey-august-2024#:~:text=For%20Americans%20living%20in%20these%20swing%20states%2C%20most%20would%20like%20to%20see%20Supreme%20Court%20reforms%2C%20namely%20a%20code%20of%20ethics%20and%20term%20limits)\]\[[3](https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/ipsos-2024-us-swing-state-election-survey-august-2024#:~:text=To%20see%20how%20these%20respondents%20in%20Michigan%2C%20Pennsylvania%2C%20Wisconsin%2C%20Georgia%2C%20North%20Carolina%2C%20Arizona%20and%20Nevada%20felt%20about%20the%20election%20in%20June%202024%2C%20please%20click%20here)\]\[[10](https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/ipsos-2024-us-swing-state-election-survey-august-2024#:~:text=For%20registered%20voters%20in%20these%20swing%20states%2C%20the%20race%20remains%20a%20dead%20heat)\].

To get the most accurate and up-to-date polling numbers for Tim Scott in the Republican primary, it would be advisable to consult specific polling organizations or databases that track primary election polling, such as RealClearPolitics, FiveThirtyEight, or directly from polling firms like Ipsos or Rasmussen Reports.
## Q1: Has Tim Scott received any major endorsements or support from key Republican figures recently?
Answer:
As of the latest available information, Tim Scott has not received any major endorsements or support from key Republican figures recently. However, it is noteworthy that Larry Ellison, co-founder of Oracle, has donated millions of dollars to support Scott’s presidential bid and is considered one of Scott's mentors \[[15](https://www.cnn.com/2023/08/28/politics/tim-scott-education-plan/index.html#:~:text=Ellison%20has%20donated%20millions%20of%20dollars%20to%20support%20Scott%E2%80%99s%20presidential%20bid%2C%20and%20Scott%20referred%20to%20Ellison%20as%20%E2%80%9Cone%20of%20my%20mentors%E2%80%9D%20during%20his%20campaign%20launch%20event%20in%20May)\]. This financial backing could be significant in bolstering Scott's campaign infrastructure and visibility.

Additionally, Scott has been actively engaging with voters in key early primary states like Iowa, which could help him build grassroots support \[[4](https://www.postandcourier.com/politics/as-tim-scott-returns-to-iowa-presidential-buzz-follows-but-what-does-he-really-want/article_19c1c99a-23b8-11ed-8904-476006d1c604.html#:~:text=The%20senator%20has%20been%20spending%20more%20time%20in%20the%20first%20state%20to%20caucus%20each%20presidential%20primary%20cycle%2C%20further%20fueling%20speculations%20about%20what%20role%20he%20will%20play%20in%202024)\]. While these activities are important, they do not equate to high-profile endorsements from influential Republican figures, which are often crucial in gaining broader party support.
## Q2: What are the latest updates or news regarding Tim Scott's campaign activities and strategy?

Bush \[[12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Dukakis_1988_presidential_campaign#:~:text=The%201988%20presidential%20campaign%20of%20Michael%20Dukakis%20began%20when%20he%20announced%20his%20candidacy%20for%20the%20Democratic%20Party%27s%20nomination%20for%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States%20on%20March%2016%2C%201987%2C%20in%20a%20speech%20in%20Boston)\].

2. **Ross Perot (1992)**: Although not a major party candidate, Perot's campaign is notable for his significant impact despite starting as an outsider. He garnered 18.9% of the popular vote, the highest for a third-party candidate since Theodore Roosevelt in 1912, but did not win any electoral votes \[[6](https://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Ross_Perot#:~:text=Henry%20Ross%20Perot%20%281930%E2%80%932019%29%20had%20big%20ears%2C%20a%20crazy%20Texas%20drawl%2C%20and%20twice%20ran%20for%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States%2C%20once%20as%20an%20independent%20in%201992%2C%20and%20again%20as%20the%20standard-bearer%20of%20his%20own%20Reform%20Party%20in%201996)\]\[[9](https://www.biography.com/political-figure/ross-perot#:~:text=Perot%20was%20the%20first%20independent%20candidate%20since%20Teddy%20Roosevelt%20in%201912%20to%20receive%20this%20large%20of%20a%20share%20of%20the%20popular%20vote)\].

3. **Woodrow Wilson (1912)**: Wilson, initially not a frontrunner, won the Democratic nomination and subsequently the general election. However, his victory was facilitated by a split in the Republican vote between Taft and Roosevelt \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1912#:~:text=Democratic%20Governor%20Woodrow%20Wilson%20unseated%20incumbent%20Republican%20President%20William%20Howard%20Taft%20and%20defeated%20former%20President%20Theodore%20Roosevelt%2C%20who%20ran%20under%20the%20banner%20of%20the%20new%20Progressive%20or%20%22Bull%20Moose%22%20Party)\]\[[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1912#:~:text=Wilson%20was%20the%20first%20Democrat%20to%20win%20a%20presidential%20election%20since%201892%20and%20one%20of%20just%20three%20Democratic%20presidents%20to%20serve%20during%20an%20era%20of%20the%20Republican%20Party%20presidential%20domination%20from%201861%20%28the%20start%20of%20the%20American%20Civil%20War%29%2C%20to%201933%20%28the%20onset%20of%20the%20Great%20Depression%29)\].

These examples suggest that while it is possible for candidates with low initial polling numbers to secure their party's nomination, winning the general election remains a significant challenge. The historical data does not provide a clear percentage of such candidates who have won the general election, but the rarity of these occurrences implies a low success rate.
## Q6: How often have candidates with grassroots support but low initial polling numbers succeeded in the primaries?
Answer:
Candidates with grassroots support but low initial polling numbers have historically faced significant challenges in succeeding in the primaries. The concept of the "invisible primary" is crucial here, where candidates compete for support from party leaders, fellow politicians, and donors before the actual primary elections begin. A candidate who wins the invisible primary usually wins the party nomination, or at least tends to be a close runner-up \[[5](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/us/elections/presidential-candidates-dashboard.html#:~:text=The%20polls%20get%20most%20of%20the%20attention%2C%20but%20they%20have%20not%20historically%20been%20the%20most%20important%20part%20of%20the%20early%20stages%20of%20a%20presidential%20campaign)\]. 

Moreover, front-runners who dominate the invisible primary almost always win the subsequent primary elections and the party presidential nomination. This dominance is often established through positive name recognition, fundraising ability, and endorsements from party elites \[[7](https://getd.libs.uga.edu/pdfs/jackson_joseph_c_200208_ma.pdf#:~:text=This%20candidate%2C%20referred%20to%20as%20the%20front-runner%2C%20almost%20always%20wins%20the%20subsequent%20primary%20elections%20and%20the%20party%20presidential%20nomination)\]\[[12](https://getd.libs.uga.edu/pdfs/jackson_joseph_c_200208_ma.pdf#:~:text=In%20the%20invisible%20primary%2C%20one%20candidate%20will%20usually%20begin%20to%20dominate%20all%20the%20others)\]. While grassroots support can be a valuable asset, it is typically not sufficient on its own to overcome the advantages held by front-runners who have already secured significant institutional backing and financial resources.

In summary, while there are exceptions, the historical trend suggests that candidates with low initial polling numbers and grassroots support rarely succeed in the primaries unless they can significantly improve their standing in the invisible primary by gaining endorsements, increasing name recognition, and raising substantial funds.
## Q7: What percentage of candidates who suspended their campaigns early in the race were able to re-enter and gain significant traction?
Answer:
Based on the available information, there is no direct historical data on the percentage of candidates who suspended their campaigns early in the race and were able to re-enter and gain significant traction. However, we can infer some insights from notable examples of political comebacks and campaign dynamics:

- **Barack Obama (2008)**: Obama trailed Hillary Clinton by nearly 28 points in October of the off year but eventually won the Democratic primary and the general election \[[3](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/08/01/nobody-has-lost-primary-after-holding-lead-like-trumps/#:~:text=In%20the%202008%20Democratic%20primary%2C%20Barack%20Obama%20trailed%20Hillary%20Clinton%20by%20an%20average%20of%20nearly%2028%20points%20in%20October%20of%20the%20off%20year%2C%20before%20winning%20one%20of%20the%20tightest%20delegate%20races%20in%20history)\].
- **George McGovern (1972)**: McGovern began his campaign trailing by nearly 30 points but managed to pull off a significant surprise by winning the Democratic primary \[[1](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/08/01/nobody-has-lost-primary-after-holding-lead-like-trumps/#:~:text=%29%20began%20his%201972%20Democratic%20primary%20campaign%20trailing%20Sen)\]\[[3](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/08/01/nobody-has-lost-primary-after-holding-lead-like-trumps/#:~:text=In%20the%202008%20Democratic%20primary%2C%20Barack%20Obama%20trailed%20Hillary%20Clinton%20by%20an%20average%20of%20nearly%2028%20points%20in%20October%20of%20the%20off%20year%2C%20before%20winning%20one%20of%20the%20tightest%20delegate%20races%20in%20history)\].
- **Ron DeSantis (2024)**: Although not a historical example of re-entering after suspension, DeSantis's current campaign highlights the difficulty of overcoming large deficits in modern primaries. He trails Donald Trump by more than 37 points, and no nominee has made up such a gap since the 1970s \[[13](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/08/01/nobody-has-lost-primary-after-holding-lead-like-trumps/#:~:text=Ron%20DeSantis%20%28R%29%20launched%20his%20presidential%20campaign%20with%20a%20slogan%20promising%20a%20%E2%80%9CGreat%20American%20Comeback)\].

These examples suggest that while significant comebacks are possible, they are rare and often require extraordinary circumstances or shifts in voter sentiment. The lack of specific data on re-entering candidates implies that such occurrences are not common enough to be well-documented.

In summary, while there are instances of candidates overcoming large deficits, the historical data does not provide a clear percentage of those who suspended and then re-entered successfully. This suggests that the likelihood of such a scenario is low.

question.question_text: Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Gavin Newsom)
question.resolution_criteria:
If Joe Biden is not the Democratic Party's nominee for President in 2024, this group question will resolve as **Yes** for the person who is the Democratic Party's nominee for Vice President on November 5, 2024 (Election Day). All other choices will resolve as **No**.

If Joe Biden is the Democratic presidential nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, then this question will be **annulled**.
question.fine_print:
This is a group question rather than multiple choice, which means each individual option is like its own Yes or No question. Please note that as a forecaster this means two things: 

1. You do not have to assign probabilities to every choice.
2. Your predictions do not have to sum up to 100%.

More choices might be added later, depending on credible reporting that someone is in serious contention for VP.
question.background_info:
In the wake of what the New York Times [described](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/30/us/politics/biden-campaign-debate-scramble.html) as a "disastrous" presidential debate with Donald Trump on June 28, 2024, Joe Biden's candidacy was left in a suddenly-precarious position, according to the Times. Metaculus forecasters on June 30, 2024 [assessed](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/) only an 80% chance of Biden being the Democratic presidential nominee, despite Biden having won 3,894 [pledged delegates](https://apnews.com/hub/ap-election-2024-delegate-tracker) to the Democratic National Convention (which is 98.9% of all delegates; 1,976 are needed for nomination).  

According to a [CNN analysis](https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/28/politics/election-biden-presidential-race-what-matters/index.html), if President Biden withdrew himself from contention, the assumption would be that his running mate Kamala Harris would be favorite to replace him at the top of the ticket, due to the delegates being pledged to vote for Biden and approved by the Biden-Harris campaign. Should Harris be the presidential nominee, according to [Politico](https://www.politico.com/news/2024/06/28/can-democrats-replace-biden-00165684): 

>Even if Harris coasted to the nomination, she would need a vice presidential candidate of her own, and there would still be a fight among the party’s future stars to be her running mate.

>Any of Democrats’ rising stars would be a possibility, though Newsom would be particularly unlikely. Unless either changed their residency, a Harris-Newsom ticket would be ineligible for California’s 54 electoral votes — and there’s no realistic path to a Democratic victory without them.

See also The National Interest: [Who Would 'President' Kamala Harris Pick for Vice President?](https://nationalinterest.org/blog/reboot/who-would-president-kamala-harris-pick-vice-president-209064)

In modern times, the Democratic Party typically features its vice presidential nominee's acceptance speech on Day 3 of the convention (Kamala Harris example [here](https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/dnc-2020-day-3/index.html)), which [would be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention) August 21, 2024. Possibly the decision on the ticket would be officially made in a [virtual roll call](https://ohiocapitaljournal.com/2024/06/21/exclusive-dnc-moves-ahead-on-all-virtual-roll-call-for-biden-presidential-nomination/) before the convention. However, this question will resolve based on who the nominee actually is on Election Day, since a vice presidential nominee can still withdraw after the convention, for example [Thomas Eagleton](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/04/157670201/the-thomas-eagleton-affair-haunts-candidates-today) in 1972.

explanation:
# SUMMARY
*Question*: Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Gavin Newsom)

*Final Prediction*: 32.0%

*Total Cost*: $1.03

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 20.0%] Chose a base rate of 92% based on the historical likelihood of sitting vice presidents being selected for the vice presidential nomination if the president is not running for re-election. Adjusted down due to Kamala Harris naming Tim Walz as her running mate, the ineligibility of a Harris-Newsom ticket for California’s electoral votes, and Newsom's public denial of interest.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 32.0%] Chose a base rate of 47% based on the likelihood of vice presidents being chosen as the nominee when not blocked by an incumbent president. Adjusted down due to Newsom's public denial of interest, the ineligibility of a Harris-Newsom ticket for California's electoral votes, and Kamala Harris naming Tim Walz as her running mate.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 42.0%] Chose a base rate of 72% based on the historical success rate of vice-presidential nominees being chosen when they have significant political experience. Adjusted down due to the ineligibility of a Harris-Newsom ticket for California’s electoral votes, Newsom's progressive stance, and Kamala Harris naming Tim Walz as her running mate.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 39.0%] Chose a base rate of 92% based on the historical likelihood of vice presidents being selected for significant roles. Adjusted down due to Kamala Harris naming Tim Walz as her running mate, the ineligibility of a Harris-Newsom ticket for California’s electoral votes, and Newsom's progressive stance.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 20.0%] Chose a base rate of 80% based on the high likelihood of the VP nominee being confirmed by the convention date. Adjusted down due to the ineligibility of a Harris-Newsom ticket for California's electoral votes, Kamala Harris naming Tim Walz as her running mate, and Newsom's positioning for a 2028 presidential run.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on the likelihood of Gavin Newsom being the Democratic vice-presidential nominee if Joe Biden is no longer the presidential nominee in 2024. The forecasters considered various factors, including historical trends, political dynamics, and public statements. They noted that sitting vice presidents have a high likelihood of being selected for the vice-presidential nomination if the president is not running for re-election. However, the ineligibility of a Harris-Newsom ticket for California’s electoral votes and Newsom's public denial of interest were significant drawbacks.

The forecasters also examined the political landscape, noting that Kamala Harris has already named Tim Walz as her running mate, which significantly reduces the likelihood of Newsom being selected. Additionally, Newsom's strong progressive stance might alienate moderate voters in swing states. Despite these factors, Newsom's active engagement in national politics and his potential future presidential ambitions were considered as pros.

## Possible Base Rates
- In modern times, the Democratic Party typically features its vice presidential nominee's acceptance speech on Day 3 of the convention, which would be August 21, 2024 [S3.Forecaster 0]
- Historically, sitting vice presidents have a high likelihood of being selected for the vice presidential nomination if the president is not running for re-election. This is supported by the fact that 11 out of 12 vice presidents who ran for president while in office earned the primary nomination [S3.Forecaster 0]
- Incumbent vice presidents have a strong chance of being selected for the vice presidential nomination, with a historical success rate of 65% for carrying their home state and 72% in elections since World War II [S3.Forecaster 1]
- Vice presidents have a notable success rate in securing their party's nomination for higher office, with 11 out of 12 earning the primary nomination [S3.Forecaster 1]
- Since 1920, major-party nominees for president have carried their running mate’s home state 65% of the time, and this percentage is slightly higher at 72% in elections since World War II [S3.Forecaster 2]
- The historical trend suggests that the practice of selecting vice presidential candidates from outside the pool of primary contenders has been a long-standing tradition in U.S. politics [S3.Forecaster 3]

## Pros
- Gavin Newsom has been actively engaging in national politics, raising his profile [S3.Forecaster 0]
- Newsom has publicly supported Biden and Harris, demonstrating loyalty to the current administration [S3.Forecaster 0]
- Newsom is seen as a strong contender for the presidency in 2028, which could make him a strategic choice for VP [S3.Forecaster 2]
- Newsom has significant political influence as the Governor of California [S3.Forecaster 3]

## Cons
- A Harris-Newsom ticket would be ineligible for California’s 54 electoral votes, which is crucial for a Democratic victory [S3.Forecaster 0]
- Newsom has publicly denied interest in running for vice president [S3.Forecaster 0]
- Kamala Harris has already named Tim Walz as her running mate [S3.Forecaster 0]
- Newsom's strong progressive stance might alienate moderate voters in swing states [S3.Forecaster 2]

## Weaknesses and possible improvements
- *Ineligibility of Harris-Newsom ticket*: The research did not sufficiently explore alternative scenarios where the ineligibility of a Harris-Newsom ticket for California’s electoral votes could be mitigated. "A Harris-Newsom ticket would be ineligible for California’s 54 electoral votes, which is crucial for a Democratic victory."
- *Overemphasis on public denials*: The research placed significant weight on Newsom's public denials of interest, which historically have not precluded candidates from being selected. "Newsom has publicly denied interest in running for vice president."
- *Insufficient consideration of alternative candidates*: The research could have explored more deeply the potential for other candidates to be selected, given the significant drawbacks of a Harris-Newsom ticket. "Kamala Harris has already named Tim Walz as her running mate."


# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What are the current odds on Metaculus for Joe Biden being the Democratic presidential nominee?
Answer:
As of the latest available information, the current odds on Metaculus for Joe Biden being the Democratic presidential nominee for the 2024 election are not explicitly stated in the search results. However, it is noted that Joe Biden has expressed his intention to run for re-election, although no official statements of candidacy have been filed as of November 2021 \[[1](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8483/trump-victory-if-biden-v-trump-2024/#:~:text=The%202024%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20will%20be%20the%2060th%20quadrennial%20presidential%20election%2C%20scheduled%20for%20Tuesday%2C%20November%205%2C%202024)\]\[[3](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8483/trump-victory-if-biden-v-trump-2024/#:~:text=It%20will%20be%20the%20first%20presidential%20election%20after%20electoral%20votes%20are%20redistributed%20according%20to%20the%20post%E2%80%932020%20census%20reapportionment)\]\[[4](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8483/trump-victory-if-biden-v-trump-2024/#:~:text=Thanks%20for%20helping%21%20The%202024%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20will%20be%20the%2060th%20quadrennial%20presidential%20election%2C%20scheduled%20for%20Tuesday%2C%20November%205%2C%202024)\]\[[5](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8483/trump-victory-if-biden-v-trump-2024/#:~:text=Incumbent%20president%20Joe%20Biden%20has%20stated%20that%20he%20intends%20to%20run%20for%20re-election%20to%20a%20second%20term%2C%20although%20no%20official%20statements%20of%20candidacy%20have%20been%20filed%20as%20of%20November%203%2C%202021)\]. Additionally, there are concerns among top Democrat officials about a Biden re-election campaign, and uncertainty about selecting an alternative nominee has been reported \[[2](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=The%20New%20York%20Times%20reported%20in%20June%202022%20that%20many%20top%20Democrat%20officials%20expressed%20%28off%20the%20record%29%20concerns%20about%20a%20Biden%20re-election%20campaign%2C%20and%20uncertainty%20about%20selecting%20an%20alternative%20nominee)\]\[[6](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%2C%20often%20speculated%20as%20being%20likely%20to%20run%20in%202024%2C%20has%20had%20a%20net%20-10%25%20approval%20rating%20from%20January%20to%20June%202022)\]\[[9](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=As%20of%20June%202022%2C%20no%20other%20candidates%20have%20expressed%20intent%20to%20run%2C%20and%20no%20candidate%20%28besides%20Harris%29%2C%20stands%20out%20in%20early%20polling)\].

For the most accurate and up-to-date odds, it is recommended to directly check the Metaculus platform under the relevant question titled "Who will be the Democratic nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?" \[[2](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=The%20New%20York%20Times%20reported%20in%20June%202022%20that%20many%20top%20Democrat%20officials%20expressed%20%28off%20the%20record%29%20concerns%20about%20a%20Biden%20re-election%20campaign%2C%20and%20uncertainty%20about%20selecting%20an%20alternative%20nominee)\]\[[9](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=As%20of%20June%202022%2C%20no%20other%20candidates%20have%20expressed%20intent%20to%20run%2C%20and%20no%20candidate%20%28besides%20Harris%29%2C%20stands%20out%20in%20early%20polling)\].
## Q1: What do prediction markets like PredictIt, BetFair, and FiveThirtyEight forecast about Gavin Newsom being the Democratic vice presidential nominee if Biden is not the presidential nominee?
Answer:
Prediction markets like PredictIt, BetFair, and FiveThirtyEight do not provide specific forecasts about Gavin Newsom being the Democratic vice presidential nominee if Biden is not the presidential nominee. However, there are several key points to consider:

1. **Gavin Newsom's Political Positioning**: Newsom is widely seen as a strong contender for the presidency in 2028, and he has been actively engaging in national politics, which could position him as a potential vice-presidential candidate. He has been making appearances outside California and supporting Democratic candidates in other states, which is often seen as a move to raise his national profile \[[8](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/11/30/gavin-newsom-presidential-race-2028/#:~:text=Newsom%2C%20seen%20widely%20in%20the%20Democratic%20Party%20as%20a%202028%20presidential%20contender-in-waiting%2C%20isn%E2%80%99t%20doing%20all%20that%20much%20waiting)\]\[[9](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/12/california-gavin-newsom-biden-president-2024#:~:text=%E2%80%9COne%20is%20a%20congressman%20from%20Minnesota%2C%20the%20other%20is%20the%20governor%20of%20California%2C%20but%20only%20one%20has%20the%20guts%20to%20announce%20it)\]\[[12](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/11/30/gavin-newsom-presidential-race-2028/#:~:text=President%20Biden%E2%80%99s%20decision%20to%20seek%20reelection%20in%202024%20has%20put%20an%20ambitious%20new%20generation%20of%20Democrats%20in%20something%20of%20a%20holding%20pattern%20%E2%80%94%20with%20many%20joining%20the%20front%20lines%20of%20the%20efforts%20to%20support%20him%20as%20they%20seek%20to%20leave%20their%20own%20marks%20for%20the%20future)\].

2. **Democratic Party Dynamics**: There are concerns within the Democratic Party about Biden's age and viability for a second term, which has led to speculation about potential successors. Newsom is among the younger, prominent Democrats who could step in if Biden were to step down \[[3](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/12/california-gavin-newsom-biden-president-2024#:~:text=ne%20of%20the%20strongest%20candidates%20for%20US%20president%20in%202024%20may%20be%20one%20who%E2%80%99s%20not%20yet%20in%20the%20race)\]\[[4](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/12/california-gavin-newsom-biden-president-2024#:~:text=Several%20developments%20in%20recent%20days%20suggest%20Newsom%2C%20who%20romped%20to%20re-election%20a%20year%20ago%20without%20really%20campaigning%2C%20is%20ready%20to%20bring%20forward%20what%20was%20already%20expected%20to%20be%20a%20strong%20run%20for%20the%20presidency%20in%202028)\]\[[6](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/12/california-gavin-newsom-biden-president-2024#:~:text=There%20are%20mounting%20concerns%20inside%20the%20Democratic%20party%2C%20matching%20polling%20among%20voters%2C%20that%20Biden%20is%20too%20old%20for%20a%20second%20term%2C%20the%20start%20of%20which%20in%20January%202025%20would%20see%20him%20two%20months%20past%20his%2082nd%20birthday%20if%20re-elected)\].

3. **Public Statements and Speculation**: Newsom has publicly denied any immediate ambitions to replace Biden, emphasizing his support for Biden's re-election campaign. However, political analysts and some Democratic insiders speculate that he could be a strategic choice for the vice-presidential slot due to his popularity and political acumen \[[2](https://www.newsweek.com/democrats-are-already-grooming-gavin-newsom-bidens-2028-successor-1830103#:~:text=Speaking%20to%20The%20New%20York%20Times%20earlier%20in%20September%20Newsom%20rejected%20the%20suggestion%20Democrats%20could%20nominate%20somebody%20other%20than%20Biden%20as%20their%202024%20candidate%2C%20commenting%3A%20%22The%20train%20has%20left%20the%20station%E2%80%A6We%27re%20all%20in)\]\[[7](https://www.newsweek.com/democrats-are-already-grooming-gavin-newsom-bidens-2028-successor-1830103#:~:text=%22%20Thomas%20Whalen%2C%20an%20associate%20professor%20of%20political%20science%20at%20Boston%20University%2C%20told%20Newsweek%20the%20move%20could%20be%20Biden%20%22signaling%20he%27d%20rather%20have%20Newsom%22%20as%20his%202024%20running%20mate%20than%20current%20Vice-President%20Kamala%20Harris)\]\[[11](https://www.newsweek.com/democrats-are-already-grooming-gavin-newsom-bidens-2028-successor-1830103#:~:text=The%20move%20is%20the%20latest%20sign%20in%20a%20burgeoning%20alliance%20between%20Biden%20and%20Newsom%2C%20who%20previously%20had%20a%20tense%20relationship%2C%20triggering%20speculation%20the%20California%20governor%20is%20being%20viewed%20in%20the%20White%20House%20as%20a%20natural%20successor%20for%202028)\].

In summary, while there is no direct forecast from prediction markets about Newsom being the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, his active national engagement and the internal dynamics of the Democratic Party make him a plausible candidate if Biden is not the presidential nominee.

## Q7: What are the main reasons Gavin Newsom might be seen as a viable or non-viable candidate for vice president (e.g., political strategy, geographical considerations, public perception)?
Answer:
Gavin Newsom's viability as a Democratic vice-presidential nominee in 2024, should Joe Biden not be the presidential nominee, can be assessed through several key factors:

- Newsom has been actively demonstrating his loyalty to Biden, hosting fundraisers and publicly supporting the President's policies, which could position him favorably within the Democratic Party \[[6](https://chriscillizza.substack.com/p/whats-gavin-newsom-playing-at#:~:text=He%20knows%20that%20the%20most%20likely%20outcome%20is%20that%20Biden%20is%20the%20nominee%20in%202024%20%E2%80%94%20and%20you%20can%20be%20sure%20that%20he%20will%20continue%20to%20go%20out%20of%20his%20way%20to%20make%20clear%20that%20he%E2%80%99s%201000%25%20behind%20Joe)\]. However, his actions have also led to speculation that he might be running a "shadow campaign" for 2024, which could be perceived as undermining Biden and create internal party friction \[[13](https://redstate.com/bonchie/2023/08/27/joe-bidens-handlers-are-getting-nervous-about-gavin-newsom-debating-ron-desantis-n2163116#:~:text=Biden%27s%20advisors%20all%20but%20admit%20that%20concern%20in%20the%20article)\]\[[14](https://www.zerohedge.com/political/gavin-newsom-running-shadow-presidential-campaign#:~:text=That%E2%80%99s%20in%20keeping%20with%20what%20he%20has%20done%20before%2C%20according%20to%20an%20analysis%20by%20the%20California%20Senate%E2%80%99s%20Office%20of%20Research)\].
- Newsom's strong stance on progressive issues, such as climate policy and social justice, aligns well with the Democratic base but may alienate moderate voters in swing states. His criticism of states like Texas for their conservative policies could hinder his appeal in those regions, which are crucial for a general election victory \[[5](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2022/08/gavin-newsom-reelection-california-2024-presidential-run/671215/#:~:text=But%20recall%20that%20Joe%20Biden%20won%20Georgia%20in%202020)\].

2. **Geographical Considerations**:
- As the Governor of California, Newsom brings significant political clout from a state with a large number of electoral votes. However, California is already a solidly Democratic state, and his selection might not provide the geographical balance that a candidate from a swing state could offer. For instance, a candidate like Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer, who has demonstrated electoral success in a key battleground state, might be seen as a more strategic choice \[[3](https://www.joshbarro.com/p/biden-should-pick-a-new-running-mate#:~:text=In%202018%2C%20Gretchen%20Whitmer%20was%20elected%20governor%20of%20Michigan%20by%20a%20margin%20of%209)\]\[[10](https://www.joshbarro.com/p/biden-should-pick-a-new-running-mate#:~:text=Which%20brings%20me%20to%20Gretchen%20Whitmer)\].

In summary, while Newsom's loyalty to Biden and his progressive credentials make him a viable candidate, his potential to polarize voters and the lack of geographical balance could be significant drawbacks.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What percentage of incumbent vice presidents have been selected as the vice presidential nominee when a sitting president did not run for re-election?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Gavin Newsom)," the historical data on incumbent vice presidents being selected as the vice presidential nominee when a sitting president did not run for re-election is limited. However, we can infer some relevant statistics from the available data on vice presidents running for higher office.

From the sources, we know that twelve vice presidents have run for president while they were in office, and eleven have earned the primary nomination in their party \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Six%20have%20been%20elected%20to%20the%20presidency%2C%20or%20over%20a%20third%20of%20running%20vice-presidents%2C%20while%20seven%20have%20lost%20the%20presidential%20election)\]\[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Eleven%20have%20earned%20the%20primary%20nomination%20in%20their%20party%2C%20with%20most%20of%20them%20winning%20the%20presidency)\]. This suggests a relatively high likelihood of vice presidents being selected for higher office within their party. However, specific data on vice presidents being selected as vice presidential nominees when a sitting president did not run for re-election is not directly available in the provided sources.

Given the historical context, it is reasonable to infer that incumbent vice presidents have a strong chance of being selected for the vice presidential nomination, especially considering their visibility and established political presence. This inference is supported by the fact that vice presidents have a notable success rate in securing their party's nomination for higher office \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Six%20have%20been%20elected%20to%20the%20presidency%2C%20or%20over%20a%20third%20of%20running%20vice-presidents%2C%20while%20seven%20have%20lost%20the%20presidential%20election)\]\[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Eleven%20have%20earned%20the%20primary%20nomination%20in%20their%20party%2C%20with%20most%20of%20them%20winning%20the%20presidency)\].

For a more precise answer, additional specific historical data would be required, but the available information suggests a favorable outlook for incumbent vice presidents in such scenarios.
## Q1: In the last 50 years, how often has a sitting vice president been chosen as the presidential nominee of their party?
Answer:
In the last 50 years, the rate at which sitting vice presidents have been chosen as the presidential nominee of their party is relatively high. Specifically, starting with Richard Nixon in 1960, every elected vice president except Dan Quayle has led in a majority of the Gallup polls that measure the party rank and file's pre-convention preferences for president. Moreover, all eight of the postwar vice presidents who have sought their party's presidential nomination have won it, with the exception of Quayle \[[15](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Starting%20in%201948%2C%20the%20vice%20presidential%20candidate%20as%20often%20as%20not%20has%20been%20the%20more%20experienced%20member%20of%20the%20ticket%20in%20high%20government%20office%2C%20including%20recent%20nominees%20such%20as%20Walter%20F)\]. 

Additionally, of the 17 sitting vice presidents who were not blocked by an incumbent president seeking another term, eight were chosen as a national presidential candidate, and four were elected \[[3](https://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-vice-presidential-advantage/#:~:text=%28Yes%2C%20these%20numbers%20include%20George%20Clinton%20and%20John%20C)\]. This indicates a significant likelihood that a sitting vice president will be chosen as the presidential nominee of their party if they decide to run and are not impeded by an incumbent president.
## Q2: How often have vice presidential nominees been selected from the same geographical region as the presidential nominee in U.S. elections?
Answer:
In U.S. elections, it is relatively uncommon for vice-presidential nominees to be selected from the same geographical region as the presidential nominee. Historically, parties often choose running mates from different regions to balance the ticket and appeal to a broader electorate. For example, in the 1896 election, William Jennings Bryan, a populist from Nebraska, chose Arthur Sewall from Maine as his running mate to appeal to conservative and New England members of the party \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Sewall#:~:text=His%20selection%20is%20believed%20to%20have%20been%20an%20effort%20to%20win%20votes%20among%20conservative%20and%20New%20England%20members%20of%20the%20party%20who%20were%20disturbed%20by%20the%20populist%20aspects%20of%20William%20Jennings%20Bryan)\]. Similarly, in the 1876 election, New York Governor Samuel Tilden selected Thomas A. Hendricks from Indiana as his vice-presidential candidate to balance the ticket geographically \[[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_A._Hendricks#:~:text=%20Hendricks%2C%20a%20lifelong%20Democrat%2C%20was%20his%20party%27s%20candidate%20for%20U)\].

These examples illustrate the strategic considerations behind selecting vice-presidential candidates from different regions, aiming to maximize electoral appeal across diverse voter bases. This pattern suggests that it is less likely for a vice-presidential nominee to be from the same geographical region as the presidential nominee.
## Q3: What are historical instances of vice presidential candidates being replaced after being initially selected at the national convention?
Answer:
Historical instances of vice presidential candidates being replaced after being initially selected at the national convention are rare but notable. One significant example is the 1972 Democratic vice-presidential candidate Thomas Eagleton, who was replaced by Sargent Shriver. Eagleton was initially selected as George McGovern's running mate, but after revelations about his mental health treatments, he was replaced by Shriver \[[12](http://archive.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2007/03/05/thomas_eagleton_77_for_brief_tumultuous_time_he_was_running_mate/#:~:text=%20Sargent%20Shriver%2C%20the%20Peace%20Corps%20founder%20and%20Kennedy%20family%20intimate%2C%20became%20the%20new%20vice%20presidential%20nominee)\].

Another instance occurred in 1968 when President Lyndon B. Johnson announced he would not seek reelection. Hubert Humphrey, who was Johnson's Vice President, then launched his campaign for the presidency and chose Senator Edmund Muskie as his running mate \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey#:~:text=After%20Lyndon%20B)\]\[[4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey#:~:text=%20In%20March%201968%2C%20Johnson%20made%20his%20surprise%20announcement%20that%20he%20would%20not%20seek%20reelection%2C%20and%20Humphrey%20launched%20his%20campaign%20for%20the%20presidency)\]. This situation, while not a direct replacement post-convention, highlights the fluidity of vice-presidential selections in response to changing political landscapes.

These examples underscore the potential for vice-presidential candidates to be replaced or newly selected under extraordinary circumstances, which could be relevant for forecasting scenarios where the presidential nominee changes.
## Q4: How often have candidates publicly denied interest in a vice presidential position but were still selected for the role?
Answer:
Public denials of interest in the vice presidential position are not uncommon, yet they do not necessarily preclude a candidate from being selected for the role. Historical examples include Lyndon B. Johnson, who initially expressed reluctance but was ultimately chosen as John F. Kennedy's running mate in 1960. Similarly, Dick Cheney led the search for George W. Bush's vice presidential candidate in 2000 and repeatedly denied interest, only to be selected himself.

While specific statistics on the frequency of such denials are not readily available, these examples illustrate that public denials do not significantly diminish the likelihood of selection. The decision often hinges on strategic considerations rather than initial public statements.

For further context, the vice presidency has often been a stepping stone to the presidency, with several vice presidents ascending to the highest office either through election or succession \[[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Six%20unsuccessfully%20sought%20the%20presidential%20nomination%20of%20their%20party)\]\[[6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Eleven%20have%20earned%20the%20primary%20nomination%20in%20their%20party%2C%20with%20most%20of%20them%20winning%20the%20presidency)\]\[[8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Six%20have%20been%20elected%20to%20the%20presidency%2C%20or%20over%20a%20third%20of%20running%20vice-presidents%2C%20while%20seven%20have%20lost%20the%20presidential%20election)\]. This historical trend underscores the strategic importance of the vice presidential pick, which can override initial public denials of interest.
## Q5: What percentage of vice presidential candidates have had approval ratings below 40% at the time of their selection?
Answer:
Based on the available information, it appears that vice presidential candidates generally have favorable approval ratings at the time of their selection. For instance, historical data shows that candidates like Sarah Palin, Paul Ryan, John Edwards, Joe Lieberman, Dick Cheney, Jack Kemp, and Al Gore were all viewed much more favorably than unfavorably at the time they were tapped to be their party's vice presidential nominee, often by a 3-to-1 margin or better \[[13](https://news.gallup.com/poll/156545/Reaction-Ryan-Pick-Among-Least-Positive-Historically.aspx#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20Palin%27s%20favorable%20rating%20among%20registered%20voters%20was%20three%20times%20greater%20than%20her%20unfavorable%20rating%20at%20the%20time%20she%20made%20her%20debut%20as%20John%20McCain%27s%20running%20mate%20at%20the%202008%20Republican%20National%20Convention%2C%2022%25%20vs)\]. Reaction to Joe Biden in 2008 was about 2-to-1 positive \[[13](https://news.gallup.com/poll/156545/Reaction-Ryan-Pick-Among-Least-Positive-Historically.aspx#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20Palin%27s%20favorable%20rating%20among%20registered%20voters%20was%20three%20times%20greater%20than%20her%20unfavorable%20rating%20at%20the%20time%20she%20made%20her%20debut%20as%20John%20McCain%27s%20running%20mate%20at%20the%202008%20Republican%20National%20Convention%2C%2022%25%20vs)\].

There is no specific data point in the provided sources that directly states the percentage of vice presidential candidates with approval ratings below 40% at the time of their selection. However, the general trend suggests that it is uncommon for vice presidential candidates to have such low approval ratings when they are chosen. This implies that the percentage of vice presidential candidates with approval ratings below 40% at the time of their selection is likely very low.
## Q6: How frequently have vice presidential candidates been chosen from outside the pool of primary contenders in recent U.S. elections?
Answer:
In recent U.S. elections, vice presidential candidates have often been chosen from outside the pool of primary contenders. According to Pew Research, since 1868, most vice presidential candidates have had significant political experience, but they were not necessarily primary contenders for the presidential nomination \[[2](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/10/what-kind-of-person-runs-for-vice-president/#:~:text=Presidential%20candidates%20get%20a%20lot%20of%20public%20scrutiny%20during%20the%20United%20States%E2%80%99%20extended%20nominating%20process%2C%20but%20like%20dandelions%20or%20mushrooms%20after%20a%20spring%20shower%2C%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20seem%20to%20pop%20up%20suddenly%20in%20the%20political%20chatter%20once%20a%20party%20settles%20on%20a%20presidential%20nominee)\]\[[7](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/10/what-kind-of-person-runs-for-vice-president/#:~:text=We%20wondered%20what%20sort%20of%20people%20have%20gotten%20picked%20for%20the%20second%20spot%20on%20national%20tickets)\]. Specifically, a third of the 72 vice presidential nominees since 1868 were U.S. senators at the time of their nomination, indicating that the selection process often looks beyond the immediate pool of presidential primary contenders \[[7](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/10/what-kind-of-person-runs-for-vice-president/#:~:text=We%20wondered%20what%20sort%20of%20people%20have%20gotten%20picked%20for%20the%20second%20spot%20on%20national%20tickets)\].

Additionally, historical data shows that until the mid-20th century, presidential candidates had little input into the choice of their running mates, with party leaders typically making the selection to balance the ticket geographically or ideologically \[[10](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/10/what-kind-of-person-runs-for-vice-president/#:~:text=Until%20the%20mid-20th%20century%2C%20most%20presidential%20candidates%20had%20little%20or%20no%20input%20into%20the%20choice%20of%20their%20running%20mate)\]\[[14](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/10/what-kind-of-person-runs-for-vice-president/#:~:text=Two%20were%20ex-military%20leaders%2C%20Air%20Force%20Gen)\]. This historical context suggests that the practice of selecting vice presidential candidates from outside the pool of primary contenders has been a long-standing tradition in U.S. politics.
## Q7: What percentage of vice presidential nominees were selected from key swing states in the last 10 election cycles?
Answer:
In the last 10 election cycles, the selection of vice presidential nominees from key swing states has not been a predominant trend. The data suggests that the home-state effect of vice presidential candidates is often overrated. For instance, since 1920, major-party nominees for president have carried their running mate’s home state 65% of the time, and this percentage is slightly higher at 72% in elections since World War II \[[3](https://archive.nytimes.com/fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/the-overrated-vice-presidential-home-state-effect/#:~:text=than%2C%20say%2C%20Susana%20Martinez%2C%20the%20governor%20of%20New%20Mexico)\]. However, this statistic does not specifically address the selection from swing states but rather the general influence of a VP candidate's home state.

Additionally, the historical analysis of vice presidential selections does not show a significant correlation between a VP candidate’s home state and the vote share from that state \[[7](http://battleground270.blogspot.com/2012/08/veepstates.html#:~:text=are%20the%20statistics%20for%20each%20Presidential%20year%20beginning%20in%201960)\]. This implies that the strategic selection of VP candidates from swing states has not been a decisive factor in recent elections.

Therefore, while the home-state effect might have some influence, it is not a strong or consistent enough factor to suggest that a significant percentage of vice presidential nominees were selected from key swing states in the last 10 election cycles.
