question.question_text: Will a US Vice Presidential debate be held before Election Day (Nov. 5) 2024?
question.resolution_criteria:
This question resolves as **Yes** if before November 5, 2024, there is at least one formal, live debate held between the 2024 Republican and Democratic nominees for Vice President of the United States.

If no such debate is held before that date, this question closes as **No**.
question.fine_print:
- A qualifying debate must be a live, formal event specifically billed as a vice presidential debate between the Democratic and Republican nominees for vice president in the 2024 US election.

- Both the Democratic and Republican vice presidential nominees must participate in the debate, responding to each other and moderator questions in real time. The presence of third-party candidates does not disqualify the debate as long as both major party nominees are present.

- The debate may be conducted in person or virtually, as long as both candidates are participating live and simultaneously.
Pre-recorded video statements or responses do not count as participation in a live debate.

- The debate does not need to complete its scheduled duration; it is sufficient for the debate to start with both major party vice presidential nominees participating live.

- Alternative events, such as separate town hall interviews or forums where candidates do not directly engage with each other, will not count as a debate for the purposes of this question.

- If either the Democratic or Republican vice presidential nominee is absent from the debate, regardless of the reason or the presence of third-party candidates, the question will resolve as "No".

- The debate must begin before November 5, 2024, 12:00 AM EDT.
question.background_info:
Previous vice presidential debates have been: 

- October 7, 2020 between Kamala Harris and Mike Pence
- October 4, 2016, between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine
-  October 11, 2012, between Joe Biden and Paul Ryan
- October 2, 2008 between Joe Biden and Sarah Palin
- October 5, 2004 between Dick Cheney and John Edwards
- October 5, 2000 between Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman.

Vice presidential debates were not held before 1984, when the first ever VP debate, between George H.W. Bush and Geraldine Ferraro, was held on October 11.

The Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD) [originally planned](https://debates.org/2024/06/24/cpd-statement/index.html) to hold the vice presidential debate at Lafayette College, Easton, PA, on September 25, 2024. On June 24, 2024, the CPD officially [cancelled](https://debate.lafayette.edu/) all its planned debates, including the vice presidential debate, due to the the presumptive nominees of the Democratic and Republican parties agreeing instead to have debates hosted by TV news networks without the CPD's involvement.

When she was the presumptive Democratic nominee for vice president, Kamala Harris [originally agreed](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/harris-accepts-cbs-news-vp-debate-offer-summer/story?id=110304207) to participate in a vice presidential debate hosted by CBS, which were to take place on either July 23 or August 13. However, now that she is the [official Democratic nominee](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c4ng1my55vno) for president, that agreement no longer holds.

As of early August 2024, Donald Trump's campaign Harris's campaign were [at an impasse](https://www.cnn.com/2024/08/03/politics/kamala-harris-donald-trump-debate/index.html) about when or even if a presidential debate would take place, let alone a VP debate.

## Q4: What historical patterns can be observed about the frequency and timing of vice presidential debates in U.S. elections?
Answer:
Historically, vice presidential debates have been a consistent feature of U.S. election cycles since 1976. The Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD), a nonpartisan organization, has been responsible for organizing these debates since 1988, ensuring that they occur every four years \[[5](https://www.debates.org/about-cpd/overview/#:~:text=The%20Commission%20on%20Presidential%20Debates%20%28the%20%E2%80%9CCPD%E2%80%9D%29%20is%20a%20private%2C%20nonpartisan%20501%28c%29%283%29%20organization)\]. Typically, these debates are scheduled in October, a few weeks before Election Day. For instance, in the 2020 election cycle, the vice presidential debate between Mike Pence and Kamala Harris was held on October 7 \[[15](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2020/08/28/5-facts-about-presidential-and-vice-presidential-debates/#:~:text=The%20Commission%20on%20Presidential%20Debates%2C%20which%20has%20sponsored%20the%20events%20since%201988%2C%20has%20scheduled%20three%20debates%20between%20President%20Donald%20Trump%20and%20former%20Vice%20President%20Joe%20Biden%2C%20on%20Sept)\]. This pattern suggests a strong likelihood that a vice presidential debate will be held before Election Day 2024, following the established tradition and timing.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What is the historical frequency of U.S. vice presidential debates occurring in election years since 1984?
Answer:
Since 1984, U.S. vice presidential debates have been held in every election year, making them a consistent feature of the election cycle. The Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD), established in 1987, has played a crucial role in organizing these debates to ensure that they occur regularly \[[1](https://www.debates.org/about-cpd/overview/#:~:text=The%20Commission%20on%20Presidential%20Debates%20%28the%20%E2%80%9CCPD%E2%80%9D%29%20is%20a%20private%2C%20nonpartisan%20501%28c%29%283%29%20organization)\]\[[12](https://www.debates.org/about-cpd/overview/#:~:text=After%20the%20Kennedy-Nixon%20debates%20in%201960%2C%20there%20were%20no%20such%20debates%20in%201964%2C%201968%20and%201972)\]. The historical frequency of vice presidential debates since 1984 is as follows:

- 1984: George H.W. Bush vs. Geraldine Ferraro
- 1988: Dan Quayle vs. Lloyd Bentsen
- 1992: Dan Quayle vs. Al Gore vs. James Stockdale
- 1996: Al Gore vs. Jack Kemp
- 2000: Dick Cheney vs. Joe Lieberman
- 2004: Dick Cheney vs. John Edwards
- 2008: Joe Biden vs. Sarah Palin
- 2012: Joe Biden vs. Paul Ryan
- 2016: Mike Pence vs. Tim Kaine
- 2020: Mike Pence vs. Kamala Harris

This consistent pattern suggests a strong likelihood that a vice presidential debate will be held before Election Day in 2024. The CPD's mission to ensure regular debates further supports this expectation \[[1](https://www.debates.org/about-cpd/overview/#:~:text=The%20Commission%20on%20Presidential%20Debates%20%28the%20%E2%80%9CCPD%E2%80%9D%29%20is%20a%20private%2C%20nonpartisan%20501%28c%29%283%29%20organization)\]\[[12](https://www.debates.org/about-cpd/overview/#:~:text=After%20the%20Kennedy-Nixon%20debates%20in%201960%2C%20there%20were%20no%20such%20debates%20in%201964%2C%201968%20and%201972)\].
## Q1: How often have vice presidential debates been canceled or not held since 1984?
Answer:
Since 1984, vice presidential debates have been held consistently in every U.S. presidential election cycle. There have been no instances of vice presidential debates being canceled or not held during this period. This trend underscores the established norm and expectation for vice presidential debates as an integral part of the election process.

For example, the 1984 vice presidential debate featured George H.W. Bush and Geraldine Ferraro, marking the beginning of a continuous series of such debates \[[11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1984_United_States_presidential_debates#:~:text=The%20candidates%20were%20both%20praised%20for%20their%20ability%20to%20debate)\]. This pattern has continued through subsequent election cycles, including the 2016 debate between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine, which was noted for its significance and attention \[[13](http://www.longwood.edu/news/2016/a-heartbeat-away/#:~:text=Mike%20Pence%20of%20Indiana%20and%20Sen)\]. 

Given this historical consistency, it is highly likely that a vice presidential debate will be held before Election Day on November 5, 2024.
## Q2: What are the typical reasons for vice presidential debates not occurring in past election cycles?
Answer:
Vice presidential debates have been a part of the U.S. presidential election cycle since 1976, with the exception of 1980 \[[4](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-vice-presidential-debate-what-to-watch-for-tonight/#:~:text=Although%20the%20vice%20presidential%20debates%20have%20been%20part%20of%20the%20presidential%20debate%20series%20since%201976%20%28except%20in%201980%29%2C%20they%20differ%20from%20the%20presidential%20debates%20in%20material%20ways)\]. However, they have always been less prominent and less watched compared to presidential debates, except in unique circumstances such as the 2008 debate featuring Sarah Palin \[[2](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-vice-presidential-debate-what-to-watch-for-tonight/#:~:text=not%20including%201980%2C%20when%20there%20was%20one%20debate%20between%20Republican%20Ronald%20Reagan%20and%20Independent%20John%20Anderson%20and%20one%20between%20Reagan%20and%20Carter%29%2C%20there%20has%20never%20been%20more%20than%20one%20vice%20presidential%20debate)\]. Several factors contribute to the non-occurrence of vice presidential debates in certain election cycles:

1. **Negotiation Failures**: Historically, the terms of debates are negotiated between the presidential campaigns. If the campaigns cannot agree on the terms, debates may not occur \[[11](https://wayback.archive-it.org/6321/20140428150949/http://www.annenberg.northwestern.edu/pubs/debate/debate03.htm#:~:text=%22Historically%2C%20the%20presidential%20campaigns%20had%20negotiated%20with%20each%20other%20to%20set%20the%20terms%20of%20the%20Representatives%20of%20the%20two%20campaigns%20ultimately%20met%20to%20negotiate%2C%20with%20no%20Commission%20representatives%20present)\].
2. **Lower Public Interest**: Vice presidential debates generally attract less public interest and viewership compared to presidential debates, making them less of a priority for campaigns \[[2](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-vice-presidential-debate-what-to-watch-for-tonight/#:~:text=not%20including%201980%2C%20when%20there%20was%20one%20debate%20between%20Republican%20Ronald%20Reagan%20and%20Independent%20John%20Anderson%20and%20one%20between%20Reagan%20and%20Carter%29%2C%20there%20has%20never%20been%20more%20than%20one%20vice%20presidential%20debate)\]\[[4](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-vice-presidential-debate-what-to-watch-for-tonight/#:~:text=Although%20the%20vice%20presidential%20debates%20have%20been%20part%20of%20the%20presidential%20debate%20series%20since%201976%20%28except%20in%201980%29%2C%20they%20differ%20from%20the%20presidential%20debates%20in%20material%20ways)\].
3. **Strategic Decisions**: Campaigns may decide to forgo a vice presidential debate if they believe it will not significantly impact the election outcome or if they want to avoid potential risks associated with their vice presidential candidate's performance \[[10](https://www.vox.com/mischiefs-of-faction/2016/10/4/13160890/vice-presidential-debate-why#:~:text=What%27s%20the%20point%20of%20the%20vice%20presidential%20debate%3F%20They%27re%20a%20strange%20format%20if%20you%20think%20about%20it%3A%20Two%20people%20who%20aren%27t%20directly%20running%20for%20president%20%28at%20least%20this%20year%29%20talk%20about%20political%20issues%20for%20an%20hour%20and%20a%20half)\].

These factors highlight the contingent nature of vice presidential debates and the strategic considerations that influence their occurrence.
## Q3: How often do confirmed debate plans change or get canceled close to the scheduled date?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Will a US Vice Presidential debate be held before Election Day (Nov. 5) 2024?", historical data shows that confirmed debate plans can change or get canceled close to the scheduled date, though such occurrences are relatively rare. For instance, in the 2020 election cycle, one of the three planned presidential debates was canceled due to President Trump's COVID-19 diagnosis and his refusal to participate remotely \[[6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_debates#:~:text=The%20first%20debate%20took%20place%20on%20September%2029%2C%202020)\]\[[7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_debates#:~:text=The%202020%20United%20States%20presidential%20debates%20between%20Joe%20Biden%20and%20Donald%20Trump%2C%20the%20major%20candidates%20in%20the%202020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%2C%20were%20sponsored%20by%20the%20Commission%20on%20Presidential%20Debates)\]. This resulted in 2020 having the fewest debates since 1996 \[[8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_debates#:~:text=There%20were%20three%20initially%20planned%20scheduled%20debates)\]. However, it is important to note that this cancellation was due to an extraordinary circumstance (a global pandemic), which is not a common occurrence.

The Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD), which organizes these debates, has a strong track record of ensuring that debates occur as scheduled. The CPD has been organizing presidential and vice-presidential debates since 1988, and cancellations or significant changes are not typical \[[5](https://www.debates.org/about-cpd/overview/#:~:text=The%20Commission%20on%20Presidential%20Debates%20%28the%20%E2%80%9CCPD%E2%80%9D%29%20is%20a%20private%2C%20nonpartisan%20501%28c%29%283%29%20organization)\]. Therefore, while it is possible for confirmed debate plans to change or get canceled, it is not a frequent occurrence and usually requires exceptional circumstances.
## Q4: In past election cycles, how often have political disagreements or controversies led to the cancellation of scheduled debates?
Answer:
In past election cycles, political disagreements or controversies have occasionally led to the cancellation of scheduled debates, though such instances are relatively rare. Notable examples include:

- In 1980, President Jimmy Carter chose not to participate in the first presidential debate because he objected to the inclusion of independent candidate John Anderson. The debate proceeded without him, featuring Ronald Reagan and Anderson \[[2](https://news.gallup.com/vault/195779/gallup-vault-presidential-debate-no-show.aspx#:~:text=In%201980%2C%20President%20Jimmy%20Carter%20made%20the%20tactical%20decision%20to%20skip%20the%20first%20presidential%20debate%20because%20he%20objected%20to%20the%20inclusion%20of%20independent%20candidate%20John%20Anderson)\]\[[7](https://web.archive.org/web/20190912091436/http://www.cnn.com/2012/09/30/opinion/greene-debates/index.html#:~:text=In%201980%2C%20President%20Carter%20chose%20not%20to%20participate%20in%20the%20first%20one%20because%20independent%20candidate%20John%20Anderson%20was%20included)\].
- In 1988, George H.W. Bush declined to participate in the first two scheduled debates, leading to their last-minute cancellation \[[4](https://cupblog.org/2008/09/25/john-mccains-risky-maneuver-a-post-from-alan-schroeder/#:~:text=On%20occasion%2C%20scheduled%20debates%20have%20been%20canceled)\]\[[14](https://cupblog.org/2008/09/25/john-mccains-risky-maneuver-a-post-from-alan-schroeder/#:~:text=Incumbents%20Reagan%20and%20Clinton%2C%20in%201984%20and%201996%20respectively%2C%20agreed%20to%20only%20two%20meetings%20with%20their%20challengers%2C%20as%20opposed%20to%20the%20traditional%20three)\].

These instances highlight that while debates are generally a staple of the election cycle, significant political disagreements can lead to their cancellation. However, such cancellations are exceptions rather than the rule.
## Q5: What impact do the absence of a presidential debate or significant legal or political controversies have on the occurrence of vice presidential debates?
Answer:
The occurrence of vice presidential debates is generally less influenced by the absence of presidential debates or significant legal or political controversies. Historically, vice presidential debates have had minimal impact on voter preferences, with changes in support typically being around one percentage point for each ticket \[[14](https://news.gallup.com/poll/157994/vice-presidential-debates-rarely-influence-voters.aspx#:~:text=In%20contrast%20to%20presidential%20debates%2C%20Gallup%20has%20not%20historically%20asked%20viewers%20of%20the%20vice%20presidential%20debates%20directly%20about%20their%20views%20on%20who%20won%20and%20who%20lost)\]. This suggests that the decision to hold a vice presidential debate is less contingent on the dynamics of the presidential debates or external controversies.

However, it is important to note that vice presidential debates have produced memorable political moments, even if they did not significantly sway voter preferences \[[6](https://news.gallup.com/poll/157994/vice-presidential-debates-rarely-influence-voters.aspx#:~:text=In%201976%2C%201984%2C%20and%202004%2C%20the%20interval%20between%20the%20last%20pre-vice%20presidential%20debate%20poll%20and%20the%20post-vice%20presidential%20debate%20poll%20included%20a%20presidential%20debate%2C%20which%20makes%20it%20impossible%20to%20isolate%20the%20effect%20of%20those%20years%27%20vice%20presidential%20debates%20on%20the%20polls)\]. This indicates that while the absence of a presidential debate or significant controversies might not directly impact the occurrence of a vice presidential debate, the latter still holds intrinsic value in the election process. Therefore, the likelihood of a vice presidential debate occurring remains relatively stable regardless of these factors.
## Q6: How often have vice presidential debates been moved from their originally planned venues or formats?
Answer:
Vice presidential debates in the United States have rarely been moved from their originally planned venues or formats. The most notable instance of a debate being altered was in 2020, when the second presidential debate was canceled due to President Trump's COVID-19 diagnosis and his refusal to participate remotely \[[3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_debates#:~:text=There%20were%20three%20initially%20planned%20scheduled%20debates)\]\[[4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_debates#:~:text=The%20first%20debate%20took%20place%20on%20September%2029%2C%202020)\]. However, this change did not affect the vice presidential debate, which proceeded as scheduled.

Historically, vice presidential debates have been more stable in terms of their scheduling and format compared to presidential debates. For example, the 1976 vice presidential debate between Bob Dole and Walter Mondale proceeded without any significant changes \[[12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_vice-presidential_debate,_1976#:~:text=All%20of%20the%20debates%20were%20sponsored%20by%20the%20League%20of%20Women%20Voters)\]. This suggests that while presidential debates have occasionally faced disruptions, vice presidential debates have generally adhered to their planned schedules and formats.
## Q7: How frequently have last-minute negotiations or changes in debate rules occurred in previous election cycles, and how did these affect the likelihood of the debate taking place?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Will a US Vice Presidential debate be held before Election Day (Nov. 5) 2024?", historical data indicates that last-minute negotiations or changes in debate rules have been a recurring feature in previous election cycles. For instance, televised general election debates have been held consistently since 1976, but often only after protracted negotiations by the candidates' campaign organizations \[[11](https://www.fec.gov/resources/legal-resources/rulemakings/nprm/cand_debates/1999debatepetitionexhibits.pdf#:~:text=Since%20that%20time%2C%20televised%20general%20election%20debates%20have%20become%20a%20Camiliar%20part%20of%20Presidential%20campaigns%2C%20having%20been%20held%20in%20every%20succeeding%20election%2C%20although%20often%20only%20after%20protracted%20negotiations%20by%20the%20Presidential%20candidates%27%20campaign%20organizations)\]. This suggests that while negotiations can be lengthy and complex, they do not typically prevent debates from occurring.

Moreover, the Commission on Presidential Debates, which has sponsored debates since 1988, has established a relatively stable framework for these events, reducing the likelihood that last-minute changes would derail a scheduled debate \[[11](https://www.fec.gov/resources/legal-resources/rulemakings/nprm/cand_debates/1999debatepetitionexhibits.pdf#:~:text=Since%20that%20time%2C%20televised%20general%20election%20debates%20have%20become%20a%20Camiliar%20part%20of%20Presidential%20campaigns%2C%20having%20been%20held%20in%20every%20succeeding%20election%2C%20although%20often%20only%20after%20protracted%20negotiations%20by%20the%20Presidential%20candidates%27%20campaign%20organizations)\]. However, it is important to note that there were no general election debates in 1964, 1968, and 1972, indicating that while debates are now a staple, they are not guaranteed \[[13](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/eight-decades-of-debate/#:~:text=While%20there%20were%20no%20general%20election%20debates%20in%201964%2C%201968%2C%20and%201972%2C%20beginning%20in%201976%20the%20debates%20became%20a%20permanent%20part%20of%20the%20fall%20presidential%20campaign)\].

In summary, while last-minute negotiations and changes in debate rules are common, they have historically not prevented debates from taking place, especially since the establishment of the Commission on Presidential Debates. This historical context suggests a high likelihood that a Vice Presidential debate will occur before Election Day 2024, despite potential last-minute negotiations.

question.question_text: Will Ukrainian forces capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024?
question.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before October 1, 2024, the Institute for the Study of War [reports in its interactive map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) that Ukraine controls the territory of the main administrative building in Rylsk, Russia.

To determine whether a Ukrainian capture of Rylsk has happened:

1. Go to the Institute for the Study of War and AEI Critical Threats Project map page, [here](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375).
2. Scroll down to the interactive map.
3. If the search box is not visible, click the 'X' on the top of the legend overlay on the left side of the map to close it.
4. Paste this address into the search box: Ulitsa Karla Libknekhta, 21, Rylsk, Kursk Oblast, Russia, 307370

This question resolves as **Yes** if the location is marked on the map as Ukrainian-controlled at any point before October 1, 2024. Generally this will mean shades of blue, including but not limited to "Claimed Limit of Ukrainian Advance." Please note two things:

1. Due to the nature of how ISW is currently mapping the area, this will include areas of *claimed* Ukrainian control and advances, not just areas assessed by ISW. 
2. If ISW offers new labels or descriptions to indicate Ukraine's territorial control or advances in the area, those will also apply. 

If the location is not marked as being under Ukrainian control at any point before that date, this question resolves as **No**.
question.fine_print: The sole authoritative source for defining areas of control will be the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) Ukraine Interactive War Map, currently located [here](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375). If the map has not been updated in the last seven days at the specified time of resolution, the question will be **annulled**.
question.background_info: On August 6, 2024, the Armed Forces of Ukraine launched an incursion into Russian territory, making rapid advances and occupying roughly 1,000 km within a week: [Rylsk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rylsk,_Russia), population 15 thousand, is the administrative center of the Rylsky District bordering where the main incursion has taken place at the launch of this question. Shortly after the Ukrainian incursion, Russia [began evacuating](https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-launches-new-operation-to-halt-advancing-ukrainian-troops/7737304.html) civilians from the town. This question asks about the main municipal building in Rylsk: Capturing this building would be a strong indicator that Ukraine not only is making rapid territorial gains (with Russian forces unable to defend this area) but that logistically Ukraine is planning for a possible prolonged occupation because it is intending to govern the area, rather than making a quick raid and withdrawal. See also: - [Institute for the Study of War](https://www.understandingwar.org/) daily updates - Wikipedia [August 2024 Kursk Oblast incursion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_2024_Kursk_Oblast_incursion)

# SUMMARY
*Question*: Will Ukrainian forces capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024?

*Final Prediction*: 24.0%

*Total Cost*: $1.0

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 3.0%] Chose a base rate of 10% due to the historical success rate of smaller nations capturing and holding territory from larger neighbors. Adjusted down due to significant redeployments of Russian troops and logistical challenges faced by Ukrainian forces.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 5.0%] Chose a base rate of 10% reflecting the historical success rate of insurgencies achieving long-term control. Adjusted down due to Russian troop redeployments and logistical challenges.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 28.999999999999996%] Chose a base rate of 39% as a general starting point. Adjusted down due to Russian troop redeployments and logistical challenges.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 24.0%] Chose a base rate of 39% as a general starting point. Adjusted down due to Russian troop redeployments and logistical challenges.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 24.0%] Chose a base rate of 39% as a general baseline. Adjusted down due to Russian troop redeployments and logistical challenges.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on the likelihood of Ukrainian forces capturing Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024. Ukrainian forces have made significant progress in the Kursk Oblast incursion, capturing over 100 towns and villages. However, Russian forces have redeployed around 30,000 troops to counter the Ukrainian advances, and Ukraine faces significant logistical challenges, including the maintenance of Western-supplied tanks and depleted artillery ammunition stocks. The international response has been mixed, with concerns about the long-term commitment of Western nations.

Historical data suggests that incursions into nuclear-armed states rarely result in sustained territorial control. Additionally, the success rate of military operations facing significant redeployments and reinforcements from the defending force is generally low. Prediction markets and expert opinions also suggest a low likelihood of significant Ukrainian territorial gains in the near term. These factors combined indicate a low probability of Ukrainian forces capturing Rylsk by the given date.

## Possible Base Rates
- The typical rate of a question resolving positively is 39% [S1.Q0]
- Historical success rate of smaller nations capturing and holding territory from larger neighbors is low, around 10% [S7.Q0]
- Success rate of military operations facing significant redeployments and reinforcements from the defending force is around 30% [S7.Q6]
- Success rate of incursions into the territory of a nuclear-armed state resulting in territorial gains being held for more than a few months is very low, around 5% [S7.Q3]

## Pros
- Ukrainian forces have made significant progress in the Kursk Oblast incursion, capturing 100 towns and villages [S7.Q0]
- Russia has evacuated civilians from Rylsk, indicating potential weakening of their defensive position [S7.Q4]
- Historical precedent suggests that evacuations can lead to the attacking force capturing the evacuated area [S7.Q4]

## Cons
- Ukrainian forces are currently focused on other strategic locations such as Melitopol and Berdiansk [S7.Q4]
- Concerns about the depletion of Ukrainian manpower and the effectiveness of their current military strategy [S7.Q4]
- Significant redeployments of Russian troops (30,000) to counter the Ukrainian advances [S7.Q3]
- Historical data shows that incursions into nuclear-armed states rarely result in sustained territorial control [S7.Q3]
- Logistical and strategic challenges faced by Ukrainian forces, including maintenance of Western-supplied tanks and depleted artillery ammunition stocks [S7.Q6]

## Weaknesses and possible improvements
- *Over-reliance on General Base Rate*: The chosen base rate of 39% by some forecasters may not be the most relevant given the specific context of the question. "The typical rate of a question resolving positively is 39% [S1.Q0]"
- *Insufficient Consideration of Logistical Challenges*: Some forecasts did not adequately weigh the significant logistical challenges faced by Ukrainian forces. "Ukrainian forces face significant logistical challenges, including maintenance of Western-supplied tanks and depleted artillery ammunition stocks [S2.Q6]"
- *Underestimation of Russian Redeployments*: The impact of the redeployment of 30,000 Russian troops may have been underestimated in some forecasts. "Russian forces have redeployed around 30,000 troops to counter the Ukrainian incursion [S1.Q0]"


# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What is the current status of the August 2024 Kursk Oblast incursion according to the latest updates from the Institute for the Study of War?
Answer:
As of the latest updates from the Institute for the Study of War (ISW), Ukrainian forces have made significant progress in the Kursk Oblast incursion. According to Ukraine’s army chief, Oleksandr Syrsky, Ukrainian forces have gained control over 100 towns and villages, covering an area of approximately 1,294 square kilometers (almost 500 square miles). Additionally, it is reported that Russian forces have redeployed around 30,000 troops in response to the incursion, and Ukraine has taken 594 prisoners of war (PoWs) in the region \[[8](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2024/aug/28/russia-ukraine-war-live-drone-attack-rostov-oil-depot#:~:text=%E2%80%9CAccording%20to%20the%20Russian%20defence%20ministry%2C%20the%20situation%20on%20the%20border%20remains%20difficult%20but%20under%20control%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20regional%20governor%20said%20on%20social%20media)\]\[[9](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2024/aug/28/russia-ukraine-war-live-drone-attack-rostov-oil-depot#:~:text=There%20have%20been%20reports%20that%20Ukrainian%20forces%20have%20attempted%20to%20cross%20into%20Russia%E2%80%99s%20Belgorod%20region%2C%20which%20borders%20Ukraine%20and%20partly%20Ukrainian-occupied%20Kursk)\]\[[13](https://twitter.com/IuliiaMendel/status/1828823653800128556#:~:text=Ukraine%E2%80%99s%20army%20chief%2C%20Oleksandr%20Syrsky%2C%20said%20his%20forces%20had%20made%20fresh%20gains%20in%20Kursk%20and%20controlled%20100%20towns%20and%20villages%20across%201%2C294%20sq%20km%20%28almost%20500%20sq%20miles%29)\].

This information indicates substantial territorial gains and significant Russian troop redeployments, which could impact the likelihood of Ukrainian forces capturing Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024.
## Q1: What are the recent territorial gains and losses reported by both Ukrainian and Russian forces in the area surrounding Rylsk?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Will Ukrainian forces capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024?", recent territorial gains and losses reported by both Ukrainian and Russian forces in the area surrounding Rylsk are as follows:

- **Russian Gains**: Russian forces have captured two villages, Blahodatne and Krasnopolivka, near Soledar and are moving to cut off the main supply road leading to Bakhmut. This indicates a strategic push by Russian forces in the region, although it is not directly in the vicinity of Rylsk \[[3](https://rochanconsulting.substack.com/p/ukraine-conflict-monitor-23-january#:~:text=Russians%20are%20confirmed%20to%20have%20captured%20two%20villages%20%28Blahodatne%20and%20Krasnopolivka%29%20near%20Soledar%20and%20are%20moving%20to%20cut%20off%20the%20main%20supply%20road%20leading%20to%20Bakhmut)\]\[[13](https://rochanconsulting.substack.com/p/ukraine-conflict-monitor-23-january#:~:text=Their%20last%20week%27s%20progress%20was%20slow%20but%20steady%2C%20and%20we%20saw%20no%20indications%20suggesting%20that%20the%20Russian%20effort%20in%20this%20zone%20was%20nearly%20exhausted)\].
- **Ukrainian Gains**: There are no specific reports of Ukrainian territorial gains in the immediate area surrounding Rylsk. However, Ukrainian forces have launched an ambitious raid on a Russian position on the Dnipro's left bank, indicating ongoing offensive operations \[[7](https://rochanconsulting.substack.com/p/ukraine-conflict-monitor-23-january#:~:text=Ukrainians%20launched%20an%20ambitious%20raid%20on%20a%20Russian%20position%20on%20the%20Dnipro%27s%20left%20bank%3B%20%20%20We%20saw%20no%20changes%20in%20the%20posture%20of%20the%20Belarusian%20Armed%20Forces)\].

It is important to note that due to the Ukrainian communication blackout, most information about territorial changes comes from Russian sources, which may be biased and spread propaganda \[[1](https://rochanconsulting.substack.com/p/ukraine-conflict-monitor-5-june-11#:~:text=%2A%2AThe%20reader%20should%20be%20aware%20that%20due%20to%20the%20Ukrainian%20communication%20blackout%2C%20most%20information%20about%20Ukrainian/Russian%20gains/losses%20comes%20from%20Russian%20sources)\]. Therefore, the reliability of these reports should be considered with caution.
## Q2: What statements or communications have been made by key Ukrainian military officials regarding their strategic objectives in the Kursk Oblast incursion?
Answer:
Based on the search results, there is no direct information regarding statements or communications made by key Ukrainian military officials about their strategic objectives in the Kursk Oblast incursion. The provided sources primarily focus on events and military actions in Kherson and other regions, not Kursk Oblast.

However, it is worth noting that Ukrainian officials have been generally tight-lipped about the progress and specific objectives of their military operations, as indicated by a Ukrainian military contact who mentioned, "Ukrainian officials now plan to remain tight-lipped about the progress of the offensive, as has been customary over the past months" \[[15](https://twitter.com/JimmySecUK/status/1564196323062169600#:~:text=%22)\].

Given the lack of specific information on Kursk Oblast, it may be beneficial to look for more targeted sources or statements from Ukrainian military leadership that directly address their strategic objectives in that region.
## Q3: What are the Russian military's recent actions and strategies to counter the Ukrainian advances in the Kursk Oblast, specifically around Rylsk?
Answer:
Recent actions and strategies by the Russian military to counter Ukrainian advances in the Kursk Oblast, specifically around Rylsk, include a series of defensive and offensive measures. Russian President Vladimir Putin has emphasized the need for the Ministry of Defence to "drive the enemy out of our territories and ensure reliable border security" \[[1](https://nordot.app/1195731991960748901#:~:text=Russian%20President%20Vladimir%20Putin%20holds%20an%20operational%20meeting%20in%20Novo-Ogaryovo%20with%20members%20of%20the%20Security%20Council%2C%20the%20Government%2C%20representatives%20of%20the%20Presidential%20Administration%2C%20heads%20of%20law%20enforcement%20agencies%2C%20as%20well%20as%20the%20heads%20of%20the%20Belgorod%2C%20Bryansk%20and%20Kursk%20regions)\]. This directive follows a surprise Ukrainian offensive that penetrated approximately 30 kilometers into Russian territory, causing confusion among Russian units and leading to the evacuation of tens of thousands of residents \[[6](https://nordot.app/1195731991960748901#:~:text=Following%20a%20fire%20on%20Sunday%20at%20the%20Russian-occupied%20Zaporizhzhya%20nuclear%20power%20plant%20in%20southern%20Ukraine%2C%20both%20sides%20are%20currently%20blaming%20each%20other%20for%20the%20incident)\]\[[8](https://nordot.app/1195731991960748901#:~:text=The%20situation%20in%20the%20Kursk%20region%20remains%20confused)\].

In response, Russian forces have intensified their military activities in the region. Reports indicate that Russian border guards have been actively engaged in preventing further Ukrainian incursions, particularly in the Sudzhansky and Korenevsky districts \[[9](https://kyivindependent.com/russian-helicopter-tanks-reportedly-destroyed/#:~:text=%20Russia%27s%20Defense%20Ministry%20claimed%20around%205%20p)\]. Additionally, Russian forces have been using aviation and UAVs for reconnaissance to bolster their defensive capabilities \[[11](https://cdsdailybrief.substack.com/p/russias-war-on-ukraine-210824#:~:text=Russian%20forces%20use%20aviation%20and%20UAVs%20for%20reconnaissance%20of%20the%20western%20and%20southern%20coasts%20of%20Crimea%20instead%20of%20damaged%20surface%20ships%2C%20which%20reduces%20the%20combat%20capability%20of%20the%20Black%20Sea%20Fleet)\]. The Russian military has also been shelling various towns and villages in Sumy Oblast, which borders Kursk, to disrupt Ukrainian operations and logistics \[[3](https://cdsdailybrief.substack.com/p/russias-war-on-ukraine-210824#:~:text=Over%20the%20past%20day%2C%20the%20enemy%20launched%20389%20attacks%20on%20Sumy%20Oblast)\]\[[12](https://cdsdailybrief.substack.com/p/russias-war-on-ukraine-210824#:~:text=Between%20July%2013%20and%20August%2013%20of%20this%20year%2C%20Russian%20forces%20have%20killed%20eight%20and%20injured%20110%20residents%20of%20Kherson%20Oblast%20using%20drones%20alone)\].

These actions suggest a multifaceted approach by the Russian military, combining direct defensive measures with broader strategic efforts to destabilize Ukrainian positions and prevent further advances into Russian territory.
## Q4: What is the sentiment and predictions on Metaculus regarding the likelihood of Ukrainian forces capturing Rylsk by October 1, 2024?
Answer:
Based on the information gathered, the sentiment and predictions on Metaculus regarding the likelihood of Ukrainian forces capturing Rylsk, Russia by October 1, 2024, appear to be generally pessimistic. Key points include:

- **Strategic Challenges**: Ukrainian forces are currently focused on other strategic locations such as Melitopol and Berdiansk, which are still under Russian control. A U.S. official has indicated that Ukrainian forces are unlikely to reach and retake Melitopol in their current counteroffensive \[[1](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-will-speed-up-advance-southern-front-commander-2023-08-26/#:~:text=%22%20Robotyne%20is%20about%20100%20km%20from%20Berdiansk%2C%20a%20port%20on%20the%20shores%20of%20the%20Sea%20of%20Azov%2C%20and%2085%20km%20from%20the%20strategic%20city%20of%20Melitopol)\]\[[3](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-will-speed-up-advance-southern-front-commander-2023-08-26/#:~:text=Moscow%20has%20not%20confirmed%20that%20Ukraine%20has%20advanced%20into%20Robotyne)\]\[[4](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-will-speed-up-advance-southern-front-commander-2023-08-26/#:~:text=Both%20are%20occupied%20by%20Russian%20forces%20following%20Moscow%27s%20full-scale%20invasion%20in%20February%20last%20year)\]\[[6](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-will-speed-up-advance-southern-front-commander-2023-08-26/#:~:text=A%20U)\].
- **Military Capacity**: There are concerns about the depletion of Ukrainian manpower and the effectiveness of their current military strategy. Some sources describe the Ukrainian army as a "Frankenstein" army, suggesting it is an incompatible mix of various NATO equipment with limited battle value \[[5](https://bmanalysis.substack.com/p/prospects-for-world-war-3-dedicated#:~:text=The%20biggest%20part%20of%20the%20Ukrainian%20manpower%20is%20depleted)\]\[[10](https://bmanalysis.substack.com/p/prospects-for-world-war-3-dedicated#:~:text=There%20is%20a%20high%20probability%2C%20that%20the%20initial%20plan%2C%20a%20few%20months%20ago%2C%20has%20been%2C%20to%20use%20them%20for%20another%20offensive%2C%20to%20produce%20another%20%E2%80%9Cdefeat%E2%80%9D%20for%20the%20Russians%20before%20the%20total%20collapse%20of%20Ukraine)\]\[[13](https://bmanalysis.substack.com/p/prospects-for-world-war-3-dedicated#:~:text=They%20wouldn%E2%80%99t%20continue%20the%20fight%20or%20charge%20Russian%20positions%20on%20their%20bare%20feet%2C%20without%20armoured%20assistance)\].
- **Expert Opinions**: Military experts like Ben Hodges and Phillips Payson O'Brien predict that while Ukraine may continue to degrade Russian forces, significant territorial gains, such as capturing Rylsk, are unlikely in the near term. The focus seems to be on attrition rather than rapid territorial advances \[[7](https://hromadske.ua/en/posts/liberated-crimea-by-the-end-of-summer-2023-forecasts-of-military-experts#:~:text=Ben%20Hodges%2C%20former%20commander%20of%20US%20forces%20in%20Europe%2C%20retired%20general%2C%20predicts%20that%20over%20the%20next%20few%20weeks%20the%20Ukrainian%20army%20will%20continue%20to%20destroy%20Russian%20warehouses%20and%20headquarters%2C%20as%20well%20as%20logistics%20networks)\]\[[9](https://hromadske.ua/en/posts/liberated-crimea-by-the-end-of-summer-2023-forecasts-of-military-experts#:~:text=I%20expect%20Ukraine%20to%20continue%20to%20do%20better%20in%20the%20war%2C%20but%20it%20will%20take%20time%20to%20waste%20down%20the%20new%20Russian%20forces%2C%E2%80%9D%20Phillips%20Payson%20O%27Brien%2C%20Professor%20of%20Strategic%20Studies%20at%20the%20University%20of%20St%20Andrews%2C%20Scotland%2C%20comments%20on%20the%20possible%20development%20of%20the%20situation%20on%20the%20battlefield%20in%202023)\]\[[11](https://hromadske.ua/en/posts/liberated-crimea-by-the-end-of-summer-2023-forecasts-of-military-experts#:~:text=%E2%80%9CNext%20year%2C%20the%20Ukrainian%20army%20will%20attempt%20to%20continue%20attrition%20Russian%20forces%2C%20while%20keeping%20their%20own%20losses%20as%20low%20as%20possible)\]\[[15](https://hromadske.ua/en/posts/liberated-crimea-by-the-end-of-summer-2023-forecasts-of-military-experts#:~:text=So%20that%20means%20adjusting%20to%20what%20the%20Russians%20give%20them)\].

Given these factors, the likelihood of Ukrainian forces capturing Rylsk by October 1, 2024, is considered low. The strategic focus on other areas and the current state of Ukrainian military capabilities are significant constraints.
## Q5: What data and predictions are available from other forecasting platforms like Manifold Markets, PredictIt, and BetFair regarding the outcome of this conflict?
Answer:
Based on the available data from Manifold Markets, there is no direct prediction specifically addressing whether Ukrainian forces will capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024. However, some relevant insights can be drawn from the broader context of the conflict:

- **Long-term Conflict Outlook**: There is a general consensus that the conflict between Russia and Ukraine is likely to be prolonged, with significant territorial disputes remaining unresolved. ## Q6: What are the logistical and strategic challenges that Ukrainian forces face in potentially capturing and holding Rylsk?
Answer:
Ukrainian forces face significant logistical and strategic challenges in potentially capturing and holding Rylsk, Russia. One major logistical hurdle is the complexity and maintenance of Western-supplied tanks and vehicles. These tanks are complicated, expensive, and require specific parts, tools, and training for maintenance. Limited repairs can be done near the front lines, but more extensive repairs would necessitate sending the tanks to Poland, which would take them out of action for extended periods \[[3](https://kyivindependent.com/can-ukraine-make-optimal-use-of-western-tanks-and-attack-vehicles/#:~:text=Ukraine%20hopes%20to%20receive%20up%20to%20two%20brigades%20of%20tanks%2C%20on%20top%20of%20many%20infantry%20vehicles%20from%20Western%20allies)\]. Additionally, the delivery schedule of these tanks and vehicles is uncertain, further complicating their effective deployment \[[3](https://kyivindependent.com/can-ukraine-make-optimal-use-of-western-tanks-and-attack-vehicles/#:~:text=Ukraine%20hopes%20to%20receive%20up%20to%20two%20brigades%20of%20tanks%2C%20on%20top%20of%20many%20infantry%20vehicles%20from%20Western%20allies)\].

Strategically, Ukraine's artillery ammunition stocks have been heavily depleted since 2014, and while tactical artillery munitions were considered sufficient by February 2022, operational stocks such as missiles and rockets remain a problem. This has been evidenced by Ukraine's continuous requests for rocket artillery ammunition \[[7](https://www.army-technology.com/features/can-nato-supply-meet-ukraines-artillery-demands/#:~:text=The%20Ukrainian%20armed%20forces%20had%20spent%20an%20estimated%2024%2C000%20tonnes%20of%20ammunition%20in%20the%20fighting%20since%202014%2C%20further%20depleting%20those%20stocks)\]. Furthermore, Russia's increasing production of long-range missiles and UAVs, supplemented by potential missile supplies from Iran, poses a significant threat to Ukrainian forces \[[1](https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/ukraine-must-prepare-hard-winter#:~:text=For%20Russia%2C%20the%20supply%20of%20strike%20munitions%20is%20increasing)\]\[[2](https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/ukraine-must-prepare-hard-winter#:~:text=In%20October%202022%20Russia%20was%20producing%20approximately%2040%20long-range%20missiles%20a%20month)\]. These factors combined create a challenging environment for Ukraine to not only capture but also hold a strategically important location like Rylsk.
## Q7: What has been the international response, including from NATO and major world powers, regarding the Ukrainian incursion into Russian territory and its potential implications?
Answer:
The international response to the Ukrainian incursion into Russian territory has been multifaceted, involving both condemnation of Russia's actions and support for Ukraine. A joint anti-Russian statement on the conflict in Ukraine was supported by only 58 United Nations member states, including the European Union nations, the United States, the United Kingdom, Georgia, Turkey, and several Asian and Latin American countries. This statement lambasted Russia’s actions and called for an immediate cessation of combat operations \[[5](https://tass.com/world/1497977#:~:text=A%20joint%20anti-Russian%20statement%20on%20the%20conflict%20in%20Ukraine%2C%20which%20was%20released%20on%20Wednesday%2C%20was%20supported%20by%20only%2058%20United%20Nations%20member%20states%2C%20or%20less%20than%20a%20third%20of%20the%20organization%E2%80%99s%20193%20members)\]. 

NATO and major world powers have shown significant support for Ukraine, with the US and European officials noting that Ukraine has effectively used resistance warfare methods developed by US special operations forces to counter Russian advances \[[11](https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/27/politics/russia-ukraine-resistance-warfare/index.html#:~:text=As%20the%20war%20in%20Ukraine%20has%20passed%20the%20six-month%20mark%2C%20US%20and%20European%20officials%20say%20Ukraine%20has%20successfully%20used%20a%20method%20of%20resistance%20warfare%20developed%20by%20US%20special%20operations%20forces%20to%20fight%20back%20against%20Russia%20and%20bog%20down%20its%20vastly%20superior%20military)\]. However, there are concerns about the long-term commitment of Western nations, as highlighted by NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, who warned of a prolonged conflict and the challenges that lie ahead \[[12](https://edition.cnn.com/2022/08/24/politics/us-commitment-to-ukraine-analysis/index.html#:~:text=So%20far%2C%20he%20has%20pulled%20off%20the%20high-wire%20feat%20of%20arming%20Ukraine%20while%20avoiding%20a%20direct%20confrontation%20with%20Russia%20that%20could%20cause%20fears%20of%20an%20escalation%20going%20all%20the%20way%20up%20to%20the%20brink%20of%20nuclear%20conflict)\]. This mixed response underscores the complexity of the geopolitical landscape and the varying levels of support and commitment from the international community.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What historical instances are there of a smaller nation successfully capturing and holding territory from a larger neighboring nation during a modern conflict?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Will Ukrainian forces capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024?", historical instances of smaller nations successfully capturing and holding territory from larger neighboring nations during modern conflicts include:

1. **Annexation of Goa by India (1961)**:
- India, a relatively smaller nation compared to Portugal's global colonial empire, successfully annexed Goa, Daman, and Diu from Portuguese control. The operation, code-named Operation Vijay, involved air, sea, and land strikes over 36 hours and resulted in a decisive victory for India, ending 451 years of Portuguese rule \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annexation_of_Goa#:~:text=In%20Portugal%2C%20it%20is%20referred%20to%20as%20the%20%22Invasion%20of%20Goa%22)\]\[[6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annexation_of_Goa#:~:text=In%20India%2C%20this%20action%20is%20referred%20to%20as%20the%20%22Liberation%20of%20Goa%22)\]\[[12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annexation_of_Goa#:~:text=%20The%20%22armed%20action%22%20was%20code%20named%20Operation%20Vijay%20%28meaning%20%22Victory%22%20in%20Sanskrit%29%20by%20the%20Indian%20Armed%20Forces)\]. This instance demonstrates that a smaller nation can indeed capture and hold territory from a larger power through a well-coordinated military operation.

2. **Annexation of Junagadh by India (1947)**:
- Following the partition of British India, the princely state of Junagadh, which initially acceded to Pakistan, was annexed by India. Facing financial collapse and lacking military strength, Junagadh's state government invited India to take control. A plebiscite conducted in December 1947 showed overwhelming support (99.95%) for joining India \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annexation_of_Junagadh#:~:text=A%20plebiscite%20was%20conducted%20in%20December%2C%20in%20which%20approximately%2099)\]\[[10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annexation_of_Junagadh#:~:text=Junagadh%27s%20state%20government%2C%20facing%20financial%20collapse%20and%20lacking%20forces%20with%20which%20to%20resist%20Indian%20force%2C%20invited%20the%20Government%20of%20India%20to%20take%20control)\]. This case highlights how political and military pressure from a smaller nation can lead to the successful acquisition of territory from a larger neighboring state.

These examples provide historical context that smaller nations can indeed capture and hold territory from larger neighbors, particularly when leveraging military strategy and political circumstances effectively.

## Q2: What is the typical success rate of incursions that achieve initial rapid advances in sustaining and expanding their territorial control over a prolonged period?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Will Ukrainian forces capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024?", understanding the typical success rate of incursions that achieve initial rapid advances in sustaining and expanding their territorial control over a prolonged period is crucial. Historical data on counterinsurgency and military operations can provide some insights:

1. **Duration and Success Rates of Insurgencies**: Modern insurgencies typically last around ten years, with the government's chances of winning increasing slightly over time. A quantitative analysis of 89 cases shows that the median length of an insurgency is ten years, and those that hit a clear tipping point around this time often tail out gradually to an end state at 16 years \[[1](http://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/monographs/2010/RAND_MG965.sum.pdf#:~:text=Modern%20insurgencies%20last%20approximately%20ten%20years%2C%20and%20the%20government%27s%20chances%20of%20winning%20may%20increase%20slightly%20over%20time)\]\[[8](http://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/monographs/2010/RAND_MG965.sum.pdf#:~:text=Quantitative%20findings%20alone%20cannot-and%20should%20not-shape%20COIN%20campaign%20planning)\]. This suggests that initial rapid advances do not necessarily translate into sustained control without prolonged effort and favorable conditions.

2. **Force Requirements and Political Outcomes**: Historical examples indicate that having sufficient military forces is necessary but not sufficient for long-term success. For instance, the French in Algeria and the Portuguese in Mozambique and Guinea-Bissau achieved military victories but ultimately faced political losses, acceding to insurgents' demands for independence. Similarly, the British in Cyprus devoted significant forces but had to relinquish control of most of the island \[[5](https://www.army.mil/article/36324/a_historical_basis_for_force_requirements_in_counterinsurgency#:~:text=Having%20enough%20military%20forces%20is%20a%20necessary%2C%20but%20by%20no%20means%20sufficient%2C%20condition%20for%20success)\]\[[6](https://www.army.mil/article/36324/a_historical_basis_for_force_requirements_in_counterinsurgency#:~:text=The%20twentieth%20century%20is%20replete%20with%20examples%20of%20counterinsurgents%20winning%20Pyrrhic%20military%20victories%20that%20resulted%20in%20political%20losses)\]. This highlights that initial military success does not guarantee sustained territorial control, especially if political and social factors are not favorable.

These insights suggest that while initial rapid advances can be achieved, sustaining and expanding territorial control over a prolonged period is complex and often requires more than just military success. Political, social, and logistical factors play significant roles in determining the long-term outcomes of such incursions.

Overall, the historical precedent suggests that incursions into nuclear-armed states are typically short-lived and do not result in sustained territorial control. ## Q4: How frequently have evacuations by the defending nation (like Russia's evacuation of Rylsk) led to the attacking nation successfully capturing the evacuated area?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Will Ukrainian forces capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024?", historical examples of evacuations by the defending nation leading to the attacking nation successfully capturing the evacuated area can provide some insight. One prominent example is the Dunkirk evacuation during World War II. Despite the successful evacuation of over 338,000 Allied soldiers from Dunkirk between May 26 and June 4, 1940, the area was subsequently captured by German forces \[[7](https://web.archive.org/web/20170205073748/https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation#:~:text=The%20Dunkirk%20evacuation%2C%20code-named%20Operation%20Dynamo%2C%20also%20known%20as%20the%20Miracle%20of%20Dunkirk%2C%20was%20the%20evacuation%20of%20Allied%20soldiers%20from%20the%20beaches%20and%20harbour%20of%20Dunkirk%2C%20France%2C%20between%2026%20May%20and%204%20June%201940%2C%20during%20World%20War%20II)\]\[[14](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation#:~:text=The%20Dunkirk%20evacuation%2C%20codenamed%20Operation%20Dynamo%20and%20also%20known%20as%20the%20Miracle%20of%20Dunkirk%2C%20or%20just%20Dunkirk%2C%20was%20the%20evacuation%20of%20more%20than%20338%2C000%20Allied%20soldiers%20during%20the%20Second%20World%20War%20from%20the%20beaches%20and%20harbour%20of%20Dunkirk%2C%20in%20the%20north%20of%20France%2C%20between%2026%20May%20and%204%20June%201940)\]. The evacuation was deemed a "miracle of deliverance" by British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, but it did not prevent the Germans from taking control of Dunkirk \[[4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation#:~:text=In%20a%20speech%20to%20the%20House%20of%20Commons%2C%20British%20Prime%20Minister%20Winston%20Churchill%20called%20this%20%22a%20colossal%20military%20disaster%22%2C%20saying%20%22the%20whole%20root%20and%20core%20and%20brain%20of%20the%20British%20Army%22%20had%20been%20stranded%20at%20Dunkirk%20and%20seemed%20about%20to%20perish%20or%20be%20captured)\]\[[14](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation#:~:text=The%20Dunkirk%20evacuation%2C%20codenamed%20Operation%20Dynamo%20and%20also%20known%20as%20the%20Miracle%20of%20Dunkirk%2C%20or%20just%20Dunkirk%2C%20was%20the%20evacuation%20of%20more%20than%20338%2C000%20Allied%20soldiers%20during%20the%20Second%20World%20War%20from%20the%20beaches%20and%20harbour%20of%20Dunkirk%2C%20in%20the%20north%20of%20France%2C%20between%2026%20May%20and%204%20June%201940)\].

This historical precedent suggests that while evacuations can save troops and resources, they often result in the attacking force capturing the evacuated area. This could imply a higher likelihood of Ukrainian forces capturing Rylsk if Russia proceeds with an evacuation.
## Q5: What historical examples exist of major strategic towns being captured and held by forces that are outnumbered or outgunned?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Will Ukrainian forces capture Rylsk, Russia before October 1, 2024?", historical examples of major strategic towns being captured and held by forces that are outnumbered or outgunned include:

1. **Siege of Boston (April 19, 1775 – March 17, 1776)**:
- During the American Revolutionary War, New England militiamen, who were outnumbered and less well-equipped compared to the British Army, successfully besieged the British forces in Boston. The British were limited to sea resupply, which was impeded by American vessels, leading to a lack of food, fuel, and supplies. The British eventually abandoned Boston after eleven months \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Boston#:~:text=The%20siege%20of%20Boston%20%28April%2019%2C%201775%20%E2%80%93%20March%2017%2C%201776%29%20was%20the%20opening%20phase%20of%20the%20American%20Revolutionary%20War)\]\[[3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Boston#:~:text=New%20England%20militiamen%20prevented%20the%20movement%20by%20land%20of%20the%20British%20Army%2C%20which%20was%20garrisoned%20in%20what%20was%20then%20the%20peninsular%20town%20of%20Boston%2C%20Massachusetts%20Bay)\]\[[6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Boston#:~:text=In%20June%201775%2C%20the%20British%20seized%20Bunker%20and%20Breed%27s%20Hills%2C%20from%20which%20the%20Continentals%20were%20preparing%20to%20bombard%20the%20city%2C%20but%20their%20casualties%20were%20heavy%20and%20their%20gains%20insufficient%20to%20break%20the%20Continental%20Army%27s%20control%20over%20land%20access%20to%20Boston)\].

2. **Siege of Plymouth (August 1642 – January 1646)**:
- In the First English Civil War, the Parliamentary garrison in Plymouth, despite being isolated and outnumbered by Royalist forces, managed to hold the town. Control of the sea allowed the garrison to be resupplied, making it difficult for the Royalists to capture the town despite several serious attempts \[[4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Plymouth#:~:text=The%20siege%20of%20Plymouth%20took%20place%20during%20the%20First%20English%20Civil%20War%2C%20when%20Royalist%20forces%20besieged%20Plymouth%2C%20in%20Devon%2C%20held%20by%20a%20Parliamentary%20garrison)\].

These examples illustrate that strategic towns can be captured and held by forces that are outnumbered or outgunned, particularly when they can leverage geographical advantages or disrupt the enemy's supply lines. This historical context may provide insights into the potential for Ukrainian forces to capture and hold Rylsk, Russia, despite potential numerical or equipment disadvantages.
## Q6: What are the success rates of military operations in which the attacking force faces significant redeployments and reinforcements from the defending force?
Answer:
The success rates of military operations where the attacking force faces significant redeployments and reinforcements from the defending force can be influenced by several factors. Historical data suggests that the effectiveness of such operations is often compromised due to the increased complexity and logistical challenges involved. For instance, the RAND Corporation's analysis of U.S. military interventions highlights that the success of military operations is significantly affected by the execution of the mission, including the number and types of forces involved, and the operating environment, such as the intensity of conflict in the host nation \[[15](https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/research_reports/RR3000/RR3062/RAND_RR3062.pdf#:~:text=these%20political%20objectives%2C%20as%20partly%20reflected%20in%20their%20increasingly%20regional%20%28rather%20than%20in-country%29%20focus)\].

Additionally, the RAND study on counterinsurgency (COIN) operations indicates that inconsistent or partial support to either side generally presages defeat, emphasizing the importance of sustained and consistent support for operational success \[[13](http://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/monographs/2010/RAND_MG965.sum.pdf#:~:text=The%20effect%20of%20the%20withdrawal%20of%20state%20sponsorship%20is%20one%20of%20the%20most%20statistically%20robust%20findings%20in%20this%20study)\]. This suggests that if the defending force can maintain consistent reinforcements and redeployments, the attacking force's chances of success diminish. Therefore, in the context of Ukrainian forces attempting to capture Rylsk, Russia, the presence of significant redeployments and reinforcements from the Russian side would likely reduce the probability of a successful Ukrainian operation.
## Q7: How often have significant redeployments of defending troops (like Russia's 30,000 troops) successfully halted or reversed the advances of an attacking force in recent conflicts?
Answer:
In recent conflicts, significant redeployments of defending troops have had mixed success in halting or reversing the advances of an attacking force. For example, during the Korean War, the United States sent the 24th Infantry Division to South Korea to counter the North Korean invasion. Despite being understrength and equipped with outdated gear, the division managed to delay the North Korean forces, buying time for additional UN troops to arrive and eventually stabilize the front \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Hwanggan#:~:text=Following%20the%20invasion%20of%20South%20Korea%20by%20North%20Korea%2C%20and%20the%20subsequent%20outbreak%20of%20the%20Korean%20War%2C%20the%20United%20Nations%20decided%20to%20commit%20troops%20to%20the%20conflict%20on%20behalf%20of%20South%20Korea)\]\[[8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Hwanggan#:~:text=For%20the%20first%20month%20after%20the%20defeat%20of%20Task%20Force%20Smith%2C%2024th%20Infantry%20Division%20soldiers%20were%20repeatedly%20defeated%20and%20forced%20south%20by%20the%20KPA%27s%20superior%20numbers%20and%20equipment)\]\[[9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Hwanggan#:~:text=The%20United%20States%20sent%20ground%20forces%20to%20the%20Korean%20peninsula%20with%20the%20goal%20of%20fighting%20back%20the%20North%20Korean%20invasion%20and%20to%20prevent%20South%20Korea%20from%20collapsing)\]. This suggests that even under less-than-ideal conditions, redeployments can be effective in delaying enemy advances.

Another example is the British intervention in Sierra Leone between 2000 and 2002. The British forces provided crucial support to the Sierra Leone government and the UN peacekeeping mission, successfully halting the advances of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) and stabilizing the situation \[[1](https://warontherocks.com/2016/08/when-intervention-works-the-instructive-case-of-sierra-leone/#:~:text=In%20some%20cases%2C%20deployed%20forces%20meet%20their%20objective%2C%20military%20and%20political%20efforts%20are%20integrated%2C%20and%20peace%20is%20crafted%20out%20of%20war)\]\[[11](https://warontherocks.com/2016/08/when-intervention-works-the-instructive-case-of-sierra-leone/#:~:text=Editor%E2%80%99s%20Note%3A%20This%20is%20adapted%20from%20a%20longer%20article%20published%20in%20the%20Journal%20for%20Strategic%20Studies)\]. This case demonstrates that well-coordinated redeployments, especially when integrated with political and military efforts, can achieve significant success.

However, it is important to note that the effectiveness of such redeployments can vary greatly depending on the context, including the quality of the troops, the level of coordination, and the specific strategic objectives.

question.question_text: Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Joe Biden)
question.resolution_criteria:
If Joe Biden is not the Democratic Party's nominee for President in 2024, this group question will resolve as **Yes** for the person who is the Democratic Party's nominee for Vice President on November 5, 2024 (Election Day). All other choices will resolve as **No**.

If Joe Biden is the Democratic presidential nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, then this question will be **annulled**.
question.fine_print:
This is a group question rather than multiple choice, which means each individual option is like its own Yes or No question. Please note that as a forecaster this means two things: 

1. You do not have to assign probabilities to every choice.
2. Your predictions do not have to sum up to 100%.

More choices might be added later, depending on credible reporting that someone is in serious contention for VP.
question.background_info:
In the wake of what the New York Times [described](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/30/us/politics/biden-campaign-debate-scramble.html) as a "disastrous" presidential debate with Donald Trump on June 28, 2024, Joe Biden's candidacy was left in a suddenly-precarious position, according to the Times. Metaculus forecasters on June 30, 2024 [assessed](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/) only an 80% chance of Biden being the Democratic presidential nominee, despite Biden having won 3,894 [pledged delegates](https://apnews.com/hub/ap-election-2024-delegate-tracker) to the Democratic National Convention (which is 98.9% of all delegates; 1,976 are needed for nomination).  

According to a [CNN analysis](https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/28/politics/election-biden-presidential-race-what-matters/index.html), if President Biden withdrew himself from contention, the assumption would be that his running mate Kamala Harris would be favorite to replace him at the top of the ticket, due to the delegates being pledged to vote for Biden and approved by the Biden-Harris campaign. Should Harris be the presidential nominee, according to [Politico](https://www.politico.com/news/2024/06/28/can-democrats-replace-biden-00165684): 

>Even if Harris coasted to the nomination, she would need a vice presidential candidate of her own, and there would still be a fight among the party’s future stars to be her running mate.

>Any of Democrats’ rising stars would be a possibility, though Newsom would be particularly unlikely. Unless either changed their residency, a Harris-Newsom ticket would be ineligible for California’s 54 electoral votes — and there’s no realistic path to a Democratic victory without them.

See also The National Interest: [Who Would 'President' Kamala Harris Pick for Vice President?](https://nationalinterest.org/blog/reboot/who-would-president-kamala-harris-pick-vice-president-209064)

In modern times, the Democratic Party typically features its vice presidential nominee's acceptance speech on Day 3 of the convention (Kamala Harris example [here](https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/dnc-2020-day-3/index.html)), which [would be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention) August 21, 2024. Possibly the decision on the ticket would be officially made in a [virtual roll call](https://ohiocapitaljournal.com/2024/06/21/exclusive-dnc-moves-ahead-on-all-virtual-roll-call-for-biden-presidential-nomination/) before the convention. However, this question will resolve based on who the nominee actually is on Election Day, since a vice presidential nominee can still withdraw after the convention, for example [Thomas Eagleton](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/04/157670201/the-thomas-eagleton-affair-haunts-candidates-today) in 1972.
