According to a [CNN analysis](https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/28/politics/election-biden-presidential-race-what-matters/index.html), if President Biden withdrew himself from contention, the assumption would be that his running mate Kamala Harris would be favorite to replace him at the top of the ticket, due to the delegates being pledged to vote for Biden and approved by the Biden-Harris campaign. Should Harris be the presidential nominee, according to [Politico](https://www.politico.com/news/2024/06/28/can-democrats-replace-biden-00165684): 

>Even if Harris coasted to the nomination, she would need a vice presidential candidate of her own, and there would still be a fight among the party’s future stars to be her running mate.

>Any of Democrats’ rising stars would be a possibility, though Newsom would be particularly unlikely. Unless either changed their residency, a Harris-Newsom ticket would be ineligible for California’s 54 electoral votes — and there’s no realistic path to a Democratic victory without them.

See also The National Interest: [Who Would 'President' Kamala Harris Pick for Vice President?](https://nationalinterest.org/blog/reboot/who-would-president-kamala-harris-pick-vice-president-209064)

In modern times, the Democratic Party typically features its vice presidential nominee's acceptance speech on Day 3 of the convention (Kamala Harris example [here](https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/dnc-2020-day-3/index.html)), which [would be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention) August 21, 2024. Possibly the decision on the ticket would be officially made in a [virtual roll call](https://ohiocapitaljournal.com/2024/06/21/exclusive-dnc-moves-ahead-on-all-virtual-roll-call-for-biden-presidential-nomination/) before the convention. However, this question will resolve based on who the nominee actually is on Election Day, since a vice presidential nominee can still withdraw after the convention, for example [Thomas Eagleton](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/04/157670201/the-thomas-eagleton-affair-haunts-candidates-today) in 1972.
api_json.resolution_criteria:
If Joe Biden is not the Democratic Party's nominee for President in 2024, this group question will resolve as **Yes** for the person who is the Democratic Party's nominee for Vice President on November 5, 2024 (Election Day). All other choices will resolve as **No**.

If Joe Biden is the Democratic presidential nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, then this question will be **annulled**.
api_json.fine_print:
This is a group question rather than multiple choice, which means each individual option is like its own Yes or No question. Please note that as a forecaster this means two things: 

1. You do not have to assign probabilities to every choice.
2. Your predictions do not have to sum up to 100%.

More choices might be added later, depending on credible reporting that someone is in serious contention for VP.

explanation:
# SUMMARY
*Question*: Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)? (Joe Biden)

*Final Prediction*: 40.0%

*Total Cost*: $1.05

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 45.0%] Chose a base rate of 50% based on the historical precedent of sitting Vice Presidents running for President and winning. Adjusted up for endorsements and active involvement, but down for low approval ratings and historical low success rate.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 40.0%] Chose a base rate of 50% based on the likelihood of a Vice President becoming the presidential nominee. Adjusted up for support from key leaders and active involvement, but down for declining approval ratings and other strong contenders.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 40.0%] Chose a base rate of 39% due to general uncertainty. Adjusted up for support and policy promises, but down for declining approval ratings and low success rate of Vice Presidents in general elections.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 39.0%] Chose a base rate of 39% due to lack of strong historical precedent. Adjusted up for support and endorsements, but down for declining approval ratings and rarity of a Vice President choosing a new running mate.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 44.0%] Chose a base rate of 39% due to no strong historical precedent. Adjusted up for endorsements and active involvement, but down for declining popularity and public concerns about Biden's age.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on predicting who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President. The forecasters considered various factors, including historical precedents, current political endorsements, and approval ratings. Kamala Harris emerged as a strong contender due to her current role as Vice President, endorsements from key Democratic leaders, and her active involvement in the campaign. However, her declining approval ratings and the low historical success rate of Vice Presidents in securing the general election were significant concerns.

The forecasters also examined the likelihood of Joe Biden withdrawing from the race, which currently seems low based on available reports. They considered other potential candidates like Dean Phillips and Cedric Richmond but found Harris to be the most likely choice due to her national profile and the loyalty of Biden's pledged delegates. The base rates used varied, with some forecasters choosing a higher rate based on historical precedents and others opting for a more conservative rate due to the general uncertainty and lack of strong historical data.

## Possible Base Rates
- Since the ratification of the Twelfth Amendment in 1804, 12 Vice Presidents have run for President while in office, and 6 of them have been elected to the presidency. This gives a base rate of 50% [S2.Q0]
- Out of the 47 individuals who have served as Vice President, only 14 have become President, giving a base rate of approximately 30% [S2.Q2]
- The typical rate of a question resolving positively is 39% [S2.Q0]

## Pros
- Kamala Harris has received endorsements from prominent Democratic leaders such as Jim Clyburn, Hakeem Jeffries, and Nancy Pelosi [S1.Q7]
- Kamala Harris has expressed a strong stance against Donald Trump and his policies, indicating her active involvement and commitment to the 2024 election campaign [S1.Q1]
- Kamala Harris is considered the most likely candidate due to her large national profile and the fact that Biden’s pledged delegates are mostly party loyalists who would likely seek the safest possible choice [S1.Q6]

## Cons
- Kamala Harris's approval rating stood at 39.2%, with a disapproval rating of 51.3%, resulting in a net approval rating of -12.1 points [S1.Q4]
- There is significant public concern about Biden's age, with 77% of Americans, including 69% of Democrats, believing he is too old to serve a second term [S1.Q5]
- The success rate of Vice Presidents who became presidential nominees in securing the general election is relatively low, with only five out of 47 becoming President in their own right [S2.Q2]

## Weaknesses and possible improvements
- *Overreliance on Historical Precedent*: The chosen base rates heavily relied on historical precedents, which may not fully capture the unique political dynamics of the current election cycle. "Given the possible base rates, the most appropriate base rate is 50% because it directly relates to the historical precedent of sitting Vice Presidents running for President and winning" [S3.Forecaster 0]
- *Insufficient Consideration of Emerging Contenders*: The analysis did not sufficiently weigh the potential impact of emerging contenders like Dean Phillips and Cedric Richmond. "There are other prominent Democratic politicians who have recently emerged as strong contenders for the vice-presidential nomination" [S3.Forecaster 1]
- *Lack of Credible Withdrawal Reports*: The forecasters did not adequately address the lack of credible reports indicating Biden's potential withdrawal, which could significantly alter the forecast. "There are no credible reports or strong rumors indicating that Joe Biden is planning to withdraw from the 2024 presidential race" [S1.Q5]


# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What are the current predictions on Metaculus for Joe Biden being the Democratic presidential nominee in 2024?
Answer:
As of the latest information available, the current predictions on Metaculus for Joe Biden being the Democratic presidential nominee in 2024 indicate significant uncertainty. According to a Metaculus question titled "Who will be the Democratic nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?", many top Democratic officials have expressed concerns about a Biden re-election campaign and there is uncertainty about selecting an alternative nominee \[[2](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=The%20New%20York%20Times%20reported%20in%20June%202022%20that%20many%20top%20Democrat%20officials%20expressed%20%28off%20the%20record%29%20concerns%20about%20a%20Biden%20re-election%20campaign%2C%20and%20uncertainty%20about%20selecting%20an%20alternative%20nominee)\]\[[6](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%2C%20often%20speculated%20as%20being%20likely%20to%20run%20in%202024%2C%20has%20had%20a%20net%20-10%25%20approval%20rating%20from%20January%20to%20June%202022)\]. This sentiment is echoed by the New York Times, which reported in June 2022 that no other candidates have expressed intent to run, and no candidate besides Vice President Kamala Harris stands out in early polling \[[6](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%2C%20often%20speculated%20as%20being%20likely%20to%20run%20in%202024%2C%20has%20had%20a%20net%20-10%25%20approval%20rating%20from%20January%20to%20June%202022)\]\[[12](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11379/2024-democrat-nominee-for-us-prez/#:~:text=As%20of%20June%202022%2C%20no%20other%20candidates%20have%20expressed%20intent%20to%20run%2C%20and%20no%20candidate%20%28besides%20Harris%29%2C%20stands%20out%20in%20early%20polling)\]. 

These factors suggest that while Biden is still a potential candidate, there is considerable doubt within the Democratic Party about his re-election prospects, which could influence the likelihood of him being the nominee.
## Q1: What has Kamala Harris said recently about her intentions and plans for the 2024 election?
Answer:
Kamala Harris has made several statements that indicate her active involvement and commitment to the 2024 election campaign. Notably, she has expressed a strong stance against Donald Trump and his policies, emphasizing the importance of protecting freedoms and rights. For instance, she stated, "This election is a fight for our country, our future, and our most fundamental freedoms and rights. We believe in the promise of America—and we’re in this fight because we know what’s at stake" \[[2](https://twitter.com/KamalaHarris/status/1820199552823013866#:~:text=This%20election%20is%20a%20fight%20for%20our%20country%2C%20our%20future%2C%20and%20our%20most%20fundamental%20freedoms%20and%20rights)\]. Additionally, she has highlighted her vision for the future, contrasting it with Trump's focus on the past: "This campaign is about two different visions for our nation. Ours is focused on the future. Donald Trump’s is focused on the past. We’re not going back" \[[3](https://twitter.com/KamalaHarris/status/1819065816060514647#:~:text=This%20campaign%20is%20about%20two%20different%20visions%20for%20our%20nation)\].

Moreover, Harris has made specific policy promises, such as addressing the housing shortage by building 3 million homes and rentals if she becomes President \[[6](https://twitter.com/KamalaHarris/status/1828387584101237162#:~:text=My%20mother%20saved%20for%20years%20to%20buy%20a%20home)\]. She has also committed to restoring and protecting reproductive freedom across all states \[[15](https://twitter.com/KamalaHarris/status/1817929460009558453#:~:text=More%20than%201%20in%203%20women%20of%20reproductive%20age%20in%20America%20now%20live%20in%20a%20state%20with%20a%20Trump%20abortion%20ban)\]. These statements collectively suggest that Harris is positioning herself as a key figure in the Democratic campaign, with a clear focus on future-oriented policies and a strong opposition to Trump’s agenda.
## Q2: Are there any prominent Democratic politicians who have recently emerged as strong contenders for the vice-presidential nomination?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)?", there are a few prominent Democratic politicians who have recently emerged as strong contenders for the vice-presidential nomination:

1. **Dean Phillips**: Democratic Rep. Dean Phillips has been openly expressing hesitation about renominating Biden and has been exploring a primary challenge to Biden for the 2024 election. Phillips, a moderate who flipped a GOP-held seat in 2018 and now serves as a co-chair of the Democratic Policy and Communications Committee, has been receiving inquiries about his willingness to challenge Biden and will meet with Democratic donors about the prospect \[[3](https://www.axios.com/2023/07/28/dean-phillips-primary-biden-2024-election#:~:text=He%20first%20confirmed%20it%20to%20the%20Star%20Tribune)\]\[[9](https://www.axios.com/2023/07/28/dean-phillips-primary-biden-2024-election#:~:text=Between%20the%20lines%3A%20Phillips%2C%20a%20moderate%20who%20flipped%20a%20GOP-held%20seat%20in%202018%20and%20now%20serves%20as%20a%20co-chair%20of%20the%20Democratic%20Policy%20and%20Communications%20Committee%2C%20is%20not%20a%20household%20name%20outside%20his%20home%20state)\]\[[14](https://www.axios.com/2023/07/28/dean-phillips-primary-biden-2024-election#:~:text=%29%20on%20Friday%20confirmed%20reporting%20that%20he%20is%20being%20pushed%20to%20challenge%20President%20Biden%20for%20the%20Democratic%20nomination%20in%202024)\].

2. **Cedric Richmond**: Cedric Richmond, a longtime supporter of both Biden and Harris’ political careers, has been floated as a potential running mate for Kamala Harris. Richmond is a well-known figure within political circles in the nation’s capital and has been considered a strong contender due to his political experience and connections \[[10](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/07/24/who-is-cedric-richmond/74524206007/#:~:text=As%20inquiries%20into%20who%20may%20join%20the%20Democratic%20ticket%20as%20Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%E2%80%99%20running%20mate%20grow%20more%20intense%2C%20the%20names%20of%20numerous%20prominent%20Democrats%2C%20including%20several%20current%20members%20of%20Congress%20and%20governors%20in%20at%20least%20five%20states%2C%20have%20been%20floated%2C%20according%20to%20sources%20familiar%20with%20the%20process)\].

These individuals have gained attention recently and could be significant contenders for the vice-presidential nomination if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President.
## Q3: What are prediction markets like PredictIt, BetFair, and FiveThirtyEight forecasting about the Democratic vice-presidential nominee if Biden is not the presidential nominee?
Answer:
Based on the available information, prediction markets and political analysts have floated several names as potential Democratic vice-presidential nominees if Joe Biden is no longer the presidential nominee in 2024. Key figures include:

- **Kamala Harris**: As the current Vice President, she remains a prominent figure and a likely candidate for the VP slot. Her involvement in significant policy areas, such as voting rights, underscores her continued relevance and visibility within the Democratic Party \[[4](https://www.africanamericanreports.com/search/label/Kamala%20Harris#:~:text=In%20the%20last%20election%2C%20more%20people%20voted%20than%20ever%20before)\]\[[7](https://www.africanamericanreports.com/search/label/Kamala%20Harris#:~:text=Today%2C%20that%20hard-won%20progress%20is%20under%20assault)\]\[[10](https://www.africanamericanreports.com/search/label/Kamala%20Harris#:~:text=%20Every%20American%20has%20a%20right%20to%20have%20their%20voice%20heard%20at%20the%20ballot%20box%2C%20and%20no%20American%20should%20be%20kept%20from%20voting%20early%2C%20voting%20by%20mail%2C%20or%20voting%20at%20all)\]\[[12](https://www.africanamericanreports.com/search/label/Kamala%20Harris#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%20released%20the%20following%20statement%20on%20Administration%E2%80%99s%20Voting%20Rights%20Efforts%3A%20%20Every%20American%20has%20a%20right%20to%20have%20their%20voice%20heard%20at%20the%20ballot%20box%2C%20and%20no%20American%20should%20be%20kept%20from%20voting%20early%2C%20voting%20by%20mail%2C%20or%20voting%20at%20all)\].
- **Cedric Richmond**: A long-time supporter of both Biden and Harris, Richmond is a well-known figure within political circles in Washington, D.C. His name has been mentioned as a potential running mate for Harris, highlighting his political influence and connections \[[6](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/07/24/who-is-cedric-richmond/74524206007/#:~:text=As%20inquiries%20into%20who%20may%20join%20the%20Democratic%20ticket%20as%20Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%E2%80%99%20running%20mate%20grow%20more%20intense%2C%20the%20names%20of%20numerous%20prominent%20Democrats%2C%20including%20several%20current%20members%20of%20Congress%20and%20governors%20in%20at%20least%20five%20states%2C%20have%20been%20floated%2C%20according%20to%20sources%20familiar%20with%20the%20process)\].
- **John Fetterman**: The current U.S. Senator from Pennsylvania, Fetterman has gained attention for his electoral success and progressive stance. His recent election to the Senate and his background make him a notable contender \[[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Fetterman#:~:text=He%20won%20the%20Democratic%20nomination%20with%2059%25%20of%20the%20vote%20and%20defeated%20Republican%20Party%20nominee%20Mehmet%20Oz%20in%20the%20general%20election%20with%2051%25%20of%20the%20vote%2C%20becoming%20the%20first%20Democrat%20to%20win%20this%20seat%20since%201962)\]\[[8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Fetterman#:~:text=%5Ba%5D%20%20Fetterman%20resigned%20as%20lieutenant%20governor%20upon%20being%20sworn%20in%20to%20the%20Senate%20on%20January%203%2C%202023)\].
- **Raphael Warnock**: As a U.S. Senator from Georgia, Warnock's historic win and his role in securing Democratic control of the Senate make him a significant figure. His prominence in the party could position him as a strong VP candidate \[[9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raphael_Warnock#:~:text=No%20candidate%20received%20a%20majority%20of%20the%20vote%20on%20election%20day%2C%20so%20Warnock%20faced%20Loeffler%20again%20in%20a%20January%205%2C%202021%2C%20runoff%20election%2C%20which%20he%20won%20by%20more%20than%2093%2C000%20votes)\].

These names reflect a mix of established political figures and rising stars within the Democratic Party, each bringing unique strengths to a potential vice-presidential candidacy.
## Q4: What do recent polls and approval ratings say about Kamala Harris's popularity within the Democratic Party?
Answer:
Recent polls and approval ratings indicate that Vice President Kamala Harris's popularity within the Democratic Party has seen a slight decline in 2023. As of June 26, 2023, her approval rating stood at 39.2%, with a disapproval rating of 51.3%, resulting in a net approval rating of -12.1 points. This is a small decline from her net approval rating of -10.7 points on January 1, 2023 \[[1](https://www.newsweek.com/how-kamala-harris-approval-rating-stands-half-way-through-2023-1812355#:~:text=Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%27%20approval%20rating%20is%20lower%20than%20President%20Joe%20Biden%27s%20after%20the%20first%20six%20months%20of%202023%2C%20but%20it%20has%20remained%20largely%20stable%20since%20January)\]\[[4](https://www.newsweek.com/how-kamala-harris-approval-rating-stands-half-way-through-2023-1812355#:~:text=Figures%20from%20poll%20tracker%20FiveThirtyEight%20show%20that%20the%20vice%20president%20enjoyed%20an%20approval%20rating%20of%2039)\]. Additionally, her favorability among Democrats has dipped, although her overall favorability rating has improved slightly from 39% in January to 43% in April 2023 \[[2](https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/white-house/kamala-harris-party-approval-poll#:~:text=%28AP%20Photo/Evan%20Vucci%29%20However%2C%20among%20Republicans%20and%20independents%2C%20the%20vice%20president%27s%20approval%20rating%20is%20making%20some%20headway)\].

Despite these figures, Harris has managed to gain some traction among independents, with her favorability rising from 30% to 36% between January and April 2023 \[[2](https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/white-house/kamala-harris-party-approval-poll#:~:text=%28AP%20Photo/Evan%20Vucci%29%20However%2C%20among%20Republicans%20and%20independents%2C%20the%20vice%20president%27s%20approval%20rating%20is%20making%20some%20headway)\]. This could be significant for her broader appeal, but within the Democratic Party, the slight decline in her approval ratings may impact her chances of being the nominee for Vice President if Joe Biden is no longer the presidential nominee.
## Q5: Are there any credible reports or rumors about Joe Biden potentially withdrawing from the 2024 presidential race?
Answer:
There are currently no credible reports or strong rumors indicating that Joe Biden is planning to withdraw from the 2024 presidential race. On the contrary, multiple sources affirm that Biden fully expects to run for re-election. For instance, a source familiar with Biden's thinking stated, "As the president has said before, he fully expects to run for reelection" \[[3](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/biden-advisers-push-early-launch-his-2024-presidential-campaign-2022-08-12/#:~:text=%22There%20is%20no%20planned%20date%20or%20timeframe)\]\[[15](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/biden-advisers-push-early-launch-his-2024-presidential-campaign-2022-08-12/#:~:text=As%20the%20president%20has%20said%20before%2C%20he%20fully%20expects%20to%20run%20for%20reelection%2C%22%20that%20source%20said)\]. Additionally, Biden's advisers are pushing for an early launch of his 2024 presidential campaign, further indicating his intention to run \[[2](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/biden-advisers-push-early-launch-his-2024-presidential-campaign-2022-08-12/#:~:text=Biden%2C%20who%20turns%2080%20shortly%20after%20the%20Nov)\]\[[14](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/biden-advisers-push-early-launch-his-2024-presidential-campaign-2022-08-12/#:~:text=%22The%20Republican%20campaign%20for%20president%20begins%20after%20the%20midterms%20and%20the%20president%20needs%20to%20make%20the%20announcement%20during%20the%20same%20time%20to%20satisfy%20concerns%20within%20the%20party%2C%22%20one%20top%20Democratic%20official%20said)\].

However, it is worth noting that there is significant public concern about Biden's age, with 77% of Americans, including 69% of Democrats, believing he is too old to serve a second term \[[1](https://www.zerohedge.com/political/almost-70-democrats-say-biden-too-old-run-again-new-ap-poll-finds#:~:text=Authored%20by%20Steve%20Watson%20via%20Summit%20News%2C%20%20%20%20A%20new%20Associated%20Press/NORC%20poll%20has%20found%20that%20an%20overwhelming%20majority%20of%20Americans%20believe%20Joe%20Biden%20to%20be%20too%20old%20to%20run%20for%20a%20second%20term%20as%20president%2C%20with%20a%20huge%20amount%20of%20Democrats%20concurring)\]. This sentiment could potentially influence his decision-making process, but as of now, there are no credible indications that he will withdraw.
## Q6: What have major news outlets like CNN, Politico, and The New York Times reported about the Democratic Party's strategy if Biden is not the nominee?
Answer:
Major news outlets like CNN, Politico, and The New York Times have reported on the Democratic Party's strategy if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President in 2024. The process for replacing Biden would be complex and politically volatile, given that he has already secured far more delegates than needed to win the nomination. The Democratic National Convention, which will formally end the primary process, is scheduled for next month \[[1](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jun/29/if-biden-drops-out-how-choose-democrat-candidate-replace#:~:text=On%20Tuesday%2C%20Lloyd%20Doggett%20of%20Texas%20became%20the%20first%20Democratic%20member%20of%20Congress%20to%20publicly%20call%20on%20Biden%20to%20drop%20out%2C%20but%2025%20others%20are%20preparing%20to%20do%20the%20same)\].

If Biden were to step aside, the vice-president, Kamala Harris, is considered the most likely candidate due to her large national profile and the fact that Biden’s pledged delegates are mostly party loyalists who would likely seek the safest possible choice \[[2](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jun/29/if-biden-drops-out-how-choose-democrat-candidate-replace#:~:text=As%20the%20vice-president%2C%20she%20has%20the%20largest%20national%20profile%20of%20any%20potential%20candidate%2C%20and%20Biden%E2%80%99s%20pledged%20delegates%20are%20mostly%20party%20loyalists%20who%20would%20be%20looking%20for%20the%20safest%20possible%20choice%20if%20he%20stepped%20aside)\]. The selection process would involve a first ballot where a majority of the roughly 4,000 pledged delegates' votes is needed. If no candidate secures a majority on the first ballot, the process would move to a second ballot where superdelegates would also have a vote \[[2](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jun/29/if-biden-drops-out-how-choose-democrat-candidate-replace#:~:text=As%20the%20vice-president%2C%20she%20has%20the%20largest%20national%20profile%20of%20any%20potential%20candidate%2C%20and%20Biden%E2%80%99s%20pledged%20delegates%20are%20mostly%20party%20loyalists%20who%20would%20be%20looking%20for%20the%20safest%20possible%20choice%20if%20he%20stepped%20aside)\]. Additionally, if multiple candidates contest the convention, a "mini-primary" would take place, where candidates would campaign among state delegations, paying particular attention to large states like California, New York, and Texas \[[6](https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2024/07/13/how-biden-could-be-replaced-at-democratic-convention-00167907#:~:text=But%20to%20have%20a%20contested%20convention%2C%20you%20need%20more%20than%20one%20candidate%20actually%20contesting%20the%20convention)\].
## Q7: Are there any recent endorsements or support statements from influential Democratic figures or groups regarding potential vice-presidential candidates?
Answer:
### Recent Endorsements or Support Statements for Potential Vice-Presidential Candidates

1. **Kamala Harris**:
- **Support from Influential Figures**: Kamala Harris has received endorsements from prominent Democratic leaders such as Jim Clyburn, Hakeem Jeffries, and Nancy Pelosi \[[2](https://msmagazine.com/2024/07/24/kamala-harris-history-black-women-politics-first-president/#:~:text=Congressional%20leaders%20Jim%20Clyburn%2C%20Hakeem%20Jeffries%20and%20Nancy%20Pelosi%20have%20given%20their%20support)\]. Additionally, Hillary Clinton has publicly supported Harris, emphasizing her qualifications and potential to break the "centuries-old ceiling" as a woman of color \[[7](https://msmagazine.com/2024/08/22/first-woman-president-kamala-harris-hillary-clinton/#:~:text=%E2%80%9CWe%20had%20an%20amazing%20opportunity%20with%20Hillary%20Clinton)\]\[[15](https://msmagazine.com/2024/08/22/first-woman-president-kamala-harris-hillary-clinton/#:~:text=This%20week%2C%20in%20what%20might%20have%20been%20the%20waning%20days%20of%20her%20second%20term%2C%20Clinton%20declared%20in%20a%20full-throated%20speech%20at%20the%20Democratic%20National%20Convention%2C%20that%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20future%20is%20here)\].

- **Endorsements and Advocacy**: While there are no direct endorsements from top Democratic figures in the provided sources, Whitmer's political success and leadership have been noted by political commentators as making her a viable candidate for the vice-presidential slot \[[1](https://www.joshbarro.com/p/biden-should-pick-a-new-running-mate#:~:text=In%202018%2C%20Gretchen%20Whitmer%20was%20elected%20governor%20of%20Michigan%20by%20a%20margin%20of%209)\]\[[5](https://www.joshbarro.com/p/biden-should-pick-a-new-running-mate#:~:text=Which%20brings%20me%20to%20Gretchen%20Whitmer)\]\[[6](https://www.joshbarro.com/p/biden-should-pick-a-new-running-mate#:~:text=So%20I%20think%20it%20would%20be%20ideal%20if%20Biden%20can%20set%20himself%20up%20so%20he%E2%80%99s%20passing%20the%20torch%20to%20a%20woman%20who%20is%20well-positioned%20to%20unite%20the%20party%20and%20lead%20it%20to%20victory%20in%202028)\].

This selection was the result of an intensive vetting process and has been seen as politically beneficial by many Democrats \[[8](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/08/06/harris-walz-vp/#:~:text=We%20are%20going%20to%20build%20a%20great%20partnership)\]\[[11](https://jacobin.com/2024/08/tim-walz-vp-harris-democrats#:~:text=Only%20two%20weeks%20after%20President%20Joe%20Biden%E2%80%99s%20decision%20to%20end%20his%20campaign%20turned%20the%202024%20election%20on%20its%20head%2C%20Vice%20President%20Kamala%20Harris%20has%20shocked%20the%20political%20establishment%20by%20choosing%20as%20her%20running%20mate%20Minnesota%20governor%20Tim%20Walz%2C%20the%20most%20progressive%20of%20the%20handful%20of%20names%20in%20contention)\]\[[13](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/08/06/harris-walz-vp/#:~:text=We%20start%20out%20as%20underdogs%20but%20I%20believe%20together%2C%20we%20can%20win%20this%20election)\].

### Summary
Kamala Harris has substantial support from key Democratic leaders and influential figures, which could make her a strong contender for the vice-presidential nomination if Joe Biden is no longer the presidential nominee. Gretchen Whitmer and Tim Walz are also notable candidates, with Whitmer's political achievements and Walz's recent selection by Harris highlighting their potential viability.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What is the historical precedent for a sitting Vice President becoming the presidential nominee if the sitting President does not run for re-election?
Answer:
Historically, the precedent for a sitting Vice President becoming the presidential nominee if the sitting President does not run for re-election is relatively rare but not unprecedented. Since the ratification of the Twelfth Amendment in 1804, which required separate votes for President and Vice President, there have been several instances where sitting Vice Presidents have sought their party's nomination for President. Notably, twelve Vice Presidents have run for President while in office, and six of them have been elected to the presidency \[[9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_vice_presidents_who_ran_for_president#:~:text=Eighteen%20of%20the%2049%20vice%20presidents%20of%20the%20United%20States%20have%20attempted%20a%20run%20for%20the%20presidency%20after%20being%20elected%20vice%20president)\]. 

A key example is Hubert Humphrey, who became the Democratic nominee in 1968 after President Lyndon B. Johnson announced he would not seek re-election. Humphrey's strategy focused on winning delegates from non-primary states, which ultimately secured him the nomination \[[12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey#:~:text=After%20Lyndon%20B)\]. However, it is important to note that the success rate for sitting Vice Presidents is not particularly high; the past 50 years have seen only George H.W. Bush successfully ascend from Vice President to President \[[4](https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2015/10/21/9574065/vice-presidents-president-history#:~:text=Before%201803%2C%20the%20electoral%20college%20used%20to%20cast%20two%20votes%20%E2%80%94%20one%20for%20president%20and%20one%20for%20vice%20president%20%E2%80%94%20but%20those%20votes%20did%20not%20specify%20which%20person%20they%20wanted%20in%20which%20office)\]. This historical context suggests that while it is possible for a sitting Vice President to become the presidential nominee, it is not a common occurrence and often involves significant political maneuvering.
## Q1: How often has a sitting Vice President chosen a new running mate after stepping into the presidential nominee role?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Who will be the Democratic nominee for Vice President on Election Day 2024 (if Joe Biden is no longer the nominee for President)?", it is important to understand how often a sitting Vice President has chosen a new running mate after stepping into the presidential nominee role.

Historically, there have been very few instances where a sitting Vice President has had to choose a new running mate after stepping into the presidential nominee role. One notable example is Lyndon B. Johnson, who became the Democratic presidential nominee after the assassination of John F. Kennedy in 1963. Johnson chose Hubert Humphrey as his running mate for the 1964 election \[[9](https://www.school-for-champions.com/history/how_lyndon_johnson_vetted_humphrey.htm#:~:text=The%20selection%20process%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Vice%20President%20follows%20different%20courses)\]. Another example is Gerald Ford, who became President after Richard Nixon's resignation in 1974 and subsequently chose Nelson Rockefeller as his Vice President, although this was not during an election year \[[9](https://www.school-for-champions.com/history/how_lyndon_johnson_vetted_humphrey.htm#:~:text=The%20selection%20process%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Vice%20President%20follows%20different%20courses)\].

Overall, the historical precedent for a sitting Vice President choosing a new running mate after stepping into the presidential nominee role is rare. This rarity suggests that if such a situation were to occur in 2024, it would be an unusual and significant event.
## Q2: What has been the success rate of Vice Presidents who became presidential nominees in securing the general election?
Answer:
The success rate of Vice Presidents who became presidential nominees in securing the general election is relatively low. Historically, out of the 47 individuals who have served as Vice President, only 14 have become President. Of these, five were elected in their own right, while the others ascended to the presidency due to the death or resignation of the sitting President \[[6](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/five-myths-about-the-veepstakes/2012/06/29/gJQAaSyTBW_story.html#:~:text=Fourteen%20vice%20presidents%20have%20become%20president)\]\[[10](https://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-vice-presidential-advantage/#:~:text=Nine%20of%20the%2047%20vice%20presidents%20became%20president%20through%20the%20death%20or%20resignation%20of%20their%20predecessor)\]. Additionally, there have been 17 bids for the presidency launched after a Vice President's term, with seven securing their party's nomination but losing the general election \[[12](https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2015/10/21/9574065/vice-presidents-president-history#:~:text=But%20the%20numbers%20show%20it%27s%20not%20a%20well-trod%20path)\]. This indicates that while Vice Presidents often become their party's presidential nominees, their success rate in winning the general election is less than 30%.

Furthermore, the role of the Vice Presidency has evolved, and since Nixon in 1960, every elected Vice President except Dan Quayle has led in pre-convention polls and won their party's nomination \[[13](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Vice%20presidents%20have%20become%20the%20presumptive%20front-runners%20for%20their%20party%27s%20presidential%20nomination)\]. However, this does not necessarily translate to winning the general election, as historical data shows a mixed record of success.
## Q3: How often have political parties changed their vice-presidential nominee close to the election in the last 50 years?
Answer:
In the last 50 years, there have been no instances where a major U.S. political party has changed its vice-presidential nominee close to the election. The historical precedent shows that once a vice-presidential candidate is selected, they typically remain on the ticket through the election. This stability is likely due to the significant logistical and strategic challenges involved in changing a running mate so close to an election, as well as the potential negative perception it could create among voters.

For example, in 1968, Hubert Humphrey, who was Lyndon B. Johnson's vice president, secured the Democratic nomination for president but did not change his vice-presidential running mate close to the election \[[3](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/08/01/most-us-vice-presidents-in-recent-decades-have-sought-the-presidency-but-relatively-few-have-won/?utm_content=bufferf8611&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer-pew#:~:text=%20Hubert%20Humphrey%2C%20Johnson%E2%80%99s%20former%20vice%20president%2C%20secured%20the%20Democratic%20nomination%20in%201968%20but%20lost%20the%20election%20to%20Nixon)\]. Similarly, in more recent elections, vice-presidential candidates have remained consistent once chosen, even in contentious or challenging election cycles.

This historical consistency suggests that it is highly unlikely for a political party to change its vice-presidential nominee close to the election, barring extraordinary circumstances.
## Q4: What percentage of vice-presidential nominees were selected from among the party's rising stars or prominent politicians in recent elections?
Answer:
In recent elections, vice-presidential nominees have often been selected from among the party's rising stars or prominent politicians. According to the Center for Politics, vice-presidential candidates generally come from those who did not seek the presidency that year, although some have previously run for president. Since 1960, only eight of the 24 first-time vice-presidential candidates had previously run for president, indicating a preference for fresh faces or those with significant political experience but not necessarily presidential ambitions \[[9](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20have%20come%20from%20those%20who%20did%20not%20seek%20the%20presidency%20that%20year)\].

Additionally, the selection process is highly personal and idiosyncratic, determined by the presidential candidate's criteria and the political context at the time of selection. This process often involves intense vetting to ensure the candidate is a plausible president and can provide electoral benefits in key states or among important constituencies \[[6](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=%201%29%20Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20must%20survive%20an%20intense%20vetting%20screen%20and%20be%20plausible%20presidents)\]\[[10](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=Of%20course%2C%20politics%20will%20play%20a%20role%20in%20the%20selection)\]. This suggests that while the selection is influenced by various factors, the trend leans towards choosing individuals who are seen as rising stars or have substantial political experience.

Sources:
- \[[9](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20have%20come%20from%20those%20who%20did%20not%20seek%20the%20presidency%20that%20year)\] Center for Politics, "The Democratic Vice Presidential Derby: Look Beyond the 2020 Contenders"
- \[[6](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=%201%29%20Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20must%20survive%20an%20intense%20vetting%20screen%20and%20be%20plausible%20presidents)\] Center for Politics, "The Democratic Vice Presidential Derby: Look Beyond the 2020 Contenders"
- \[[10](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=Of%20course%2C%20politics%20will%20play%20a%20role%20in%20the%20selection)\] Bipartisan Policy Center, "Selecting a Vice President: Advice for Presidential Candidates"
## Q5: What are the typical characteristics (e.g., political experience, demographic background) of vice-presidential nominees selected under similar circumstances?
Answer:
Vice-presidential nominees selected under circumstances where the presidential nominee is no longer the incumbent typically have significant political experience, often as senators, high federal executive officials, governors, or members of the House. Since 1940, 18 of the 31 first-time vice-presidential selectees had most recently been senators, six had held high federal executive office, four were governors, and three were members of the House \[[1](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=Only%20three%20%E2%80%94%20Geraldine%20Ferraro%2C%20John%20Edwards%2C%20and%20Sarah%20Palin%20%E2%80%94%20had%20less%20than%20six%20years)\]\[[3](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=The%20average%20for%20the%20last%2014%20first-time%20running%20mates%20is%2014%20years)\]. The average political experience for the last 14 first-time running mates is 14 years, with only three having less than six years of experience \[[3](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=The%20average%20for%20the%20last%2014%20first-time%20running%20mates%20is%2014%20years)\]\[[7](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=But%20consideration%20of%20those%20candidates%20were%20anomalous%2C%20and%20these%20nontraditional%20possibilities%20generally%20came%20before%20the%20rise%20of%20the%20vice%20presidency%20as%20a%20more%20influential%20office%20or%20were%20floated%20by%20presidential%20candidates%20who%20had%20extensive%20national%20experience%2C%20which%20compensated%20for%20these%20candidates%E2%80%99%20lack%20of%20typical%20experience)\].

Additionally, vice-presidential candidates generally have not sought the presidency in the same election year. Since 1960, only eight of the 24 first-time vice-presidential candidates had previously run for president, indicating that two-thirds of those chosen had not previously sought their party’s presidential nomination \[[2](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20have%20come%20from%20those%20who%20did%20not%20seek%20the%20presidency%20that%20year)\]\[[4](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Occasionally%2C%20the%20running%20mate%20sought%20the%20presidential%20nomination%20previously)\]. This suggests that the pool of potential vice-presidential nominees is often drawn from experienced politicians who have not been recent presidential contenders.
## Q6: How frequently do political endorsements influence the selection of vice-presidential nominees in competitive or uncertain election cycles?
Answer:
Political endorsements can play a significant role in the selection of vice-presidential nominees, particularly in competitive or uncertain election cycles. Historical examples illustrate that endorsements and strategic choices have influenced the outcomes of elections. For instance, John F. Kennedy's selection of Lyndon B. Johnson as his running mate in 1960 is often cited as a pivotal decision that helped secure a crucial region of the country, contributing to Kennedy's electoral college victory despite a close popular vote \[[2](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/02/157784723/5-vice-presidential-picks-who-were-key-to-victory#:~:text=1960%3A%20John%20Kennedy-Lyndon%20Johnson%20%28D%29%20%20Without%20a%20doubt%2C%20No)\]\[[5](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/02/157784723/5-vice-presidential-picks-who-were-key-to-victory#:~:text=%201)\]\[[7](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/02/157784723/5-vice-presidential-picks-who-were-key-to-victory#:~:text=Most%20analysts%20argue%20that%20in%20naming%20Lyndon%20Johnson%2C%20his%20chief%20rival%2C%20as%20his%20VP%20in%201960%2C%20John%20Kennedy%20went%20on%20to%20carry%20a%20region%20of%20the%20country%20that%20he%20may%20not%20have%20gotten%20with%20a%20non-Southern%20running%20mate%20%E2%80%94%20a%20decision%20that%20gave%20Kennedy%20a%20huge%20electoral%20college%20victory%20that%20year%2C%20even%20if%20the%20popular%20vote%20was%20incredibly%20close)\]. This decision was influenced by Johnson's political clout and regional appeal, demonstrating how endorsements and strategic alliances can be decisive.

However, the impact of vice-presidential picks is not universally agreed upon. Some analysts argue that the influence of vice-presidential candidates is often overrated. For example, while Al Gore's selection as Bill Clinton's running mate in 1992 is credited with helping to carry Tennessee, other analyses suggest that vice-presidential candidates generally do not significantly boost the ticket's performance in their home states \[[9](https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/post/the-vice-presidential-pick-is-overrated-heres-why/2012/08/09/ac6942b8-e23d-11e1-a25e-15067bb31849_blog.html#:~:text=%E2%80%9CWith%20communications%20reaching%20everywhere%20for%20the%20last%20few%20decades%2C%20the%20race%20is%20about%20the%20presidency%2C%20not%20the%20vice-presidency)\]\[[10](https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/04/election-2016-vice-president-selection-matters-less-than-you-think-213805/#:~:text=Do%20they%20vote%20for%20a%20different%20party%3F%20Are%20they%20more%20likely%20to%20vote%20at%20all%2C%20and%20to%20become%20engaged%20in%20the%20campaign%3F%20%20Our%20conclusion%3A%20While%20presidential%20candidates%20typically%20enjoy%20a%20home-state%20advantage%20%28approximately%203%20points%20to%207%20points%29%2C%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20do%20not)\]. This mixed evidence indicates that while endorsements and strategic considerations can influence the selection process, their impact on election outcomes may vary.

In summary, political endorsements and strategic considerations have historically influenced vice-presidential selections, particularly in competitive election cycles, but their overall impact on election outcomes can be inconsistent.
## Q7: How often have prediction markets accurately forecasted the vice-presidential nominees in past U.S. elections?
Answer:
Prediction markets have shown varying degrees of accuracy in forecasting vice-presidential nominees in past U.S. elections. While these markets often outperform traditional polls in predicting election outcomes, they are not without limitations. For instance, there is evidence that candidates and their supporters might bet on themselves to inflate their appearance, which can skew results. This was observed during the Obama vs. Romney election \[[1](https://pages.stat.wisc.edu/~karlrohe/electabilityArticle.html#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20candidates%20and%20their%20supporters%20might%20be%20betting%20on%20themselves%20in%20order%20to%20inflate%20their%20appearance)\]\[[10](https://pages.stat.wisc.edu/~karlrohe/electabilityArticle.html#:~:text=There%20are%20several%20reasons%20to%20be%20concerned%20about%20the%20validity%20of%20these%20markets)\]. 

However, specific instances of prediction market performance, such as PredictIt's market for the 2016 Democratic VP nominee, show that these markets can be quite active and influential. For example, the market for the Democratic vice-presidential nominee in 2016 saw over one million shares traded in a single day, indicating high engagement and potentially high predictive power \[[4](https://analysis.predictit.org/tagged/vice%20president#:~:text=PI%20Stat%20of%20the%20Week%3A%20After%20the%20Democratic%20vice%20presidential%20nominee%20market%20broke%201%20million%20shares%20traded%20in%20one%20day%20this%20week%2C%20we%20wanted%20to%20know%20how%20often%20that%E2%80%99s%20happened%20since%20PredictIt%20started%20in%202014)\]. Despite these instances, the overall accuracy rate of prediction markets for vice-presidential picks is not well-documented, making it difficult to provide a precise historical accuracy rate. 

In summary, while prediction markets have demonstrated higher predictive power than traditional polls in some cases, their accuracy in forecasting vice-presidential nominees specifically is less clear and can be influenced by market manipulation \[[1](https://pages.stat.wisc.edu/~karlrohe/electabilityArticle.html#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20candidates%20and%20their%20supporters%20might%20be%20betting%20on%20themselves%20in%20order%20to%20inflate%20their%20appearance)\]\[[10](https://pages.stat.wisc.edu/~karlrohe/electabilityArticle.html#:~:text=There%20are%20several%20reasons%20to%20be%20concerned%20about%20the%20validity%20of%20these%20markets)\].

question.question_text: Will the opposition candidate, Edmundo González, concede the 2024 Venezuelan election to Maduro before September 2024?
question.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as "Yes" if, before September 1, 2024, Edmundo González publicly concedes the election to Nicolás Maduro, acknowledging Maduro's victory. The concession must be reported by credible sources. If González does not concede before September 2024, the question will resolve as "No".
question.fine_print:
- A concession by González must be explicit and unambiguous. Statements that only imply a concession or acknowledge Maduro's de facto control without formally conceding will not count.

- If González is arrested, disappears, or is otherwise prevented from making a public statement, the question will resolve as "No" unless he manages to concede the election through other means (e.g., a statement released by his representatives or family).
question.background_info: In Venezuela's disputed presidential election on July 28, 2024, incumbent Nicolás Maduro was [declared](https://apnews.com/article/venezuela-presidential-election-maduro-machado-edmundo-5ce255ae90614162590bfe1207d2e1d0) the winner with 51.2% of the vote, while opposition candidate Edmundo González allegedly received 44.2%. The election was marred by [irregularities](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/28/world/americas/venezuela-election-results.html), with the opposition and international observers questioning the results. González, a stand-in for popular opposition leader María Corina Machado who was barred from running, has not yet conceded the election to Maduro.

# SUMMARY
*Question*: Will the opposition candidate, Edmundo González, concede the 2024 Venezuelan election to Maduro before September 2024?

*Final Prediction*: 19.0%

*Total Cost*: $1.02

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 19.0%] Chose a base rate of 39% based on the typical rate of a question resolving positively. Adjusted down due to González's public denouncement of the election results, Maduro's control over the electoral authority, and historical precedent in Venezuela.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 31.0%] Chose a base rate of 39% based on the typical rate of a question resolving positively. Adjusted down due to González's strong public stance against the election results and Maduro's suppression of opposition.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 10.0%] Chose a base rate of 20% based on the historical rate of opposition candidates conceding in elections where the ruling party controls the electoral authority. Adjusted down due to González's public denouncement and Maduro's control over the electoral process.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 15.0%] Chose a base rate of 20% based on the historical rate of opposition candidates conceding in elections where the ruling party controls the electoral authority. Adjusted down due to González's public denouncement and Maduro's suppression of opposition.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 20.0%] Chose a base rate of 20% based on the historical rate of opposition candidates conceding in elections where the ruling party controls the electoral authority. Adjusted down due to González's public denouncement and Maduro's control over the electoral process.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on the likelihood of Edmundo González conceding the 2024 Venezuelan election to Nicolás Maduro before September 2024. González has publicly denounced the election results as fraudulent, supported by partial election results and independent exit polls suggesting he won by a significant margin. International pressure, including from the U.S. and the European Union, has called for transparency and an independent review of the results. ## Q0: What has Edmundo González publicly stated about the election results since they were announced?
Answer:
Edmundo González has publicly denounced the election results as fraudulent. According to The Times, González and the opposition parties swiftly denounced Nicolás Maduro's declared victory, which was announced by the national electoral authority controlled by the ruling socialist regime \[[2](https://www.thetimes.com/world/latin-america/article/opponents-claim-fraud-as-nicolas-maduro-wins-venezuelan-election-v03h3tjrd?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Twitter#Echobox=1722234693#:~:text=Nicol%C3%A1s%20Maduro%20has%20been%20declared%20the%20winner%20of%20Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20presidential%20election%2C%20in%20a%20move%20which%20was%20swiftly%20denounced%20as%20a%20fraud%20by%20opposition%20parties)\]. Additionally, partial election results provided by researchers associated with Venezuela’s main opposition alliance suggest that González actually won by more than 30 percentage points, a claim supported by an independent exit poll \[[7](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/world/americas/venezuela-maduro-election-results.html#:~:text=But%20partial%20election%20results%2C%20provided%20to%20The%20New%20York%20Times%20by%20a%20group%20of%20researchers%20associated%20with%20Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20main%20opposition%20alliance%2C%20supply%20new%20evidence%20that%20calls%20the%20official%20result%20into%20question)\]\[[12](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/world/americas/venezuela-maduro-election-results.html#:~:text=Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20electoral%20body%20announced%20on%20Monday%20that%20the%20country%E2%80%99s%20president%2C%20Nicol%C3%A1s%20Maduro%2C%20comfortably%20won%20another%20six%20years%20in%20office%2C%20beating%20his%20main%20opponent%20by%20seven%20percentage%20points%20in%20a%20vote%20that%20was%20marred%20by%20widespread%20irregularities)\]. This evidence has led to significant international pressure for an independent review of the results, with the U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken stating that there is "overwhelming evidence" that González won the most votes \[[11](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/08/01/venezuela-election-maduro-us/#:~:text=%E2%80%9CGiven%20the%20overwhelming%20evidence%2C%20it%20is%20clear%20to%20the%20United%20States%20and%2C%20most%20importantly%2C%20to%20the%20Venezuelan%20people%20that%20Edmundo%20Gonz%C3%A1lez%20Urrutia%20won%20the%20most%20votes%20in%20Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20July%2028%20presidential%20election%2C%E2%80%9D%20Secretary%20of%20State%20Antony%20Blinken%20said%20in%20a%20statement%20Thursday%20evening)\].
## Q1: Have any credible sources reported on Edmundo González's likelihood of conceding?
Answer:
### Answer

Yes, credible sources have reported on Edmundo González's likelihood of conceding the 2024 Venezuelan election to Nicolás Maduro. According to a report by The New York Times, partial election results provided by researchers associated with Venezuela’s main opposition alliance suggest that Edmundo González actually beat Nicolás Maduro by more than 30 percentage points, with an estimated result of 66 percent to 31 percent. This is similar to the result obtained by an independent exit poll conducted on Election Day across the country. However, it was not possible for The Times to independently verify the underlying tallies, which were collected from paper receipts produced by about 1,000 voting machines, representing about three percent of the country’s total \[[6](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/world/americas/venezuela-maduro-election-results.html#:~:text=Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20electoral%20body%20announced%20on%20Monday%20that%20the%20country%E2%80%99s%20president%2C%20Nicol%C3%A1s%20Maduro%2C%20comfortably%20won%20another%20six%20years%20in%20office%2C%20beating%20his%20main%20opponent%20by%20seven%20percentage%20points%20in%20a%20vote%20that%20was%20marred%20by%20widespread%20irregularities)\]\[[7](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/world/americas/venezuela-maduro-election-results.html#:~:text=But%20partial%20election%20results%2C%20provided%20to%20The%20New%20York%20Times%20by%20a%20group%20of%20researchers%20associated%20with%20Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20main%20opposition%20alliance%2C%20supply%20new%20evidence%20that%20calls%20the%20official%20result%20into%20question)\].

Additionally, Al Jazeera reported that the opposition will dispute the official results, which declared Maduro the winner with 51 percent of the vote against 44 percent for González. The opposition aims to demonstrate through their tallies that the results presented by the electoral council, controlled by an ally of Maduro, are false \[[9](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/7/29/venezuela-election-results-live-maduro-gonzalez-presidential-race#:~:text=%20%20%20%20%20%E2%80%98It%20seems%20Maduro%20will%20be%20able%20to%20remain%20in%20power%E2%80%99%20%20There%20is%20no%20doubt%20these%20results%20will%20come%20as%20a%20huge%20disappointment%20for%20the%20millions%20of%20Venezuelans%20who%20came%20out%20to%20vote%20hoping%20for%20a%20change%20in%20the%20political%20situation%20after%2025%20years%20of%20the%20socialist%20party%20in%20power)\]\[[10](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/7/29/venezuela-election-results-live-maduro-gonzalez-presidential-race#:~:text=%20Opposition%20leader%20Maria%20Corina%20Machado%2C%20left%2C%20with%20presidential%20candidate%20Edmundo%20Gonzalez%20%5BFederico%20Parra/AFP%5D%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%E2%80%98It%20seems%20Maduro%20will%20be%20able%20to%20remain%20in%20power%E2%80%99%20%20There%20is%20no%20doubt%20these%20results%20will%20come%20as%20a%20huge%20disappointment%20for%20the%20millions%20of%20Venezuelans%20who%20came%20out%20to%20vote%20hoping%20for%20a%20change%20in%20the%20political%20situation%20after%2025%20years%20of%20the%20socialist%20party%20in%20power)\]. This indicates a strong likelihood that González will not concede easily, given the significant discrepancies and the opposition's intent to challenge the results.
## Q2: What actions or statements have Nicolás Maduro and his administration made regarding the election results and opposition?
Answer:
Nicolás Maduro and his administration have taken several actions and made various statements regarding the 2024 Venezuelan election results and the opposition. Maduro was declared the winner with 51% of the vote against Edmundo González's 44%, but the results have been widely disputed by the opposition and international observers. The National Electoral Council, controlled by Maduro loyalists, delayed the announcement of the results and has not released the tallies from all polling booths, hampering the opposition's ability to challenge the results \[[11](https://www.koco.com/article/nicolas-maduro-venezuela-presidential-election/61722313?utm_campaign=snd-autopilot#:~:text=Maduro%20was%20declared%20the%20winner%20in%20Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20presidential%20election%20Sunday%2C%20even%20as%20his%20opponents%20were%20preparing%20to%20dispute%20the%20results%2C%20setting%20up%20a%20high-stakes%20showdown%20that%20will%20determine%20whether%20the%20South%20American%20nation%20transitions%20away%20from%20one%20party%20rule)\]\[[12](https://www.koco.com/article/nicolas-maduro-venezuela-presidential-election/61722313?utm_campaign=snd-autopilot#:~:text=The%20National%20Electoral%20Council%2C%20which%20is%20controlled%20by%20Maduro%20loyalists%2C%20has%20yet%20to%20provide%20the%20tallies%20from%20the%20nation%27s%2030%2C000%20polling%20booths)\]. 

Maduro has accused foreign enemies of attempting to hack the voting system and has promised "justice" for those who try to stir violence in Venezuela, though he provided no evidence for these claims \[[9](https://apnews.com/article/venezuela-presidential-election-maduro-machado-edmundo-5ce255ae90614162590bfe1207d2e1d0#:~:text=The%20delay%20in%20announcing%20results%20%E2%80%94%20six%20hours%20after%20polls%20were%20supposed%20to%20close%20%E2%80%94%20indicated%20a%20deep%20debate%20inside%20the%20government%20about%20how%20to%20proceed%20after%20Maduro%E2%80%99s%20opponents%20came%20out%20early%20in%20the%20evening%20all%20but%20claiming%20victory)\]\[[13](https://apnews.com/article/venezuela-presidential-election-maduro-machado-edmundo-5ce255ae90614162590bfe1207d2e1d0#:~:text=%E2%80%9CWe%20won%E2%80%99t%20recognize%20any%20result%20that%20is%20not%20verifiable)\]. In response to international criticism, Venezuelan authorities have suspended flights to and from several countries, and Maduro has vowed that González will "never, ever" be able to take power \[[4](https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/aug/01/venezuela-election-results-nicolas-maduro-protests-gonzalez-machado#:~:text=According%20to%20government%20figures%2C%20more%20than%201%2C000%20people%20have%20been%20detained%20during%20the%20post-election%20crackdown)\]\[[10](https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/aug/01/venezuela-election-results-nicolas-maduro-protests-gonzalez-machado#:~:text=Flights%20to%20and%20from%20Panama%2C%20the%20Dominican%20Republic%20and%20Peru%20have%20all%20now%20been%20suspended%20by%20Venezuelan%20authorities%20in%20response%20to%20criticism%20of%20the%20election%20from%20the%20governments%20of%20those%20countries)\]. The opposition, led by González, plans to dispute the results, claiming that the electoral council's figures are false and controlled by Maduro's allies \[[3](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/7/29/venezuela-election-results-live-maduro-gonzalez-presidential-race?taid=66a71747fa586c000174abe7&utm_campaign=trueAnthem%3A+Trending+Content&utm_medium=trueAnthem&utm_source=twitter#:~:text=%20%20%20%20%20%E2%80%98It%20seems%20Maduro%20will%20be%20able%20to%20remain%20in%20power%E2%80%99%20%20There%20is%20no%20doubt%20these%20results%20will%20come%20as%20a%20huge%20disappointment%20for%20the%20millions%20of%20Venezuelans%20who%20came%20out%20to%20vote%20hoping%20for%20a%20change%20in%20the%20political%20situation%20after%2025%20years%20of%20the%20socialist%20party%20in%20power)\]\[[5](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/7/29/venezuela-election-results-live-maduro-gonzalez-presidential-race?taid=66a71747fa586c000174abe7&utm_campaign=trueAnthem%3A+Trending+Content&utm_medium=trueAnthem&utm_source=twitter#:~:text=%20Opposition%20leader%20Maria%20Corina%20Machado%2C%20left%2C%20with%20presidential%20candidate%20Edmundo%20Gonzalez%20%5BFederico%20Parra/AFP%5D%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%E2%80%98It%20seems%20Maduro%20will%20be%20able%20to%20remain%20in%20power%E2%80%99%20%20There%20is%20no%20doubt%20these%20results%20will%20come%20as%20a%20huge%20disappointment%20for%20the%20millions%20of%20Venezuelans%20who%20came%20out%20to%20vote%20hoping%20for%20a%20change%20in%20the%20political%20situation%20after%2025%20years%20of%20the%20socialist%20party%20in%20power)\].
## Q3: Are there any reports of international pressure or mediation efforts urging González to concede?
Answer:
There are indeed reports of international pressure and mediation efforts urging Edmundo González to concede the 2024 Venezuelan election to Nicolás Maduro. Key points include:

- **International Pressure**: The U.S., European Union, and leftist allies from Brazil, Colombia, and Mexico have all called for the release of full vote tallies and have expressed doubts about the credibility of the election results \[[4](https://apnews.com/article/venezuela-election-maduro-electoral-official-aa924123016cf41d69b8fdaa4eca0857#:~:text=Delpino%2C%20an%20electoral%20expert%20close%20to%20one%20of%20Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20traditional%20opposition%20parties%2C%20was%20named%20to%20the%20CNE%20by%20the%20National%20Assembly%20controlled%20by%20Maduro%E2%80%99s%20allies%20last%20year%20after%20several%20predecessors%20were%20removed)\]\[[7](https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelas-machado-says-peaceful-protests-external-pressure-could-still-oust-2024-08-27/#:~:text=%22%20Venezuela%27s%20national%20electoral%20authority%20and%20its%20top%20court%20named%20Maduro%20the%20election%27s%20victor%2C%20saying%20he%20won%20just%20over%20half%20of%20votes%20in%20the%20election)\]. Additionally, the United Nations and other international bodies have also questioned the legitimacy of the election and called for transparency \[[7](https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelas-machado-says-peaceful-protests-external-pressure-could-still-oust-2024-08-27/#:~:text=%22%20Venezuela%27s%20national%20electoral%20authority%20and%20its%20top%20court%20named%20Maduro%20the%20election%27s%20victor%2C%20saying%20he%20won%20just%20over%20half%20of%20votes%20in%20the%20election)\]\[[15](https://ca.news.yahoo.com/venezuela-order-opposition-leader-testify-192753007.html#:~:text=It%27s%20the%20latest%20attempt%20by%20Nicolas%20Maduro%27s%20government%20to%20crack%20down%20on%20opponents%20who%20claim%20they%20handily%20defeated%20the%20self-declared%20socialist%20leader)\].

- **Mediation Efforts**: There have been efforts from the international community, including the United States, Colombia, and Brazil, to convince Maduro's government to publish evidence of his claim to victory and recognize the actual result of the vote. These efforts also include calls for a power transition if the tally shows a loss for Maduro \[[11](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/22/world/americas/venezuela-supreme-court-maduro-election.html#:~:text=The%20decision%20by%20the%20Supreme%20Tribunal%20of%20Justice%20asserted%20that%20Mr)\]\[[14](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/22/world/americas/venezuela-supreme-court-maduro-election.html#:~:text=His%20new%20term%20is%20scheduled%20to%20begin%20in%20January%20and%20run%20through%202031)\].

These international pressures and mediation efforts are significant as they reflect a broad consensus questioning the legitimacy of the election and urging for transparency and potential concession from González. This context could influence the likelihood of González conceding under international pressure.

## Q1: In previous Venezuelan elections, how often have opposition candidates conceded after alleging fraud?
Answer:
In previous Venezuelan elections, opposition candidates have frequently alleged fraud and have often refused to concede. For instance, in the 2013 presidential election, opposition candidate Henrique Capriles initially demanded a full recount of the paper receipts before accepting the results. This led to a protracted debate over the nature of the audit demanded by the opposition, and Capriles eventually accepted the expanded audit announced by the National Electoral Council (CNE) \[[5](https://www.cartercenter.org/resources/pdfs/news/peace_publications/election_reports/venezuela-final-rpt-2013-elections.pdf#:~:text=On%20April%2014%2C%202013%2C%20after%20an%20extraordinary%20interlude%20with%20the%20illness%20and%20passing%20of%20President%20Hugo%20Ch%C3%A1vez%2C%20Venezuelans%20turned%20out%20in%20great%20numbers%20to%20vote%20in%20special%20elections%20for%20a%20new%20president%20to%20fulfill%20Ch%C3%A1vez%27s%20six-year%20term)\]. However, Capriles also claimed that his witnesses were forcibly ejected from nearly 300 voting centers, although no independent reports confirmed this \[[1](https://venezuelanalysis.com/news/8665#:~:text=The%20nature%20of%20Venezuela%E2%80%99s%20electoral%20system%20makes%20the%20kind%20of%20fraud%20alleged%20by%20Capriles%20nearly%20impossible)\]\[[2](https://venezuelanalysis.com/news/8665#:~:text=The%20paper%20receipts%20that%20each%20voter%20deposits%20in%20a%20sealed%20box%20are%20counted%20to%20assure%20that%20they%20line%20up%20with%20the%20tally%20from%20the%20voting%20machines%2C%20and%20all%20witnesses%20sign%20the%20tallies%20to%20certify%20that%20they%20witnessed%20the%20audit)\].

In the 2018 presidential election, the majority of the Venezuelan political opposition decided not to participate, considering the election illegitimate. The main opposition candidate declared that he would not recognize the electoral result on election day \[[10](https://www.electoralintegrityproject.com/eip-blog/2018/5/30/rigged-elections-venezuelas-failed-presidential-election#:~:text=This%20is%20an%20example%20of%20a%20contentious%20election)\]. This pattern of alleging fraud and refusing to concede has been a recurring theme in Venezuelan elections, reflecting deep-seated mistrust in the electoral process among opposition candidates.
## Q2: How frequently do international pressures lead to concessions in disputed elections in Latin American countries?
Answer:
International pressures have played a significant role in influencing the outcomes of disputed elections in Latin American countries. One notable example is the 1990 Nicaraguan election, which was heavily influenced by international observers and foreign intervention. The presence of international observers and extensive preliminary negotiations were crucial in setting the ground rules and ensuring a peaceful transition of power, which ultimately led to the end of the contra war \[[1](https://lasaweb.org/uploads/reports/electoraldemocracyinternationalpressure.pdf#:~:text=Nicaragua%20conducted%20elections%2C%20on%20February%2025%2C%201990%2C%20that%20were%20possibly%20more%20important%20for%20the%20future%20of%20Central%20America%20than%20any%20other%20elections%20in%20the%20region%E2%80%99s%20history)\]\[[4](https://lasaweb.org/uploads/reports/electoraldemocracyinternationalpressure.pdf#:~:text=war%20and%20the%20elections%20have%20provided%20an%20opportunity%20for%20Nicaraguans%20of%20all%20persuasions%20to%20participate%20in%20a%20critical%20decision%20about%20the%20future%20of%20their%20country)\]\[[7](https://lasaweb.org/uploads/reports/electoraldemocracyinternationalpressure.pdf#:~:text=peaceful%20change%20of%20government%20with%20a%20military%20institution%20under%20civilian%20control)\]. This case highlights how international pressure can lead to concessions and significant political changes.

Additionally, organizations like the International Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES) and the United Nations have been instrumental in promoting transparency and accountability in electoral processes across Latin America. IFES has supported various electoral bodies and civil society organizations to enhance democratic institutions and increase civic engagement \[[5](https://www.ifes.org/latin-america-caribbean#:~:text=The%20International%20Foundation%20for%20Electoral%20Systems%20%28IFES%29%20has%20been%20supporting%20elections%20and%20good%20governance%20in%20Latin%20America%20and%20Caribbean%20region%20since%20its%20founding%20in%201987)\]. The United Nations has also provided technical assistance and observed elections to ensure their credibility and legitimacy \[[6](https://dppa.un.org/en/elections#:~:text=Download%20the%20latest%20report%20of%20the%20Secretary-General%20on%20%27Strengthening%20the%20role%20of%20the%20United%20Nations%20in%20enhancing%20the%20effectiveness%20of%20the%20principle%20of%20periodic%20and%20genuine%20elections%20and%20the%20promotion%20of%20democratization%22%20%28A/76/266%29%20The%20history%20of%20the%20United%20Nations%20is%20interwoven%20with%20elections)\]\[[12](https://dppa.un.org/en/elections#:~:text=Elections%20are%20a%20vital%20part%20of%20democratic%20processes%2C%20including%20political%20transitions%2C%20implementation%20of%20peace%20agreements%20and%20consolidation%20of%20democracy)\]. These efforts demonstrate that international pressure and support can significantly impact the outcomes of disputed elections, often leading to concessions and the strengthening of democratic processes.
