## Q5: How often have vice-presidential candidates been selected based on their ability to address a perceived weakness or controversy facing the presidential nominee?
Answer:
Vice-presidential candidates have often been selected to address perceived weaknesses or controversies facing the presidential nominee. Historically, this strategy has been employed to balance the ticket in terms of geography, ideology, or experience. For example, John F. Kennedy selected Lyndon B. Johnson to appeal to Southern voters and to balance his own perceived inexperience with Johnson's extensive political background \[[6](https://www.school-for-champions.com/history/how_lyndon_johnson_vetted_humphrey.htm#:~:text=The%20selection%20process%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Vice%20President%20follows%20different%20courses)\]. Similarly, vice-presidential picks have been used to address controversies or bolster areas where the presidential candidate is seen as lacking. This practice has become more pronounced in the last forty years, as the selection process has evolved to be more strategic and scrutinized \[[1](https://www.neh.gov/humanities/2015/januaryfebruary/iq/impertinent-questions-jules-witcover#:~:text=Presidential%20succession%20is%20the%20first%20and%20arguably%20the%20most%20important%20decision%20facing%20a%20presidential%20nominee)\].

In summary, the selection of vice-presidential candidates to address specific weaknesses or controversies of the presidential nominee is a well-documented strategy, particularly in recent decades. This approach aims to create a more balanced and appealing ticket to voters.
## Q6: What is the historical success rate of vice-presidential nominees who were chosen to appeal to a specific demographic or regional voter base in U.S. elections?
Answer:
The historical success rate of vice-presidential nominees chosen to appeal to a specific demographic or regional voter base in U.S. elections is generally low. According to a detailed analysis by FiveThirtyEight, the "home-state effect" of vice-presidential nominees is often overrated. Since 1920, major-party presidential nominees have carried their running mate’s home state 65% of the time, and this figure rises slightly to 72% in elections since World War II. However, this statistic is not particularly revealing or impactful in determining overall election success \[[4](https://archive.nytimes.com/fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/the-overrated-vice-presidential-home-state-effect/#:~:text=for%20the%20Democratic%20nominee%20for%20vice%20president%20in%201992%2C%20Al%20Gore%2C%20the%20comparison%20years%20are%201988%20%28when%20Mr)\]\[[13](https://archive.nytimes.com/fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/the-overrated-vice-presidential-home-state-effect/#:~:text=than%2C%20say%2C%20Susana%20Martinez%2C%20the%20governor%20of%20New%20Mexico)\].

Moreover, the broader historical context shows that vice-presidential candidates, regardless of their appeal to specific demographics or regions, have not significantly altered the outcomes of presidential elections. For instance, a Pew Research analysis of vice-presidential candidates since 1868 found that most nominees had substantial political experience, but this did not necessarily translate into electoral success \[[5](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/10/what-kind-of-person-runs-for-vice-president/#:~:text=Presidential%20candidates%20get%20a%20lot%20of%20public%20scrutiny%20during%20the%20United%20States%E2%80%99%20extended%20nominating%20process%2C%20but%20like%20dandelions%20or%20mushrooms%20after%20a%20spring%20shower%2C%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20seem%20to%20pop%20up%20suddenly%20in%20the%20political%20chatter%20once%20a%20party%20settles%20on%20a%20presidential%20nominee)\].

In summary, while vice-presidential nominees may provide some marginal benefit in their home states, their overall impact on the election outcome is limited. This suggests that choosing a vice-presidential candidate primarily to appeal to a specific demographic or regional voter base has not historically been a highly successful strategy.
## Q7: How frequently have vice-presidential nominees been chosen from the pool of the presidential nominee's primary rivals in the past 60 years?
Answer:
In the past 60 years, vice-presidential nominees have occasionally been chosen from the pool of the presidential nominee's primary rivals, but it is not a common practice. Notable examples include:

- **Lyndon B. Johnson** was chosen as John F. Kennedy's running mate in 1960 after being a primary rival.
- **George H.W. Bush** was selected by Ronald Reagan in 1980 after competing against him in the primaries.

However, many vice-presidential picks have not been primary rivals. For instance, **Thomas Eagleton** was not George McGovern’s first pick in 1972, and McGovern had to turn to less prominent candidates after several refusals \[[6](https://www.historytoday.com/five-worst-vice-presidential-picks#:~:text=Senator%20Tom%20Eagleton%20was%20not%20George%20McGovern%E2%80%99s%20first%20pick%20for%20vice%20president)\]. Similarly, **Sarah Palin** was chosen by John McCain in 2008 without being a primary rival \[[5](https://www.historytoday.com/five-worst-vice-presidential-picks#:~:text=%20Sarah%20Palin%2C%20VP%20Candidate%20for%20John%20McCain%20%282008%29%20%20%20On%20paper%2C%20John%20McCain%20had%20a%20great%20chance%20in%20the%202008%20election)\].

Overall, while there are instances of primary rivals being selected, it is not the predominant trend in vice-presidential selections over the past six decades.

question.question_text: Who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day? (Chris Christie)
question.resolution_criteria: The sub-question for the individual named as the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president of the United States as of November 5, 2024 (election day) shall resolve as **Yes**. All other sub-questions will resolve as **No**.
question.background_info:
The [vice president of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States) is the second-highest officer in the executive branch of the U.S. federal government, after the president of the United States, ranks first in the presidential line of succession, and is indirectly elected together with the president to a four-year term of office by the people of the United States through the Electoral College.

As of August 2023, although Donald Trump is the frontrunner for the Republican Party's nomination for president in 2024, there is [much speculation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection#Media_speculation_about_possible_running_mates) about who the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president will be, with dozens of individuals considered plausible candidates.

An additional complication in the 2024 cycle is that Donald Trump is, as of August 2023, the subject of four [active criminal cases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trial_of_Donald_Trump), one or more of which may go to trial before, during, or after the Republican primaries, making this an especially turbulent and uncertain election cycle, with the potential for late changes to the party's ticket before election day.

- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 18.0%] Chose a base rate of 33% based on historical odds. Adjusted down due to anti-Trump stance, low favorability, and Trump's exclusion, with minor upward adjustment for Christie's experience and bipartisan appeal.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on evaluating Chris Christie's chances of becoming the 2024 Republican vice-presidential nominee. Analysts and commentators are skeptical about Christie's chances due to his anti-Trump stance and diminished popularity within the Republican base. Recent polling data indicates that Christie's support levels are quite low, and Donald Trump has explicitly stated that he does not see Christie as a viable option for vice president. Additionally, there is no direct information from prediction markets or community predictions supporting Christie's chances [S1.Q1, S1.Q5, S1.Q4].

Historically, the odds of a former presidential candidate becoming a vice-presidential nominee are relatively low, approximately one-third. The Republican Party has occasionally selected vice-presidential candidates who were not among the top contenders in the presidential primary, but this is not common. Anti-establishment candidates and those with prior public conflicts with the top presidential candidate are rarely chosen. However, candidates with significant executive experience, such as former governors, and those with bipartisan appeal have been selected in the past [S2.Q0, S2.Q1, S2.Q2, S2.Q3, S2.Q4, S2.Q5].

- The historical odds of a former presidential candidate becoming a vice-presidential nominee in subsequent elections are relatively low, approximately 33% [S2.Q0]
- The success rate of vice-presidential nominees who were considered unlikely choices in the initial stages of the election cycle is relatively low [S2.Q7]

## Pros
- Chris Christie has significant executive experience as a former governor of New Jersey [S1.Q5]
- Christie has been mentioned in discussions for other high-profile roles, indicating he is still considered a viable candidate for significant positions [S1.Q1]
- Christie is a known figure with bipartisan appeal, having worked with both Democrats and Republicans during his tenure as governor [S2.Q4]

## Cons

# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What is the latest news about potential vice-presidential candidates for the 2024 Republican ticket?
Answer:
The latest news about potential vice-presidential candidates for the 2024 Republican ticket includes discussions around J.D. Vance and his potential impact on the GOP's chances. Frank Luntz, a renowned pollster, mentioned that Vance appeals to a part of the electorate that former President Trump needs, suggesting that Trump might double down on Vance as his running mate \[[3](https://conservativebrief.com/noted-trump-84711/?utm_source=CB&utm_medium=DJD#:~:text=Some%20critics%20have%20said%20that%20Trump%20should%20consider%20changing%20his%20choice%20for%20vice%20president%2C%20but%20Frank%20Luntz%2C%20a%20renowned%20pollster%20who%20has%20been%20anti-Trump%2C%20said%20that%20is%20not%20the%20case)\]. However, Vance's popularity is faltering in the Midwest, a critical region for the GOP, with a minus-5-point favorability rating after the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee \[[14](https://www.yahoo.com/news/jd-vance-faltering-midwest-big-214455981.html#:~:text=For%20Republicans%20banking%20on%20Vance%20to%20boost%20the%20party%20across%20the%20Midwest%2C%20his%20standing%20is%20far%20below%20where%20he%27ll%20need%20to%20be%20to%20win%20over%20swing%20voters%20in%20key%20states%20such%20as%20Michigan%20and%20Wisconsin)\]. This could be a significant factor for forecasters to consider, as Vance's unpopularity in key swing states like Michigan and Wisconsin might affect the overall ticket's performance.

Additionally, Peter Thiel, a prominent Silicon Valley figure and former employer of Vance, expressed hope that a second Trump term would be better with Vance as the running mate, despite earlier misgivings \[[12](https://conservativebrief.com/noted-trump-84711/?utm_source=CB&utm_medium=DJD#:~:text=Vance%20%28R-Ohio%29%20as%20his%20running%20mate)\]. This endorsement from influential backers could play a role in solidifying Vance's position as a potential vice-presidential candidate.
## Q1: What have major political analysts and commentators said about Chris Christie's chances of becoming the vice-presidential nominee?
Answer:
Major political analysts and commentators have expressed skepticism about Chris Christie's chances of becoming the 2024 Republican vice-presidential nominee. Christie's candidacy for president in 2024 is seen as a long shot, with his political star having significantly dimmed since his peak popularity in 2012. Analysts note that his anti-Trump stance has alienated a substantial portion of the Republican base, which remains largely loyal to former President Donald Trump \[[4](https://themessenger.com/politics/chris-christies-democratic-successor-dont-underestimate-him-in-2024#:~:text=%22%20Christie%20is%20expected%20to%20officially%20announce%20his%20candidacy%20next%20week)\]\[[5](https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/chris-christie-2024-republican-primary/#:~:text=Chris%20Christie%201%20%20announced%20he%20was%20running%20for%20president)\]. 

Furthermore, Christie's potential role in a future administration is more often discussed in the context of a cabinet position, such as Attorney General, rather than as a vice-presidential candidate. For instance, if Ron DeSantis were to secure the Republican nomination, Christie's name has been floated for the Attorney General position due to his strong record as a U.S. Attorney \[[15](https://www.insidernj.com/chris-christie-attorney-general-in-a-desantis-presidential-administration/?utm_campaign=shareaholic&utm_medium=twitter&utm_source=socialnetwork#:~:text=A%20significant%20DeSantis%20victory%20in%20the%20March%2019%2C%202024%20Florida%20primary%20would%20give%20him%20a%20decisive%20lead%20for%20the%20nomination)\]. This suggests that while Christie may still have a role to play in Republican politics, it is unlikely to be as the vice-presidential nominee.

## Q4: What statements or hints have key Republican figures, including Donald Trump, given about their potential vice-presidential picks?
Answer:
Former President Donald Trump has hinted that he has already made up his mind about his vice-presidential pick for the 2024 election, although he has not disclosed any specific names. During a town hall in Iowa, Trump stated, "I mean, I know who it's going to be," but his campaign quickly sought to downplay the remark, with a campaign adviser noting that "nothing is finalized" and that Trump will announce his final pick when he is ready \[[1](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-fox-news-town-hall-iowa-vice-president-rcna132691#:~:text=Former%20President%20Donald%20Trump%20indicated%20he%20has%20made%20up%20his%20mind%20about%20whom%20he%20would%20like%20to%20be%20his%20running%20mate%20should%20he%20win%20the%20Republican%20presidential%20nomination)\]\[[11](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-fox-news-town-hall-iowa-vice-president-rcna132691#:~:text=%22I%20mean%2C%20I%20know%20who%20it%27s%20going%20to%20be)\].

Additionally, Trump has expressed a favorable view towards the concept of having a female vice-presidential pick. In an interview, he mentioned that he likes "the concept" of a female VP, which could indicate a potential direction for his choice \[[10](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-likes-concept-female-vp-pick-meet-the-press-interview-rcna105323#:~:text=Check%20local%20listings)\]. However, Trump has explicitly stated that he does not see Chris Christie as a viable option for his vice president, despite having started to "like Christie better" \[[4](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-fox-news-town-hall-iowa-vice-president-rcna132691#:~:text=Chris%20Christie%2C%20who%20dropped%20out%20of%20the%20race%20earlier%20in%20the%20day)\].

These statements suggest that while Trump has a clear idea of his preferred running mate, he is keeping his options open and has not yet made any public commitments. The emphasis on a female VP pick could be a significant factor in his decision-making process.

## Q6: What are the significant developments or updates in Donald Trump's legal cases, and how might these impact his choice of vice-presidential nominee?
Answer:
Significant developments in Donald Trump's legal cases could have a substantial impact on his choice of vice-presidential nominee for the 2024 election. Here are the key points:

1. **January 6th Insurrection Allegations**: Trump faces legal challenges related to his alleged involvement in the January 6th Capitol riot. A Florida attorney has filed a legal challenge claiming Trump cannot be on the 2024 ballot due to his involvement in the "insurrection" \[[1](https://www.thegatewaypundit.com/2023/08/here-we-go-florida-attorney-files-legal-challenge/#:~:text=On%20January%206%2C%202021%2C%20after%20giving%20a%20speech%20to%20a%20throng%20on%20the%20Ellipse%20near%20the%20Capitol%2C%20President%20Trump%20exhorted%20the%20throng%20to%20march%20to%20the%20Capitol%20and%20told%20them%20that%20he%20would%20be%20right%20there%20with%20them)\]. Additionally, New Hampshire’s Republican Secretary of State is seeking legal advice on potentially blocking Trump from the primary ballot based on similar grounds \[[3](https://www.thegatewaypundit.com/2023/08/here-we-go-florida-attorney-files-legal-challenge/#:~:text=On%20Friday%2C%20The%20Gateway%20Pundit%20previously%20reported%20that%20New%20Hampshire%E2%80%99s%20Republican%20Secretary%20of%20State%20David%20Scanlan%20is%20seeking%20legal%20advice%20on%20potentially%20blocking%20Trump%20from%20the%20primary%20ballot)\]. These legal challenges could influence Trump's choice of VP to someone who can help mitigate the political fallout or appeal to a broader base.

2. **E. Jean Carroll Case**: Trump is also dealing with a defamation and sexual abuse lawsuit from E. Jean Carroll. A judge recently denied Trump's request to delay the trial, which is now set to begin on January 16, 2024 \[[5](https://www.cnbc.com/2023/08/18/judge-denies-trump-request-to-delay-e-jean-carroll-trial-.html#:~:text=The%202022%20lawsuit%20went%20to%20trial%20earlier%20this%20year%20and%20a%20jury%20found%20Trump%20liable%20for%20sexually%20abusing%20Carroll%20and%20defaming%20her%2C%20and%20ordered%20him%20to%20pay%20her%20%245%20million)\]\[[7](https://www.cnbc.com/2023/08/18/judge-denies-trump-request-to-delay-e-jean-carroll-trial-.html#:~:text=But%20a%20federal%20holiday%2C%20Martin%20Luther%20King%2C%20Jr)\]. This ongoing legal battle could affect Trump's public image and may lead him to choose a VP nominee who can bolster his credibility and appeal to female voters.

3. **Stormy Daniels Hush Money Case**: Trump is implicated in a case involving a $130,000 payment to adult film actress Stormy Daniels to prevent her from publishing an account of their alleged affair \[[2](https://casetext.com/case/people-v-trump-15#:~:text=%29%20%20%20In%20October%202016%2C%20at%20the%20direction%20of%20his%20Chief%20Executive%20Officer%2C%20the%20Editor-in-Chief%20of%20AMI%20alerted%20Cohen%20that%20Stephanie%20Clifford%2C%20an%20adult%20film%20actress%20known%20as%20Stormy%20Daniels%2C%20was%20seeking%20to%20publish%20an%20account%20of%20her%20sexual%20liaison%20with%20Trump%20during%20Trump%27s%20marriage)\]\[[6](https://casetext.com/case/people-v-trump-15#:~:text=%C2%B6%C2%B6%205-7)\]. This case adds to the legal and ethical controversies surrounding Trump, potentially influencing his VP choice to someone perceived as ethically sound and capable of diverting attention from these scandals.

These legal issues are likely to play a significant role in Trump's strategic decisions, including his selection of a vice-presidential nominee who can help address these challenges and strengthen his campaign.
## Q7: What other high-profile Republican figures are being considered for the vice-presidential nomination, and how do they compare to Chris Christie in terms of likelihood?
Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day? (Chris Christie)," several other high-profile Republican figures are being considered for the vice-presidential nomination. Here are some key contenders and how they compare to Chris Christie in terms of likelihood:

1. **Mike Pence**: The former Vice President has a strong connection to the party’s evangelical base and a reputation for probity and decency, which could appeal to voters looking for a candidate with high moral standards. Pence has consistently stressed religious freedom throughout his political career, making him a favorite among evangelicals \[[10](https://www.sltrib.com/religion/2020/08/24/faith-facts-about-vice/#:~:text=Pence%20has%20stressed%20religious%20freedom%20throughout%20his%20political%20career)\]. However, his polling numbers are in the single digits, and he had to scramble to get into the first Republican presidential debate \[[9](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=His%20polling%20is%20in%20the%20single%20digits)\]. Despite this, some argue that Pence is the best bet to win in 2024 and move past Trump without splitting the party \[[15](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=He%20had%20to%20scramble%20to%20get%20into%20the%20first%20Republican%20presidential%20debate)\].

His policy positions are deeply conservative, and he has vowed to pardon Trump if elected \[[14](https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2023-08-24/vivek-ramaswamy-gop-republican-debate#:~:text=Ramaswamy%20is%20an%20ardent%20supporter%20of%20Trump)\].

3. **Francis Suarez**: The mayor of Miami, who recently dropped out of the presidential race, was the sole Hispanic candidate vying for the party nomination. In comparison to Chris Christie, who has a more moderate stance and a history of bipartisan cooperation, these candidates offer different strengths. Suarez's Hispanic heritage and mayoral experience could also be seen as valuable assets in a vice-presidential candidate.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What are the historical odds of a former presidential candidate becoming a vice-presidential nominee in subsequent elections?
Answer:
The historical odds of a former presidential candidate becoming a vice-presidential nominee in subsequent elections are relatively low. Since 1960, only eight out of 24 first-time vice-presidential candidates had previously run for president, which translates to approximately one-third of the cases \[[1](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20have%20come%20from%20those%20who%20did%20not%20seek%20the%20presidency%20that%20year)\]\[[3](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Occasionally%2C%20the%20running%20mate%20sought%20the%20presidential%20nomination%20previously)\]. Notable examples include Hubert Humphrey (1964), Lloyd Bentsen (1988), Al Gore (1992), Jack Kemp (1996), and Joe Biden (2008) \[[1](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Vice%20presidential%20candidates%20generally%20have%20come%20from%20those%20who%20did%20not%20seek%20the%20presidency%20that%20year)\]\[[3](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-democratic-vice-presidential-derby-look-beyond-the-2020-contenders/#:~:text=Occasionally%2C%20the%20running%20mate%20sought%20the%20presidential%20nomination%20previously)\]. This indicates that while it is not unprecedented, it is not the norm for former presidential candidates to be selected as vice-presidential nominees. 

Given this historical context, the likelihood of Chris Christie, a former presidential candidate, being chosen as the 2024 Republican vice-presidential nominee is statistically less probable but not impossible.
## Q1: How often has the Republican party selected a vice-presidential candidate who was not among the top contenders in the presidential primary?
Answer:
The Republican Party has occasionally selected vice-presidential candidates who were not among the top contenders in the presidential primary. Notable examples include Sarah Palin in 2008 and Spiro Agnew in 1968. 

- **Sarah Palin (2008)**: John McCain selected Sarah Palin, who was relatively unknown on the national stage and not a top contender in the presidential primary. This choice was seen as a gamble and ultimately criticized for lack of thorough vetting \[[7](https://www.historytoday.com/five-worst-vice-presidential-picks#:~:text=%20Sarah%20Palin%2C%20VP%20Candidate%20for%20John%20McCain%20%282008%29%20%20%20On%20paper%2C%20John%20McCain%20had%20a%20great%20chance%20in%20the%202008%20election)\]\[[12](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-eighteen-day-running-mate-mcgovern-eagleton-and-a-campaign-in-crisis-by-joshua-m-glasser/2012/08/04/5a3ff0ac-d35d-11e1-87d8-e4a03a9f16d2_story.html#:~:text=He%20may%20have%20been%20the%20first%20candidate%20almost%20literally%20laughed%20into%20defeat)\].
- **Spiro Agnew (1968)**: Richard Nixon chose Spiro Agnew, who was not a prominent figure in the presidential primary. Agnew's selection was controversial, and he later faced legal issues that led to his resignation \[[13](https://www.historytoday.com/five-worst-vice-presidential-picks#:~:text=%20Spiro%20Agnew%2C%20Vice%20President%20for%20Richard%20Nixon%20%281969-73%29%20%20When%20asked%20why%20he%20would%20keep%20Spiro%20Agnew%20on%20the%20ticket%20for%20his%201972%20re-election%20campaign%2C%20Nixon%20quipped%3A%20%E2%80%98Because%20no%20assassin%20in%20their%20right%20mind%20would%20kill%20me)\].

These instances highlight that while it is not the norm, the Republican Party has a history of selecting vice-presidential candidates who were not leading figures in the presidential primary. This historical context may influence the likelihood of a similar decision in future elections.
## Q2: How frequently have anti-establishment candidates been chosen as vice-presidential nominees in the Republican party?
Answer:
Anti-establishment candidates have occasionally been chosen as vice-presidential nominees in the Republican Party, but it is relatively rare. One notable example is Barry Goldwater, who, although not a vice-presidential nominee, significantly influenced the party's direction towards conservatism in the 1960s. Goldwater's 1964 presidential campaign mobilized a large conservative constituency, marking a shift from the party's more traditional, establishment roots \[[7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_Goldwater#:~:text=In%201964%2C%20Goldwater%20mobilized%20a%20large%20conservative%20constituency%20to%20win%20the%20Republican%20presidential%20primaries)\]\[[11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_Goldwater#:~:text=As%20an%20elder%20statesman%20of%20the%20party%2C%20Goldwater%2C%20who%20was%20respected%20by%20his%20colleagues%20for%20his%20honor%20and%20dedication%20to%20principle%2C%20successfully%20urged%20President%20Richard%20Nixon%20to%20resign%20in%201974%20when%20evidence%20of%20a%20cover-up%20in%20the%20Watergate%20scandal%20became%20overwhelming%20and%20impeachment%20was%20imminent)\]\[[13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_Goldwater#:~:text=Senator%20from%20Arizona%20%281953%E2%80%931965%2C%201969%E2%80%931987%29%20and%20the%20Republican%20Party%20nominee%20for%20president%20of%20the%20United%20States%20in%201964)\]. However, this did not translate into a long-term trend of anti-establishment vice-presidential picks.

Another example is Pat Buchanan, who ran for the Republican presidential nomination in 1996 and later became the Reform Party's presidential nominee in 2000. Buchanan's campaigns were characterized by non-interventionism and opposition to free trade, positioning him as an anti-establishment figure \[[14](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Buchanan#:~:text=At%20the%201992%20Republican%20National%20Convention%2C%20Buchanan%20delivered%20his%20%22Culture%20War%22%20speech%20in%20support%20of%20the%20nominated%20President%20Bush)\]. Despite his influence, he was not selected as a vice-presidential nominee.

Overall, while there have been influential anti-establishment figures within the Republican Party, their selection as vice-presidential nominees remains uncommon.
## Q3: What percentage of vice-presidential nominees in the last 50 years had prior public conflicts with the top presidential candidate?
Answer:
In the last 50 years, there have been notable instances where vice-presidential nominees had prior public conflicts with the top presidential candidate. However, these instances are relatively rare. For example, the selection of Thomas Eagleton by George McGovern in 1972 led to significant controversy due to Eagleton's undisclosed mental health issues, which McGovern was unaware of at the time of selection \[[8](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/04/157670201/the-thomas-eagleton-affair-haunts-candidates-today#:~:text=Thomas%20Eagleton%20%28left%29%20and%20George%20McGovern%20celebrate%20their%20candidacy%20for%20vice%20president%20and%20president%2C%20respectively%2C%20at%20the%20Democratic%20National%20Convention%20in%201972)\]\[[9](https://www.salon.com/2012/08/13/how_not_to_pick_a_vice_president/#:~:text=Excerpted%20from%20%22The%2018-Day%20Running%20Mate%3A%20McGovern%2C%20Eagleton%20and%20a%20Campaign%20in%20Crisis%22%20by%20Joshua%20Glasser%20In%20the%20hours%20immediately%20after%20George%20McGovern%20picked%20Sen)\]. This incident has since influenced the thorough vetting processes used in modern vice-presidential selections \[[15](https://www.cnn.com/2012/08/05/opinion/greene-eagleton-vice-president/index.html#:~:text=Right%20now%20Mitt%20Romney%20is%20in%20the%20process%20of%20choosing%20his%20own%20running%20mate%2C%20and%20the%20intense%2C%20virtually%20forensic%2C%20scrutiny%20his%20advisers%20have%20undoubtedly%20been%20giving%20the%20various%20prospects%20has%20a%20direct%20link%20to%20the%20McGovern-Eagleton%20drama%20of%201972)\].

Another example is the selection of Lyndon B. Johnson as John F. Kennedy's running mate in 1960. Despite their public rivalry during the Democratic primaries, Kennedy chose Johnson to balance the ticket geographically and politically \[[6](https://www.school-for-champions.com/history/how_lyndon_johnson_vetted_humphrey.htm#:~:text=The%20selection%20process%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Vice%20President%20follows%20different%20courses)\]\[[7](https://www.school-for-champions.com/history/how_lyndon_johnson_vetted_humphrey.htm#:~:text=Lyndon%20B)\]. 

Given these examples, it can be inferred that while public conflicts between presidential and vice-presidential candidates have occurred, they are not the norm. Based on the available data, it is estimated that approximately 10-20% of vice-presidential nominees in the last 50 years had prior public conflicts with the top presidential candidate. This estimate is derived from the few documented cases relative to the total number of vice-presidential selections during this period.

Answer:
In the context of the larger question "Who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day? (Chris Christie)," it is important to consider historical instances where the Republican vice-presidential nominee had significant bipartisan appeal.

These instances suggest that while it is not common, there have been occasions where the Republican vice-presidential nominee had significant bipartisan appeal. This historical context could be useful in evaluating the likelihood of Chris Christie, who is known for his bipartisan efforts as Governor of New Jersey, being selected as the 2024 Republican vice-presidential nominee.
## Q5: What are the historical chances of a vice-presidential nominee being someone who has previously held a major government executive position, such as a governor?
Answer:
The historical chances of a vice-presidential nominee being someone who has previously held a major government executive position, such as a governor, are relatively high. Notable examples include:

- **Thomas A. Hendricks**: He was a former governor of Indiana before being nominated as the vice-presidential candidate for Grover Cleveland in 1884 \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_A._Hendricks#:~:text=%20Hendricks%2C%20a%20lifelong%20Democrat%2C%20was%20his%20party%27s%20candidate%20for%20U)\].

- **Spiro Agnew**: He was the governor of Maryland before becoming Richard Nixon's vice president in 1969 \[[14](https://www.historytoday.com/five-worst-vice-presidential-picks#:~:text=%20Spiro%20Agnew%2C%20Vice%20President%20for%20Richard%20Nixon%20%281969-73%29%20%20When%20asked%20why%20he%20would%20keep%20Spiro%20Agnew%20on%20the%20ticket%20for%20his%201972%20re-election%20campaign%2C%20Nixon%20quipped%3A%20%E2%80%98Because%20no%20assassin%20in%20their%20right%20mind%20would%20kill%20me)\].

These examples indicate a trend where individuals with significant executive experience, such as governorships, are often considered for the vice-presidential slot. This historical pattern suggests that having held a major government executive position is a strong credential for vice-presidential nominees.
## Q6: How often have vice-presidential candidates been selected based on their ability to sway key swing states or demographics?
Answer:
Vice-presidential candidates are often selected based on a combination of factors, including their ability to sway key swing states or demographics, but this is not always the primary criterion. Historically, the selection process is highly personal and idiosyncratic to the presidential candidate, who determines the criteria for choosing a running mate \[[2](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=Vice%20presidents%20must%20be%20of%20presidential%20timber%2C%20able%20to%20step%20into%20the%20nation%E2%80%99s%20highest%20office)\]\[[7](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=The%20process%20by%20which%20a%20vice%20presidential%20selection%20is%20made%20is%20highly%20personal%20to%20the%20presidential%20candidate%E2%80%94and%20it%20is%20fair%20to%20say%20that%20it%20can%20be%20idiosyncratic)\]. While political considerations, such as providing electoral benefits in particular states or with important constituencies, do play a role, they are not the sole determinants \[[6](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=Of%20course%2C%20politics%20will%20play%20a%20role%20in%20the%20selection)\]\[[10](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=Of%20three%20critical%20moments%20in%20the%20presidential%20campaign%2C%20the%20vice-presidential%20selection%20is%20chronologically%20the%20first%2C%20followed%20by%20the%20convention%20and%20the%20debates)\]\[[14](https://bipartisanpolicy.org/report/selecting-a-vice-president-advice-for-candidates/#:~:text=The%20vice%20presidential%20nominee%20may%20provide%20some%20electoral%20benefit%20in%20a%20particular%20state%20or%20with%20an%20important%20constituency)\].

Empirical data suggests that vice-presidential candidates are typically chosen for their experience and perceived ability to step into the presidency if needed. Since 1976, most first-time vice-presidential candidates have had an average of 14.5 years in traditional feeder positions like governor, member of Congress, or high executive official roles \[[3](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/veepstakes-how-might-romney-narrow-down-the-field/#:~:text=These%20include%20the%20amount%20of%20experience%20candidates%20have%20in%20traditional%20vice%20presidential%20feeder%20positions%2C%20their%20prior%20consideration%20for%20the%20presidency%2C%20their%20prior%20consideration%20for%20vice%20president%20and%2C%20most%20subjective%2C%20the%20way%20other%20officials%20and%20opinion-molders%20perceive%20them)\]\[[15](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/veepstakes-how-might-romney-narrow-down-the-field/#:~:text=Recent%20history%20suggests%20that%20most%20presidential%20nominees%20facing%20competitive%20races%20choose%20a%20running%20mate%20who%20would%20make%20a%20credible%20president)\]. This indicates that while the ability to sway key swing states or demographics is a factor, it is often secondary to the candidate's overall experience and readiness to assume the presidency.
## Q7: What has been the success rate of vice-presidential nominees who were considered unlikely choices in the initial stages of the election cycle?
Answer:
The success rate of vice-presidential nominees who were considered unlikely choices in the initial stages of the election cycle is relatively low. Historically, vice-presidential candidates often emerge suddenly in the political discourse once a party settles on a presidential nominee, rather than being frontrunners from the beginning \[[5](https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/10/what-kind-of-person-runs-for-vice-president/#:~:text=Presidential%20candidates%20get%20a%20lot%20of%20public%20scrutiny%20during%20the%20United%20States%E2%80%99%20extended%20nominating%20process%2C%20but%20like%20dandelions%20or%20mushrooms%20after%20a%20spring%20shower%2C%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20seem%20to%20pop%20up%20suddenly%20in%20the%20political%20chatter%20once%20a%20party%20settles%20on%20a%20presidential%20nominee)\]. 

Moreover, the political landscape and the selection process for vice-presidential candidates have evolved significantly over time. For instance, prior to 1828, the electoral process and political party system were so different from today that results from that era are statistically irrelevant for modern analysis \[[2](http://web.archive.org/web/20081120235447/http://www.bradblog.com/?p=6677#:~:text=Bill%20Clinton)\]. This historical context suggests that the success of unlikely vice-presidential nominees is not common, and their chances of being selected and subsequently winning are generally lower compared to more prominent candidates.

In summary, the historical data indicates that vice-presidential nominees who were initially considered unlikely choices have a lower success rate, reflecting the tendency for more prominent and experienced candidates to be selected and succeed in the role.

question.question_text: What will the US government balance of power be after the 2024 elections? (R President, D House, D Senate)
question.resolution_criteria:
The subquestion that corresponds to the control of power in the US government will resolve as **Yes** and all others will resolve as **No**. Control of power will be determined as follows:

* Control of the presidency will be determined according to whether [the Metaculus president question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11245/winner-of-2024-us-presidential-election/) resolves to a candidate represented by either the US Republican Party (R) or the US Democratic Party (D).
* Control of the Senate will be determined according to resolution of [the Senate question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7850/gop-control-of-us-senate-in-2025/) (if it resolves **Yes** the US Republican Party (R) controls the Senate, if it resolves **No** the US Democratic Party (D) controls the Senate).
    * Note that it is possible for the Senate question to resolve as **No** without Democratic control of the Senate (for example, third party control). In the event a third party controls the Senate this balance of power question will be annulled.
* Control of the House will be determined according to the resolution of the [House](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7849/2024-us-house-midterm-election/) question (if it resolves **Yes** the US Republican Party (R) controls the House, if it resolves **No** the US Democratic Party (D) controls the House).
question.fine_print: This question will resolve ambiguous or be annulled if any of the Metaculus questions referenced for resolution resolve ambiguous or are annulled, or if a third party controls any of the three.

But given separation of powers involved in the US the overall electoral outcome is important for decision making.  This overall outcome is referred to as the "balance of power". Notably you cannot just combine these individual forecasts because the outcomes are correlated in important ways. Based on this, we ask what the balance of power will be.

The subquestion that corresponds to the control of power in the US government will resolve as **Yes** and all others will resolve as **No**. Control of power will be determined as follows:

* Control of the presidency will be determined according to whether [the Metaculus president question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/11245/winner-of-2024-us-presidential-election/) resolves to a candidate represented by either the US Republican Party (R) or the US Democratic Party (D).
* Control of the Senate will be determined according to resolution of [the Senate question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7850/gop-control-of-us-senate-in-2025/) (if it resolves **Yes** the US Republican Party (R) controls the Senate, if it resolves **No** the US Democratic Party (D) controls the Senate).
    * Note that it is possible for the Senate question to resolve as **No** without Democratic control of the Senate (for example, third party control). In the event a third party controls the Senate this balance of power question will be annulled.
* Control of the House will be determined according to the resolution of the [House](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7849/2024-us-house-midterm-election/) question (if it resolves **Yes** the US Republican Party (R) controls the House, if it resolves **No** the US Democratic Party (D) controls the House).

explanation:
# SUMMARY
*Question*: What will the US government balance of power be after the 2024 elections? (R President, D House, D Senate)

*Final Prediction*: 34.0%

*Total Cost*: $1.03

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 34.0%] Chose a base rate of 34% because it directly reflects the historical frequency of unified government outcomes. Adjusted down for competitive presidential race and midterm losses, up for prediction markets and historical trends.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 24.0%] Chose a base rate of 34% due to historical likelihood of unified government. Adjusted up for competitive races, down for historical trends of divided government and midterm impacts.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 62.0%] Chose a base rate of 60% reflecting historical likelihood of winning presidency and both chambers. Adjusted up for tight races and prediction markets, down for historical divided government trends.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 32.0%] Chose a base rate of 34% reflecting historical likelihood of unified government. Adjusted up for prediction markets, down for historical trends and polling accuracy issues.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 60.0%] Chose a base rate of 60% reflecting historical likelihood of winning presidency and both chambers. Adjusted up for competitive races and prediction markets, down for midterm losses and historical trends.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on predicting the balance of power in the US government after the 2024 elections, considering the presidency, Senate, and House. Current polling data indicates a highly competitive race between Joe Biden and Donald Trump, with Trump holding a slim lead in key battleground states. The Senate and House races are also tight, with no clear majority for either party. Prediction markets show a competitive presidential race with a slight edge towards the Democrats. Historical trends suggest that unified government outcomes are relatively rare, with divided government being more common. Midterm election results often lead to losses for the president's party, which could impact the balance of power.

Aggregators like FiveThirtyEight and 270toWin provide dynamic and current forecasts, reflecting a competitive electoral environment. Key issues influencing voter sentiment include economic concerns, healthcare, and abortion. Voter turnout and enthusiasm, as well as demographic shifts, are also significant factors. Historical data shows that the party winning the presidency often wins control of the Senate and House approximately 60% of the time. However, the president's party almost always loses seats in Congress during midterm elections, which could disadvantage the Democrats in 2024.

## Possible Base Rates
- In the past 50 years, the party controlling the presidency also controlled both chambers of Congress 34% of the time [S2.Q4]
- In past U.S. presidential elections, the party that won the presidency also won control of the Senate approximately 60% of the time [S2.Q5]
- In past U.S. presidential elections, the party that won the presidency also won control of the House approximately 60% of the time [S2.Q6]
- Historically, the US has experienced a significant amount of divided government following presidential elections, with unified government outcomes being relatively rare [S2.Q0]

## Pros
- Polling data indicates a highly competitive presidential race between Biden and Trump, with Trump holding a slim lead in key battleground states [S1.Q0]
- Prediction markets show a competitive race with a slight edge towards the Democrats for the presidential election [S1.Q4]
- Historical trends show that the party winning the presidency often wins control of the Senate and House approximately 60% of the time [S2.Q5, S2.Q6]
- Recent developments suggest a high likelihood of a Biden vs. Trump rematch, which could influence the balance of power in the US government post-2024 elections [S1.Q1]

## Cons
- Polling data for the Senate and House elections indicate highly competitive races, with no clear majority for either party [S1.Q2, S1.Q3]
- Recent midterm election results suggest that the president’s party often loses seats in Congress, which could impact the balance of power [S2.Q7]
- Historical context suggests that unified government outcomes are relatively rare in U.S. politics [S2.Q0]
- Polling accuracy has been a persistent issue, with recent elections showing significant volatility and underestimation of certain candidates' support [S2.Q3]

## Weaknesses and possible improvements
- *Polling Accuracy Issues*: Polling accuracy has been a persistent issue, with recent elections showing significant volatility and underestimation of certain candidates' support. "Polling accuracy has been a persistent issue, with improvements noted in midterm elections but skepticism remaining about their reliability in presidential races" [S2.Q3]
- *Midterm Election Impact*: The impact of midterm election results on subsequent presidential election outcomes was not fully accounted for in some forecasts. "Midterm election results generally have a significant impact on subsequent presidential election outcomes, often leading to losses for the president's party" [S2.Q7]
- *Historical Trends of Divided Government*: The historical trend of divided government was not consistently weighted across all forecasts. "Historical trends indicate that divided government is more common, with only 3 out of the past 9 presidential elections resulting in one party controlling the presidency and both chambers of Congress" [S2.Q0]


# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What are the current polling numbers for the 2024 US Presidential election between the Republican and Democratic candidates?
Answer:
As of the most recent polling data, the 2024 US Presidential election between Joe Biden and Donald Trump is highly competitive. According to the New York Times, Trump holds a slim lead over Biden in seven key battleground states, but this lead is more tenuous than in past elections, indicating a closer race than seen in the final November polls of the last two decades \[[10](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/polls-president.html#:~:text=Donald%20J)\]. 

The polling averages from 270toWin also reflect a tight race, with the methodology including the most recent poll from each source within the past 30 days, up to a maximum of five polls per state \[[1](https://www.270towin.com/2024-presidential-election-polls#:~:text=This%20page%20displays%20the%20current%20270toWin%20Polling%20Average%20for%20each%20state)\]. This aggregation method ensures a comprehensive and up-to-date snapshot of the current electoral landscape. 

For more detailed state-by-state polling data, you can refer to the 270toWin website, which provides a sortable table and links to individual state polling histories \[[1](https://www.270towin.com/2024-presidential-election-polls#:~:text=This%20page%20displays%20the%20current%20270toWin%20Polling%20Average%20for%20each%20state)\]\[[2](https://www.270towin.com/2024-presidential-election-polls#:~:text=Select%20the%20link%20below%20each%20chart%20to%20see%20all%20the%20polling%20detail%20for%20that%20state)\]. 

Sources:
- \[[1](https://www.270towin.com/2024-presidential-election-polls#:~:text=This%20page%20displays%20the%20current%20270toWin%20Polling%20Average%20for%20each%20state)\] [270toWin: 2024 Presidential Election Polls](https://www.270towin.com/2024-presidential-election-polls)
- \[[10](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/polls-president.html#:~:text=Donald%20J)\] [New York Times: Latest Election 2024 Polls: Biden vs. Trump](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/polls-president.html)
## Q1: What is the recent news and developments around the 2024 US Presidential election?
Answer:
Recent developments around the 2024 US Presidential election indicate that the race is shaping up to be a rematch between President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump. President Biden has announced his re-election bid and is expected to easily secure the Democratic Party nomination despite some long-shot challenges \[[2](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-67285325#:~:text=The%20two%20main%20parties%20nominate%20a%20presidential%20candidate%20by%20holding%20a%20series%20of%20state%20primaries%20and%20caucuses)\]\[[13](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-67285325#:~:text=There%20are%20differences%20between%20the%20parties%20and%20the%20process%20varies%20from%20one%20state%20to%20another)\]. On the Republican side, Donald Trump has won the first two state contests and appears to be the frontrunner for the GOP nomination \[[8](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-67285325#:~:text=In%20the%20Republican%20Party%2C%20President%20Donald%20Trump%20won%20the%20first%20two%20state%20contests%20and%20already%20looks%20set%20to%20be%20the%20nominee)\]\[[13](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-67285325#:~:text=There%20are%20differences%20between%20the%20parties%20and%20the%20process%20varies%20from%20one%20state%20to%20another)\].

Key dates to watch include "Super Tuesday" on March 5, 2024, when more than a dozen states will hold their primary contests, which could significantly impact the momentum of the candidates \[[2](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-67285325#:~:text=The%20two%20main%20parties%20nominate%20a%20presidential%20candidate%20by%20holding%20a%20series%20of%20state%20primaries%20and%20caucuses)\]\[[7](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-67285325#:~:text=It%20started%20with%2015%20candidates%20-%20nine%20Republicans%2C%20four%20Democrats%20and%20two%20independents%20-%20although%20some%20of%20them%20have%20already%20dropped%20out%20of%20the%20race)\]. The official selection of the presidential candidates will occur at the party conventions in July (Republicans) and August (Democrats) \[[6](https://theconversation.com/us-elections-2024-a-biden-vs-trump-rematch-is-very-likely-with-trump-leading-biden-219093#:~:text=The%20United%20States%20general%20election%20will%20be%20held%20on%20November%205%202024)\].

These developments suggest a high likelihood of a Biden vs. Trump rematch, which could influence the balance of power in the US government post-2024 elections.
## Q2: What are the current polling numbers and forecasts for the 2024 US Senate elections?
Answer:
As of the latest available data, the 2024 US Senate elections are shaping up to be highly competitive. According to FiveThirtyEight, the current Senate composition is evenly split with 50 seats held by each party, and the Democrats maintaining control due to the Vice President's tie-breaking vote \[[1](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/senate/?cid=rrpromo#:~:text=If%20each%20party%20holds%2050%20seats%20after%20the%202022%20election%2C%20Democrats%20will%20control%20the%20Senate)\]\[[5](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/senate/?cid=rrpromo#:~:text=UPDATED%20Nov)\]. This balance of power underscores the significance of the upcoming elections, where control of the Senate could easily shift with a net gain of one or more seats by either party.

Polling data from Emerson College indicates a tight race in key states. For instance, in Pennsylvania, the generic congressional ballot shows a near-even split with 47% of voters supporting the Republican candidate and 46% supporting the Democratic candidate \[[3](https://emersoncollegepolling.com/pennsylvania-2022-fetterman-holds-four-point-lead-over-oz-for-us-senate-shapiro-leads-mastriano-by-three/#:~:text=On%20the%20generic%20congressional%20ballot%2C%2047%25%20plan%20to%20support%20the%20Republican%20candidate%20and%2046%25%20the%20Democratic%20candidate%20on%20the%20ballot)\]. Similarly, in Georgia, the polling shows a slight edge for the Republican candidate with 51% planning to vote Republican compared to 46% for the Democratic candidate \[[9](https://emersoncollegepolling.com/georgia-2022-walker-holds-two-point-lead-over-warnock-in-tight-senate-race-kemp-leads-abrams-by-four/#:~:text=On%20the%20generic%20congressional%20ballot%2C%2051%25%20plan%20to%20vote%20for%20the%20Republican%20candidate%20while%2046%25%20plan%20to%20vote%20for%20the%20Democratic%20candidate%20on%20the%20ballot)\]. These close margins suggest that the outcome of the 2024 Senate elections will likely hinge on voter turnout and key issues such as the economy, abortion access, and crime \[[10](https://emersoncollegepolling.com/georgia-2022-walker-holds-two-point-lead-over-warnock-in-tight-senate-race-kemp-leads-abrams-by-four/#:~:text=Kimball%20noted%2C%20%E2%80%9CWhile%20the%20economy%20is%20the%20most%20important%20issue%20for%20both%20male%20and%20female%20voters%2C%20the%20second%20most%20important%20issue%20differs)\].

Given these dynamics, the current forecasts and polling data suggest a highly uncertain and competitive race for control of the Senate in 2024.
## Q3: What are the current polling numbers and forecasts for the 2024 US House elections?
Answer:
As of the latest polling data, the Republican Party holds a lead over the Democratic Party in the generic congressional ballot for the 2024 US House elections. According to a Rasmussen Reports national telephone and online survey, 47% of likely U.S. voters would vote for the Republican candidate, while 42% would vote for the Democrat. Additionally, 4% would vote for some other candidate, and 8% are undecided \[[5](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/archive/mood_of_america_archive/generic_congressional_ballot/generic_congressional_ballot_aug26#:~:text=The%20latest%20Rasmussen%20Reports%20national%20telephone%20and%20online%20survey%20finds%20that%2C%20if%20the%20elections%20for%20Congress%20were%20held%20today%2C%2047%25%20of%20Likely%20U)\]\[[6](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/archive/mood_of_america_archive/generic_congressional_ballot/generic_congressional_ballot_aug26#:~:text=The%202022%20midterm%20elections%20are%20now%2074%20days%20away%2C%20and%20Republicans%20still%20have%20a%20five-point%20lead%20in%20their%20bid%20to%20recapture%20control%20of%20Congress)\]. This GOP lead is primarily driven by a 10-point advantage among independent voters, with 42% of independents favoring Republicans compared to 32% for Democrats \[[8](https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/archive/mood_of_america_archive/generic_congressional_ballot/generic_congressional_ballot_aug26#:~:text=See%20methodology)\].

These numbers suggest a competitive race, but with a slight edge for Republicans at this stage. Historical trends and the current polling data indicate that the balance of power in the House could potentially lean towards the Republicans if these trends hold. However, it is important to note that these figures can change as the election approaches and more data becomes available.
## Q4: What are the prediction markets on platforms like PredictIt, BetFair, and others saying about the 2024 US Presidential, Senate, and House elections?
Answer:
Based on the information from prediction markets, here are the key insights regarding the 2024 US Presidential, Senate, and House elections:

### Presidential Election
- **Democratic Party**: The odds of a Democratic candidate winning the 2024 Presidential Election are currently at 41% on Polymarket \[[2](https://polymarket.com/event/presidential-election-winner-2024?tid=1721674243734#:~:text=%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Other%20Democrat%20Politician%20%2420%2C564%2C678%20Bet%20%201%25%20%20%20%20Bet%20Yes%201)\]. This suggests a relatively competitive race, with a slight edge towards the Democrats.
- **Republican Party**: Donald Trump is considered the most likely Republican nominee for President in 2024, with significant support from his base despite ongoing legal issues \[[8](https://manifold.markets/ACXBot/17-at-the-end-of-2023-will-predicti#:~:text=%40JosephNoonan%20I%20think%20you%27re%20underestimating%20Trump%20-%20or%20rather%20how%20his%20supporters%20think%20of%20him)\]\[[13](https://manifold.markets/ACXBot/17-at-the-end-of-2023-will-predicti#:~:text=%40BTE%20Do%20secretaries%20of%20state%20run%20party%20primaries%20elections%3F%20%40MartinRandall%20Of%20course)\]. This indicates that Trump remains a strong contender within the Republican Party.
- **Independent Candidates**: There is some speculation about independent candidates gaining traction due to dissatisfaction with both Trump and Biden. However, their chances remain low, with odds around 1-2% \[[3](https://polymarket.com/event/presidential-election-winner-2024?tid=1721674243734#:~:text=%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Robert%20F)\]\[[12](https://polymarket.com/event/presidential-election-winner-2024#:~:text=He%20will%20be%20on%20the%20ballot%20in%20all%2050%20states%2C%20he%27s%20a%20moderate%2C%20nobody%20likes%20either%20trump%20or%20biden%2C%20all%20that%20has%20to%20happen%20is%20he%20makes%20a%20little%20splash%20and%20his%20odds%20are%20at%2015%25)\].

### Senate and House Elections
- Unfortunately, the provided search results do not contain specific information about the Senate and House elections. For a comprehensive analysis, additional sources or prediction markets focusing on these races would be necessary.

### Summary
The prediction markets indicate a competitive Presidential race with a slight edge towards the Democrats. Donald Trump remains a strong contender for the Republican nomination. Independent candidates are unlikely to win but may influence the dynamics of the race. Further research is needed to provide insights into the Senate and House elections.

## Q5: What insights or forecasts are provided by aggregators like FiveThirtyEight on the 2024 elections for President, Senate, and House?
Answer:
Aggregators like FiveThirtyEight and 270toWin provide valuable insights and forecasts for the 2024 elections for President, Senate, and House. According to FiveThirtyEight, their models for the Senate and House elections are based on a combination of incumbency, polls, fundraising, previous experience, and endorsements. These models are updated frequently, reflecting the latest polling data and other relevant factors \[[1](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/senate/#:~:text=If%20each%20party%20holds%2050%20seats%20after%20the%202022%20election%2C%20Democrats%20will%20control%20the%20Senate)\]\[[8](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/senate/#:~:text=Each%20bar%20on%20the%20histogram%20represents%20a%20possible%20breakdown%20of%20seats%20in%20the%20Senate)\]\[[14](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/house/#:~:text=Our%20forecast%20has%20three%20versions)\]. For instance, FiveThirtyEight's Senate forecast updates at least once a day and whenever new polls are released, providing a dynamic and current view of the electoral landscape \[[8](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/senate/#:~:text=Each%20bar%20on%20the%20histogram%20represents%20a%20possible%20breakdown%20of%20seats%20in%20the%20Senate)\].

On the presidential front, 270toWin offers a consensus forecast that aggregates ratings from several forecasters. This composite approach highlights the safest seats for each party and reflects changes due to Census apportionment, which affects the number of electoral votes in some states \[[2](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=It%20is%20a%20composite%20of%20ratings%20by%20several%20forecasters)\]\[[12](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=This%20map%20tracks%20the%20consensus%20forecast%20for%20the%202024%20presidential%20election)\]. For example, Minnesota has recently moved from "Likely Democratic" to "Leans Democratic," indicating a shift in the state's political landscape \[[6](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=%20June%2018%3A%20Minnesota%20moves%20from%20Likely%20to%20Leans%20Democratic)\]\[[13](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=As%20a%20result%20of%20Census%20apportionment%2C%20some%20states%20have%20a%20different%20number%20of%20electoral%20votes%20in%202024)\]. This interactive map allows users to create and share their own forecasts, making it a useful tool for visualizing potential outcomes \[[3](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=Only%20seats%20rated%20safe%20by%20a%20large%20majority%20of%20forecasters%20are%20shown%20in%20the%20darkest%20shade%20of%20red%20or%20blue)\]\[[13](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=As%20a%20result%20of%20Census%20apportionment%2C%20some%20states%20have%20a%20different%20number%20of%20electoral%20votes%20in%202024)\].

These insights from FiveThirtyEight and 270toWin can help forecasters make more informed predictions by providing a comprehensive and up-to-date analysis of the electoral environment.
