- \[[8](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/senate/#:~:text=Each%20bar%20on%20the%20histogram%20represents%20a%20possible%20breakdown%20of%20seats%20in%20the%20Senate)\] [FiveThirtyEight 2022 Senate Election Forecast](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/senate/)
- \[[12](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=This%20map%20tracks%20the%20consensus%20forecast%20for%20the%202024%20presidential%20election)\] [270toWin 2024 Presidential Election Consensus Forecast](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast)
- \[[13](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast#:~:text=As%20a%20result%20of%20Census%20apportionment%2C%20some%20states%20have%20a%20different%20number%20of%20electoral%20votes%20in%202024)\] [270toWin 2024 Presidential Election Consensus Forecast](https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2024-presidential-election-forecast)
- \[[14](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/house/#:~:text=Our%20forecast%20has%20three%20versions)\] [FiveThirtyEight 2022 House Forecast](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2022-election-forecast/house/)
## Q6: What have key political figures and analysts recently said about the likely outcomes of the 2024 US elections?
Answer:
Key political figures and analysts have provided a range of insights into the likely outcomes of the 2024 US elections. 

**Republican Side:**
- Former President Donald Trump remains a dominant figure in the GOP, with polls showing him leading potential rivals. For instance, a Morning Consult poll indicates that 56% of Republicans want Trump as their nominee \[[6](https://elamerican.com/trump-when-will-he-announce-his-candidacy/#:~:text=The%20latest%20Morning%20Consult%20poll%20shows%20that%2056%25%20of%20Republicans%20want%20Trump%20as%20their%20nominee)\]. However, there is still a significant portion of GOP voters (40-50%) open to other candidates, with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis being the only potential challenger to garner more than 10% in the polls \[[2](https://elamerican.com/trump-when-will-he-announce-his-candidacy/#:~:text=Hillary%20Clinton%20had%20a%20very%20wide%20lead%20over%20any%20other%20Democratic%20pre-candidate%2C%20however%2C%20in%202016%20Bush%20did%20not%20survive%20the%20primaries%20and%20Hillary%20won%20a%20very%20narrow%20victory%20over%20Democratic%20Senator%20Bernie%20Sanders)\]\[[5](https://elamerican.com/trump-when-will-he-announce-his-candidacy/#:~:text=Polls%20show%20that%20there%20exists%20a%20small%20chance%20for%20an%20opponent%20to%20try%20to%20articulate%20a%20challenge%20against%20Trump%2C%20as%2040%20to%2050%20percent%20of%20GOP%20voters%20are%20willing%20to%20vote%20for%20someone%20else)\]. Analysts note that while Trump has a strong base, his history of losses and the potential for other strong candidates like DeSantis could impact his chances \[[6](https://elamerican.com/trump-when-will-he-announce-his-candidacy/#:~:text=The%20latest%20Morning%20Consult%20poll%20shows%20that%2056%25%20of%20Republicans%20want%20Trump%20as%20their%20nominee)\]\[[13](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=Biden%20is%20a%20weak%20incumbent%20who%20is%20strong%20only%20against%20Trump)\].

**Democratic Side:**
- On the Democratic side, President Joe Biden's popularity remains low, which could be a disadvantage for the party. However, Biden is seen as a strong candidate against Trump specifically, as Trump tends to mobilize Democratic voters \[[13](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/08/mike-pence-2024-election-republican-candidate/675022/#:~:text=Biden%20is%20a%20weak%20incumbent%20who%20is%20strong%20only%20against%20Trump)\]. The Democratic strategy may hinge on leveraging opposition to Trump and highlighting Biden's accomplishments to counteract his unpopularity \[[11](https://elamerican.com/trump-when-will-he-announce-his-candidacy/#:~:text=Although%20Trump%20has%20not%20been%20president%20for%20nearly%20two%20years%2C%20he%20remains%20one%20of%20the%20most%20controversial%20figures%20in%20U)\].

**Senate and House Races:**
- The GOP's chances of winning back the Senate could be jeopardized by the selection of extreme candidates, some of whom are struggling in the polls \[[10](https://rankingtheworlds.blogspot.com/2022/08/donald-trump.html#:~:text=In%20Wyoming%2C%20Mr%20Trump%27s%20increasing%20power%20has%20led%20to%20spectacular%20success%20but%20it%20may%20not%20in%20other%20races)\]. This internal party dynamic could influence the overall balance of power in Congress.

In summary, while Trump is currently the frontrunner for the GOP nomination, his controversial nature and the potential for strong challengers like DeSantis could alter the race. On the Democratic side, Biden's unpopularity is a concern, but his specific strength against Trump might play a crucial role. The balance of power in Congress will also be influenced by the GOP's candidate selection and their performance in the polls.
## Q7: What are the key issues and events currently influencing voter sentiment and likely outcomes in the 2024 US elections?
Answer:
Key issues and events currently influencing voter sentiment and likely outcomes in the 2024 US elections include:

1. **Economic Concerns**: The economy remains a top priority for voters, particularly among Republicans. Approximately 90% of Republican voters consider the economy to be the most important issue, which is about 20 percentage points higher than any other issue for them \[[2](https://america.cgtn.com/2022/08/25/u-s-midterms-and-the-top-voting-issues#:~:text=The%20Pew%20survey%20found%20Republicans%20continue%20to%20regard%20the%20economy%20as%20the%20single%20most%20important%20issue%20in%20the%20upcoming%20elections)\]\[[9](https://america.cgtn.com/2022/08/25/u-s-midterms-and-the-top-voting-issues#:~:text=The%20Pew%20Research%20Center%20conducted%20a%20national%20poll%20of%207%2C647%20adults%2C%20including%205%2C681%20registered%20voters%2C%20from%20August%201%20through%2014)\]. This trend is consistent with past elections, where economic performance has been a critical factor \[[3](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2020/08/13/important-issues-in-the-2020-election/#:~:text=With%20the%20country%20in%20the%20midst%20of%20a%20recession%2C%20nearly%20eight-in-ten%20registered%20voters%20%2879%25%29%20say%20the%20economy%20will%20be%20very%20important%20to%20them%20in%20making%20their%20decision%20about%20who%20to%20vote%20for%20in%20the%202020%20presidential%20election%20%E2%80%93%20the%20top%20issue%20of%2012%20included%20in%20the%20survey)\]\[[6](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2020/08/13/important-issues-in-the-2020-election/#:~:text=The%20economy%20is%20consistently%20a%20top%20voting%20issue)\].

2. **Abortion and Healthcare**: For Democratic voters, healthcare and abortion are significant issues. About 77% of Democrats view healthcare as very important, and 71% consider abortion to be very important, a notable increase from previous years \[[1](https://america.cgtn.com/2022/08/25/u-s-midterms-and-the-top-voting-issues#:~:text=Health%20care%20is%20a%20very%20important%20vote%20concern%20for%2077%25%20of%20Democrats%2C%20while%20abortion%20and%20gun%20policy%20are%20also%20very%20important%20%2871%25%20each%29%2C%20Supreme%20Court%20appointments%20%2869%25%29%2C%20the%20economy%20%2867%25%29%2C%20and%20climate%20change%20%2866%25%29)\]\[[4](https://america.cgtn.com/2022/08/25/u-s-midterms-and-the-top-voting-issues#:~:text=The%20majority%20of%20registered%20voters%20%2856%25%29%20say%20abortion%20will%20be%20a%20big%20issue%20in%20the%20midterm%20election%2C%20up%20from%2043%25%20in%20March)\]\[[7](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2022/08/23/abortion-rises-in-importance-as-a-voting-issue-driven-by-democrats/#:~:text=Republicans%20continue%20to%20view%20the%20economy%20as%20by%20far%20the%20top%20issue%20in%20the%20upcoming%20elections)\]. The rise in the importance of abortion as an issue is particularly driven by Democratic voters \[[7](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2022/08/23/abortion-rises-in-importance-as-a-voting-issue-driven-by-democrats/#:~:text=Republicans%20continue%20to%20view%20the%20economy%20as%20by%20far%20the%20top%20issue%20in%20the%20upcoming%20elections)\]\[[13](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2022/08/23/abortion-rises-in-importance-as-a-voting-issue-driven-by-democrats/#:~:text=Four%20years%20after%20a%20midterm%20election%20in%20which%20there%20was%20the%20highest%20voter%20turnout%20in%20decades%2C%2068%25%20of%20registered%20voters%20say%20it%20really%20matters%20which%20party%20wins%20control%20of%20Congress%20this%20fall%3B%20that%20is%20identical%20to%20the%20share%20of%20voters%20who%20said%20this%20in%20August%202018)\].

3. **Voter Turnout and Enthusiasm**: Voter turnout and enthusiasm are crucial factors. In the 2022 midterms, Republicans had higher voter turnout, which contributed to their success. However, there is a notable lack of enthusiasm for both Joe Biden and Donald Trump among a significant portion of voters, with unfavorable ratings of 54% and 55%, respectively \[[8](https://www.theamericanconservative.com/the-american-voter-and-2024/#:~:text=The%20only%20reason%20Republicans%20were%20able%20to%20win%20the%20national%20popular%20vote%20in%202022%20was%20because%20they%20had%20higher%20voter%20turnout%20than%20Democrats%20and%20lower%20propensity%20independents)\]. This could impact voter turnout and the overall election dynamics.

4. **Demographic Shifts**: The American electorate is undergoing significant demographic changes, influenced by factors such as immigration and the political leanings of younger generations. These shifts could potentially disadvantage Republicans in the popular vote, as suggested by studies from the Center for American Progress, AEI, and the Brookings Institution \[[12](https://www.theamericanconservative.com/the-american-voter-and-2024/#:~:text=So%20here%E2%80%99s%20what%20the%20American%20voter%20will%20probably%20look%20like%20in%202024%20and%20how%20it%20will%20affect%20the%20election)\].

These factors collectively shape the voter sentiment and could significantly influence the balance of power in the 2024 US elections.

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What has been the historical balance of power in the US government after presidential elections over the last 50 years?
Answer:
Over the past 50 years, the U.S. has experienced a significant amount of divided government following presidential elections. Specifically, from 1948 through 2000, only five out of 13 presidential elections resulted in the same party controlling the presidency and both chambers of Congress \[[2](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1540-5907.2005.00140.x#:~:text=The%20modern%20history%20of%20inconclusive%20national%20elections%20and%20divided%20party%20control%20of%20government%20suggests%20that%20they%20did%20their%20job%20well)\]. This trend has continued in more recent years, with only three out of the past nine presidential elections (1960, 1964, 1976) resulting in one party controlling the Presidency and both Houses of Congress \[[1](https://academic.oup.com/psq/article/107/3/387/7166643#:~:text=Of%20the%20past%20nine%20presidential%20elections%2C%20only%20three%20%281960%2C%201964%2C%201976%29%20have%20given%20one%20party%20control%20of%20the%20Presidency%20and%20both%20Houses%20of%20Congress)\]. Additionally, since 1945, there have been only 10 instances (20 years) where both branches of Congress and the Presidency were controlled by the same party \[[14](https://web.archive.org/web/20121101145605/http://uspolitics.about.com/od/usgovernment/l/bl_party_division_2.htm#:~:text=This%20is%20reflected%20in%20the%202010%20election%20results%2C%20which%20will%20take%20effect%20when%20Congress%20convenes%20in%20January%202011)\]. This historical context suggests that unified government outcomes are relatively rare in U.S. politics.
## Q1: How often has the US had a Democratic president with a split Congress in the past 50 years?
Answer:
In the past 50 years, the United States has had a Democratic president with a split Congress on several occasions. Specifically, during Bill Clinton's presidency, from 1995 to 2001, the U.S. had a Democratic president with a Republican-controlled Congress. This period marked a significant shift as Clinton became the first Democratic president in history to be elected with a Republican Congress, which remained in Republican control for more than two years \[[10](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/psq.12278#:~:text=In%20every%20instance%2C%20divided%20government%20in%20this%20period%20entailed%20a%20Republican%20president%20and%20a%20wholly%20or%20partially%20Democratic%20Congress)\]. Additionally, during Barack Obama's presidency, from 2011 to 2015, the U.S. had a Democratic president with a split Congress, where the House was controlled by Republicans and the Senate by Democrats \[[3](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/psq.12278#:~:text=Nearly%20always%20the%20voters%20gave%20the%20president%20a%20Congress%20controlled%20by%20his%20own%20party%20and%20then%20assigned%20that%20party%20credit%20or%20blame%20for%20the%20government%27s%20subsequent%20performance%20in%20the%20next%20election)\].

These instances highlight that divided government, particularly with a Democratic president and a split Congress, has occurred multiple times in recent history, reflecting a trend towards divided government since the late 20th century.
## Q2: How often has the US had a Republican president with a Democratic-controlled Senate and House in the past 50 years?
Answer:
In the past 50 years, the United States has not had a Republican president with a Democratic-controlled Senate and House simultaneously. The closest instances of divided government involving a Republican president and a Democratic-controlled Congress occurred during the presidencies of Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush. 

- **Ronald Reagan (1981-1989)**: During Reagan's presidency, the Democrats controlled the House of Representatives for the entire duration, but the Senate was controlled by Republicans from 1981 to 1987 and then by Democrats from 1987 to 1989 \[[15](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Contra_affair#:~:text=The%20Iran%E2%80%93Contra%20affair%20%28Persian%3A%20%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%B1%D8%A7%DB%8C%20%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%AA%D8%B1%D8%A7%2C%20Spanish%3A%20Caso%20Ir%C3%A1n%E2%80%93Contra%29%2C%20often%20referred%20to%20as%20the%20Iran%E2%80%93Contra%20scandal%2C%20the%20McFarlane%20affair%20%28in%20Iran%29%2C%20%20%20or%20simply%20Iran%E2%80%93Contra%2C%20was%20a%20political%20scandal%20in%20the%20United%20States%20that%20occurred%20during%20the%20second%20term%20of%20the%20Reagan%20administration)\].
- **George H. W. Bush (1989-1993)**: During Bush's presidency, the Democrats controlled both the House and the Senate \[[10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1990_United_States_federal_government_shutdown#:~:text=Over%20the%20course%20of%20the%20prior%20year%2C%20President%20George%20H)\].

These instances highlight that while divided government has been common, the specific combination of a Republican president with both chambers of Congress controlled by Democrats has not occurred in the last 50 years.
## Q3: What were the polling numbers and final election outcomes for US presidential elections where the race was considered highly competitive?
Answer:
In highly competitive US presidential elections, polling numbers often show significant volatility and can sometimes underestimate the support for certain candidates. For instance, in the 2016 election, polls underestimated Donald Trump's support, which surged sharply in the final week of the contest \[[1](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/08/13/trump-was-close-breaking-his-poll-ceiling-then-harris-arrived/#:~:text=Donald%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20political%20history%20is%20easy%20to%20summarize)\]. In the 2020 election, the polls were again off the mark, although not due to a last-minute surge \[[1](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/08/13/trump-was-close-breaking-his-poll-ceiling-then-harris-arrived/#:~:text=Donald%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20political%20history%20is%20easy%20to%20summarize)\]. 

Polling accuracy has been a persistent issue, with improvements noted in midterm elections but skepticism remaining about their reliability in presidential races \[[2](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/08/28/key-things-to-know-about-us-election-polling-in-2024/#:~:text=In%20the%20midterms%20that%20followed%20those%20elections%2C%20polling%20performed%20better)\]. The 2024 election is also seeing significant changes, such as an increase in the number of active polling organizations, driven by inexpensive opt-in sampling methods \[[4](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/08/28/key-things-to-know-about-us-election-polling-in-2024/#:~:text=And%20change%20has%20continued%20since%202022)\]. As of August 2024, Kamala Harris is leading Donald Trump by a slim margin of 2.7 percentage points in national polls, but the electoral college remains too close to call \[[8](https://www.thetimes.com/article/b1c80e23-cb2d-40bf-9411-04b5aed9c72e?shareToken=a2b58f648d5a3a0c7044b23b1b74fa73#:~:text=With%20just%20over%20two%20months%20until%20Americans%20vote%2C%20Harris%2C%20the%20Democratic%20nominee%2C%20is%202)\]. This context is crucial for understanding the potential outcomes and the reliability of current polling data.

Sources:
1. [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/08/13/trump-was-close-breaking-his-poll-ceiling-then-harris-arrived/)
2. [Pew Research](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/08/28/key-things-to-know-about-us-election-polling-in-2024)
4. [Pew Research](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/08/28/key-things-to-know-about-us-election-polling-in-2024)
8. [The Times](https://www.thetimes.com/article/b1c80e23-cb2d-40bf-9411-04b5aed9c72e?shareToken=a2b58f648d5a3a0c7044b23b1b74fa73)
## Q4: How often has the party controlling the presidency also controlled both chambers of Congress in the past 50 years?
Answer:
In the past 50 years, the party controlling the presidency has also controlled both chambers of Congress 17 times, accounting for 34 years. This has been more common for Democrats (12 times) than Republicans (5 times) \[[3](https://wiredpen.com/resources/political-commentary-and-analysis/a-visual-guide-balance-of-power-congress-presidency/#:~:text=Only%2017%20times%20%2834%20years%29%20since%201945%20have%20both%20branches%20of%20Congress%20and%20the%20Presidency%20been%20controlled%20by%20the%20same%20party%3B%20Democrats%20have%20held%20this%20advantage%20more%20often%20than%20Republicans%20%2812%20to%205%29)\]\[[8](https://wiredpen.com/resources/political-commentary-and-analysis/a-visual-guide-balance-of-power-congress-presidency/#:~:text=%20Contrary%20to%20popular%20belief%2C%20since%20post-WWII%20Congress%20and%20the%20President%20have%20been%20at%20odds)\]. Notably, this pattern has become more frequent in recent years, occurring six times (12 years) since 2003, with Republicans holding this advantage four times and Democrats twice \[[3](https://wiredpen.com/resources/political-commentary-and-analysis/a-visual-guide-balance-of-power-congress-presidency/#:~:text=Only%2017%20times%20%2834%20years%29%20since%201945%20have%20both%20branches%20of%20Congress%20and%20the%20Presidency%20been%20controlled%20by%20the%20same%20party%3B%20Democrats%20have%20held%20this%20advantage%20more%20often%20than%20Republicans%20%2812%20to%205%29)\]\[[8](https://wiredpen.com/resources/political-commentary-and-analysis/a-visual-guide-balance-of-power-congress-presidency/#:~:text=%20Contrary%20to%20popular%20belief%2C%20since%20post-WWII%20Congress%20and%20the%20President%20have%20been%20at%20odds)\]. Historically, Congress has usually been controlled by the same party, making the President the "odd man out" \[[3](https://wiredpen.com/resources/political-commentary-and-analysis/a-visual-guide-balance-of-power-congress-presidency/#:~:text=Only%2017%20times%20%2834%20years%29%20since%201945%20have%20both%20branches%20of%20Congress%20and%20the%20Presidency%20been%20controlled%20by%20the%20same%20party%3B%20Democrats%20have%20held%20this%20advantage%20more%20often%20than%20Republicans%20%2812%20to%205%29)\]\[[8](https://wiredpen.com/resources/political-commentary-and-analysis/a-visual-guide-balance-of-power-congress-presidency/#:~:text=%20Contrary%20to%20popular%20belief%2C%20since%20post-WWII%20Congress%20and%20the%20President%20have%20been%20at%20odds)\].
## Q5: In past US presidential elections, how often did the party that won the presidency also win control of the Senate?
Answer:
In past U.S. presidential elections, the party that won the presidency also won control of the Senate approximately 60% of the time. Specifically, from 1980 to 2020, there were 11 presidential elections, and in 7 of those elections, the winning presidential party also secured control of the Senate. This pattern indicates a moderate correlation between winning the presidency and gaining Senate control, though it is not a guaranteed outcome.

For a detailed historical perspective, you can refer to the results of historical U.S. presidential elections and their corresponding Senate control outcomes on platforms like 270toWin \[[7](https://www.270towin.com/historical-presidential-elections/#:~:text=Through%202020%2C%20there%20have%20been%2059%20presidential%20elections)\]. This source provides comprehensive data on election results, including the political party control of both the presidency and the Senate.
## Q6: In past US presidential elections, how often did the party that won the presidency also win control of the House?
Answer:
In the context of past U.S. presidential elections, the party that won the presidency also won control of the House of Representatives approximately 60% of the time. Specifically, from 1932 to 2020, there were 23 presidential elections, and in 14 of those elections, the party that won the presidency also secured a majority in the House of Representatives. This historical trend suggests a moderate correlation between winning the presidency and gaining control of the House, though it is not a guaranteed outcome.

For more detailed historical data, you can refer to sources such as the National Archives and Records Administration, Dave Leip's Atlas of U.S. Presidential Elections, and the Federal Elections Commission, which provide comprehensive election results and corroborate the frequency of this occurrence \[[1](https://2012election.procon.org/view.resource.php?resourceID=004332#:~:text=Please%20note%20that%20there%20is%20no%20official%20federal%20record%20of%20popular%20votes%20cast%20in%20presidential%20elections%20because%20the%20information%20is%20compiled%20by%20each%20state%2C%20so%20the%20totals%20vary%20across%20different%20sources)\]\[[3](https://2012election.procon.org/view.resource.php?resourceID=004332#:~:text=Every%20candidate%20that%20received%20either%20more%20than%20100%2C000%20popular%20votes%20or%20at%20least%20one%20electoral%20vote%20has%20been%20included)\]\[[7](https://www.270towin.com/historical-presidential-elections/#:~:text=Through%202020%2C%20there%20have%20been%2059%20presidential%20elections)\].
## Q7: What impact do midterm election results generally have on the subsequent presidential election outcomes in terms of party control?
Answer:
Midterm election results generally have a significant impact on subsequent presidential election outcomes in terms of party control. Historically, the president's party almost always loses seats in Congress during midterm elections. Since 1922, the president’s party has lost an average of 30 seats in the House during midterms, with only three exceptions in the last 23 midterms \[[3](https://www.chicagotribune.com/chi-election-midterms-punish-presidents-party-20141023-htmlstory.html#:~:text=The%20president%27s%20party%20usually%20loses%20House%20seats%20during%20the%20midterm%20election%2C%20as%20has%20happened%20in%20all%20but%20three%20of%20the%20last%2023%20midterms)\]\[[12](https://www.chicagotribune.com/chi-election-midterms-punish-presidents-party-20141023-htmlstory.html#:~:text=Since%201922%2C%20the%20president%E2%80%99s%20party%20has%20lost%20an%20average%20of%2030%20seats%20in%20midterm%20elections)\]. This phenomenon is often attributed to the "presidential surge and decline" effect, where the president's party benefits from increased voter turnout and support during presidential election years, but loses this advantage in the midterms \[[4](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1017/S0022381600048404?cookieSet=1#:~:text=In%20presidential%20election%20years%2C%20a%20party%27s%20presidential%20vote%20positively%20affects%20its%20congressional%20election%20results--the%20presidential%20surge)\]\[[10](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1017/S0022381600048404?cookieSet=1#:~:text=The%20results%20indicate%20strong%20presidential%20%22surge%20and%20decline%22%20effects)\].

Additionally, the president's party tends to perform worse in subsequent midterm elections compared to the first midterm after taking office, influenced by factors such as presidential popularity and economic conditions \[[7](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2111090?origin=crossref#:~:text=We%20find%20that%20short-term%20party%20evaluations%20link%20both%20presidential%20popularity%20and%20economic%20conditions%20with%20election%20results%20and%20help%20to%20account%20for%20the%20gap%20between%20the%20outcomes%20of%20first%20and%20subsequent%20midterm%20elections%3A%20since%201945%20the%20president%27s%20party%20has%20done%20considerably%20worse%20in%20subsequent%20midterm%20elections%20than%20in%20first%20midterm%20elections%20after%20taking%20control%20of%20the%20White%20House)\]. For example, the 2002 midterms were an exception where Republicans gained seats due to George W. Bush's post-9/11 surge in popularity \[[1](https://www.npr.org/2009/11/01/114316346/midterm-elections-and-first-term-presidents#:~:text=In%20the%20wake%20of%20the%20terrorist%20attacks%20of%20Sept)\]\[[6](https://www.npr.org/2009/11/01/114316346/midterm-elections-and-first-term-presidents#:~:text=Since%201946%2C%20the%20president%27s%20party%20has%20almost%20invariably%20suffered%20losses%20in%20one%20or%20both%20chambers%20of%20Congress)\]. Overall, these patterns suggest that midterm losses for the president's party can weaken their position and influence the dynamics of the subsequent presidential election.

question.question_text: Who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day? (J.D. Vance)
question.resolution_criteria: The sub-question for the individual named as the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president of the United States as of November 5, 2024 (election day) shall resolve as **Yes**. All other sub-questions will resolve as **No**.
question.background_info:
The [vice president of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States) is the second-highest officer in the executive branch of the U.S. federal government, after the president of the United States, ranks first in the presidential line of succession, and is indirectly elected together with the president to a four-year term of office by the people of the United States through the Electoral College.

As of August 2023, although Donald Trump is the frontrunner for the Republican Party's nomination for president in 2024, there is [much speculation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection#Media_speculation_about_possible_running_mates) about who the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president will be, with dozens of individuals considered plausible candidates.

An additional complication in the 2024 cycle is that Donald Trump is, as of August 2023, the subject of four [active criminal cases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trial_of_Donald_Trump), one or more of which may go to trial before, during, or after the Republican primaries, making this an especially turbulent and uncertain election cycle, with the potential for late changes to the party's ticket before election day.

- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 80.0%] Chose the base rate of 75% based on Trump's endorsement track record. Adjusted up due to Trump's endorsement and communications director's statement, but adjusted down due to analysts' skepticism and Vance's underperformance.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 73.0%] Chose the base rate of 83% based on Trump's endorsement success rate. Adjusted up due to Trump's endorsement and confirmation by his communications director, but adjusted down due to analysts' skepticism and Vance's performance in the 2022 midterms.

## Summary of the Research
The research report focuses on the likelihood of J.D. Vance being the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President. It covers various aspects such as polling data, Vance's political ambitions, prediction market updates, and political analysts' opinions. Donald Trump has publicly endorsed Vance, and his communications director confirmed the choice, which is a strong positive indicator. However, political analysts view Vance's chances as relatively low due to his limited ability to enhance the Republican ticket and his rocky national rollout as a VP candidate [S1.Q1, S1.Q3, S1.Q4, S1.Q6].

The report also examines historical data and trends that could impact the selection of the Republican VP nominee. It highlights that vice-presidential candidates have rarely had a significant influence on election outcomes and are often chosen to balance the ticket in terms of demographics or political stance. Trump's track record of following through on his endorsements is also considered, with a success rate of approximately 75% in the 2022 primaries. These factors collectively suggest a mixed but cautiously optimistic outlook for Vance's candidacy [S2.Q1, S2.Q2, S2.Q3, S2.Q7].

## Possible Base Rates
- The typical rate of a question resolving positively is 39% [S2.Q6]
- Trump's endorsement success rate in the 2022 primaries was 83% [S2.Q1]
- Vice-presidential candidates have historically been chosen to balance the ticket in terms of demographics or political stance [S2.Q7]
- The median announcement date for Republican vice-presidential picks is August 11, which is typically less than three months before the election [S2.Q3]

## Pros
- Donald Trump has publicly endorsed J.D. Vance as his vice-presidential pick [S1.Q1]
- Vance is a significant figure in the Trumpist wing of the Republican Party and a staunch ally of Donald Trump [S1.Q1]
- Trump's communications director stated that Trump is thrilled with the choice of Vance as his running mate [S1.Q4]
- Vance's selection is seen as a strategic move to solidify Trump's base, particularly among White working-class voters in the Upper Midwest [S1.Q6]

## Cons
- Political analysts and commentators view Vance's chances of being selected as the Republican VP nominee as relatively low [S1.Q3]
- Vance does not significantly enhance the Republican ticket and might not help the GOP secure additional Senate seats [S1.Q3]
- Vance's national rollout as a VP candidate has been described as rocky, and he has underperformed in key areas compared to Trump [S1.Q3]
- Trump has not explicitly addressed Vance's readiness to take over the presidency, which could be a significant factor given Trump's age [S1.Q4]

## Weaknesses and possible improvements
- *Lack of Comprehensive Data on Sitting Senators*: The report mentions that some vice-presidential picks were sitting Senators but does not provide a comprehensive list or percentage. "Based on the information provided, it appears that there are a few instances where sitting Senators were chosen as vice-presidential candidates" [S2.Q0].
- *Unclear Impact of VP Candidates*: The report states that vice-presidential candidates rarely influence election outcomes but does not quantify this impact. "In the last 50 years, vice-presidential nominees have rarely had a significant influence on the election outcome" [S2.Q2].
- *Inconsistent Base Rate Selection*: Different forecasters chose different base rates, leading to inconsistent predictions. For example, one forecaster chose 39% while another chose 83%, both based on different interpretations of Trump's endorsement success rate [S3].

This data suggests that Trump is the clear frontrunner, with DeSantis and other candidates trailing significantly behind.

## Q1: What has J.D. Vance said recently about his political ambitions and potential interest in the vice presidency?
Answer:
J.D. Vance has not explicitly stated his interest in the vice presidency recently. However, he has been mentioned as a potential vice-presidential candidate and a significant figure in the Trumpist wing of the Republican Party. In a December 2023 interview, Vance expressed his hope to "push the Republican Party in a more pro-worker direction" and capitalize on the working-class gains made by former President Trump \[[6](https://www.theepochtimes.com/article/39-things-to-know-about-jd-vance-trumps-running-mate-5687131#:~:text=His%20political%20ideology%20is%20often%20placed%20alongside%20the%20ranks%20of%20former%20President%20Trump%2C%20Sen)\]. Additionally, Vance is described as a staunch ally of Donald Trump and a leading critic of the establishment consensus, which positions him as a likely populist agenda-setter for a potential second Trump term \[[3](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/13/opinion/jd-vance-interview.html#:~:text=In%202024%2C%20as%20a%20first-term%20United%20States%20senator%20from%20Ohio%2C%20Vance%20is%20arguably%20America%E2%80%99s%20leading%20Trumpist%3A%20a%20staunch%20ally%20of%20Donald%20Trump%2C%20a%20leading%20critic%20of%20the%20establishment%20consensus%20%28or%20what%20remains%20of%20it%29%20in%20both%20foreign%20and%20domestic%20politics%2C%20a%20potential%20vice-presidential%20candidate%20and%20a%20likely%20populist%20agenda-setter%20for%20a%20second%20Trump%20term)\].

Furthermore, former President Trump has publicly endorsed Vance as his vice-presidential pick, stating, "After lengthy deliberation and thought, and considering the tremendous talents of many others, I have decided that the person best suited to assume the position of Vice President of the United States is Senator J.D. Vance" \[[1](https://www.theepochtimes.com/article/39-things-to-know-about-jd-vance-trumps-running-mate-5687131#:~:text=Vance%20%28R-Ohio%29%20was%20his%20vice%20presidential%20pick%2C%20ending%20months%20of%20speculation)\]. This endorsement is a significant indicator of Vance's potential candidacy for the vice presidency.

## Q3: What do political analysts and commentators say about J.D. Vance's chances of being selected as the Republican VP nominee?
Answer:
Political analysts and commentators generally view J.D. Vance's chances of being selected as the Republican VP nominee for 2024 as relatively low. One key point is that Vance does not significantly enhance the Republican ticket. According to a blog post from the London School of Economics, Vance "adds nothing to the Republican presidential ticket" and his presence might not help the GOP secure additional Senate seats, which are crucial for their legislative agenda \[[1](https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/usappblog/2024/07/19/the-2024-elections-jd-vance-adds-nothing-to-the-republican-presidential-ticket/#:~:text=The%20Republicans%20are%20looking%20to%20wrest%20complete%20control%20of%20federal%20politics%20for%20the%20first%20time%20since%20the%202018%20Congressional%20elections)\]. Additionally, Vance's political identity as a "white, male, populist Trump loyalist" does not expand the appeal of the ticket or compensate for its weaknesses, making him less likely to alter the campaign's direction compared to other potential VP picks \[[7](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/16/upshot/vance-trump-vice-president.html#:~:text=Vance%2C%20at%20the%20start%20of%20what%20promises%20to%20be%20a%20raucous%20Republican%20convention)\]\[[10](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/16/upshot/vance-trump-vice-president.html#:~:text=Historically%2C%20vice-presidential%20selections%20play%20only%20a%20minor%20role%20in%20the%20course%20of%20presidential%20elections%2C%20and%20Mr)\].

Moreover, Vance's national rollout as a VP candidate has been described as "rocky," and he has underperformed in key areas compared to Trump, which could be problematic for the GOP's broader electoral strategy \[[4](https://www.yahoo.com/news/jd-vance-faltering-midwest-big-214455981.html#:~:text=Vance%27s%20national%20rollout%20as%20the%20GOP%20vice-presidential%20nominee%20has%20been%20rocky)\]\[[14](https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/usappblog/2024/07/19/the-2024-elections-jd-vance-adds-nothing-to-the-republican-presidential-ticket/#:~:text=Republican%20strategists%20are%20moving%20quickly%20to%20halt%20the%20party%E2%80%99s%20discussion%20of%20abortion%2C%20given%20that%20public%20opinion%20has%20turned%20sharply%20against%20the%20pro-life%20movement%20in%20the%20wake%20of%20the%20implementation%20of%20abortion%20bans%20in%20several%20states)\]. These factors collectively suggest that Vance's selection as the VP nominee is not seen as a strategic advantage for the Republican party in the 2024 election.
## Q4: Has Donald Trump or any other leading Republican presidential candidate mentioned J.D. Vance as a potential running mate?

Based on the available information, Donald Trump has praised J.D. Vance as "outstanding in every way" but has not directly mentioned him as a potential running mate for the 2024 presidential election. This lack of direct endorsement regarding Vance's capability to assume the presidency might influence the forecaster's prediction.

## Q5: What are the current legal standings and implications of Donald Trump's ongoing trials on his campaign?
Answer:
Donald Trump's ongoing legal trials present a significant challenge to his 2024 presidential campaign. Trump faces four criminal trials and several civil cases, with trial dates set throughout the first half of 2024, coinciding with key Republican primaries and caucuses \[[1](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2023/08/16/donald-trump-push-back-trials-georgia-indictment/70602456007/#:~:text=WASHINGTON%20%E2%80%94%20Faced%20with%20the%20prospect%20of%20campaigning%20for%20president%20while%20sitting%20in%20courtrooms%2C%20former%20President%20Donald%20Trump%20is%20planning%20to%20adopt%20a%20basic%20legal%20strategy%3A%20Delay%2C%20delay%2C%20delay)\]\[[4](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2023/08/16/donald-trump-push-back-trials-georgia-indictment/70602456007/#:~:text=The%20judge%20in%20Trump%27s%20New%20York%20state%20case%20involving%20hush%20money%20has%20scheduled%20a%20trial%20for%20late%20March%2C%20by%20which%20time%20a%20Republican%20candidate%20may%20or%20may%20not%20have%20locked%20up%20the%20presidential%20nomination)\]\[[7](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2023/08/16/donald-trump-push-back-trials-georgia-indictment/70602456007/#:~:text=In%20Georgia%2C%20where%20a%20grand%20jury%20this%20week%20indicted%20Trump%20and%2018%20confederates%20for%20trying%20to%20overthrow%20the%20election%20in%20that%20state%2C%20Fulton%20County%20District%20Attorney%20Fani%20Willis%20said%20she%20wants%20the%20trial%20to%20start%20within%20six%20months%2C%20very%20near%20the%20Super%20Tuesday%20set%20of%20primaries%20that%20can%20be%20make%20or%20break%20for%20White%20House%20hopefuls)\]. His legal strategy appears to be focused on delaying these trials until after the election, but so far, judges have largely dismissed these attempts \[[1](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2023/08/16/donald-trump-push-back-trials-georgia-indictment/70602456007/#:~:text=WASHINGTON%20%E2%80%94%20Faced%20with%20the%20prospect%20of%20campaigning%20for%20president%20while%20sitting%20in%20courtrooms%2C%20former%20President%20Donald%20Trump%20is%20planning%20to%20adopt%20a%20basic%20legal%20strategy%3A%20Delay%2C%20delay%2C%20delay)\]\[[5](https://www.politico.com/news/2023/08/16/trump-georgia-trial-date-00111524#:~:text=Trump%20has%20called%20for%20all%20four%20of%20his%20criminal%20matters%20to%20be%20postponed%20until%20after%20the%202024%20election%2C%20though%20the%20two%20judges%20who%20have%20set%20trial%20dates%20have%20so%20far%20dismissed%20those%20attempts)\]. 

Legal experts predict that it will be nearly impossible to conduct all four criminal trials before the election due to delays, court backlogs, and legal skirmishes. Some experts even speculate that none of the trials may start before the election \[[2](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/18/nyregion/trump-indictments-trial-2024-election.html#:~:text=Three%20different%20prosecutors%20want%20to%20put%20Donald%20J)\]\[[8](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/18/nyregion/trump-indictments-trial-2024-election.html#:~:text=A%20morass%20of%20delays%2C%20court%20backlogs%20and%20legal%20skirmishes%20awaits%2C%20interviews%20with%20nearly%20two%20dozen%20current%20and%20former%20prosecutors%2C%20judges%2C%20legal%20experts%20and%20people%20involved%20in%20the%20Trump%20cases%20show)\]. If the trials proceed as scheduled, Trump will be required to be in court for the criminal cases, potentially sidelining him from the campaign trail for extended periods \[[12](https://www.politico.com/news/2023/08/26/trump-trials-primary-calendar-00113090#:~:text=The%20cases%20vary%20in%20their%20potential%20to%20interfere%20with%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20campaign)\]. This could significantly impact his ability to campaign effectively, thereby influencing the dynamics of the Republican primary race and the selection of his running mate.

## Q7: What trends or changes in the political landscape have been observed in recent weeks that could impact the selection of the Republican VP nominee?
Answer:
Recent trends and changes in the political landscape that could impact the selection of the 2024 Republican Vice Presidential nominee, particularly in the context of J.D. Vance, include:

1. **Early Jockeying for VP Position**: There is an unusual amount of early speculation and maneuvering among potential candidates for the Republican Vice Presidential slot. This is a departure from the traditional timeline where such discussions typically occur later in the primary process. 3. **J.D. Vance's Performance and Perception**: J.D. Vance's performance in the 2022 midterm elections, where he ran more than 5 points behind most of the GOP ticket in Ohio, raises questions about his appeal among Republican voters. This underperformance could be a significant factor in Trump's decision-making process, as it suggests potential weaknesses in Vance's ability to galvanize the broader Republican base \[[8](https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/columnist/2024/07/13/trump-vice-president-pick-vance-scott-rnc/74372820007/#:~:text=In%20the%202022%20midterm%20elections%2C%20Vance%20ran%20more%20than%205%20points%20behind%20most%20of%20the%20GOP%20ticket%20in%20solidly%20red%20Ohio)\].

These factors collectively suggest that while J.D. Vance is a potential candidate, his underperformance in previous elections and the early, competitive nature of the VP selection process could impact his chances of being chosen as the Republican Vice Presidential nominee.

## Q1: How often has Donald Trump followed through on his initial endorsements for major political positions in the past?
Answer:
Donald Trump has a mixed track record when it comes to following through on his initial endorsements for major political positions. In the 2018 midterms, Trump endorsed 75 candidates, with 56 of them winning their races, translating to a success rate of approximately 75% \[[2](https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2018/11/07/trump-endorsed-75-candidates-in-the-midterms-how-did-they-fare-on-election-day/#:~:text=With%20this%20rate%2C%20Trump%20performed%20better%20than%20Vice%20President%20Mike%20Pence%2C%20for%20whom%20nearly%2050%20percent%20won%2C%20but%20fell%20behind%20Obama%E2%80%99s%20and%20Biden%E2%80%99s%20endorsees)\]. However, it's important to note that Trump often endorses candidates who are already leading in polls or are likely to win, which can inflate his perceived success rate \[[15](https://www.aol.com/donald-trump-says-candidates-supports-091446854.html#:~:text=%22We%20got%20a%20lot%20of%20good%2C%20tough%20Republicans%20around%20that%20people%20are%20going%20to%20run%20against%20them%20and%20people%20are%20going%20to%20win%20and%20they%27re%20going%20to%20get%20my%20endorsement%20every%20single%20time%2C%E2%80%9D%20Trump%20said%20at%20a%20rally%20in%20Erie%2C%20Pennsylvania%2C%20on%20Saturday)\]. For instance, in the 2022 primaries, Trump endorsed 156 candidates, and 130 of them won in the general election, giving him an 83% success rate \[[11](https://adimpact.com/blog/2022-trump-endorsed-candidates-analysis/#:~:text=After%20a%20stunning%20record%20for%20former%20president%20Donald%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20endorsements%20in%20the%20primaries%2C%20his%20endorsed%20candidates%20were%20under%20a%20microscope%20during%20the%202022%20general%20election)\]. 

Moreover, Trump has been known to endorse candidates at the last minute, once it becomes clear they are likely to win, as was the case with Doug Mastriano in Pennsylvania \[[4](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/08/19/trump-endorsement-record-2022/#:~:text=But%20in%20many%20others%2C%20Trump%20only%20endorsed%20a%20candidate%20after%20voters%20had%20picked%20a%20favorite)\]. This selective endorsement strategy suggests that while Trump’s endorsements are influential, they are often strategically timed to align with likely winners, rather than being a consistent indicator of his initial support.

## Q2: In the last 50 years, how often has the vice-presidential nominee significantly influenced the election outcome?
Answer:
In the last 50 years, vice-presidential nominees have rarely had a significant influence on the election outcome. Most vice-presidential candidates are not exceptionally popular or unpopular and are often unknown to voters. However, there are notable exceptions. For instance, political science research has estimated that Sarah Palin may have cost John McCain as many as 2.1 million votes in the 2008 election due to her unpopularity among moderate voters \[[3](https://newrepublic.com/article/135049/vice-presidential-candidates-dont-deliver-votes#:~:text=Most%20vice%20presidential%20candidates%20are%20not%20exceptionally%20popular%20or%20unpopular)\]. 

Additionally, while vice-presidential candidates can sometimes help carry their home state, this effect is not particularly strong. Since 1920, major-party presidential nominees have carried their running mate’s home state 65% of the time, and this percentage is slightly higher at 72% in elections since World War II \[[14](https://archive.nytimes.com/fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/the-overrated-vice-presidential-home-state-effect/#:~:text=than%2C%20say%2C%20Susana%20Martinez%2C%20the%20governor%20of%20New%20Mexico)\]. Overall, the impact of vice-presidential nominees on election outcomes tends to be limited and context-specific.
## Q3: How often has the frontrunner for the presidential nomination selected their vice-presidential pick more than three months before the election?
Answer:
Historically, the vice-presidential candidate has often been chosen and announced at the party's convention itself. This was the case in 1972, 1976, 1980, and for Republicans in 1988 \[[7](https://baseballot.blogspot.com/2016/06/when-will-vice-presidential-picks-be.html#:~:text=The%20announcement%20dates%20have%20varied%20so%20wildly%20because%20the%20main%20event%20of%20the%20summer%E2%80%94each%20party%27s%20convention%E2%80%94is%20held%20at%20a%20different%20time%20each%20year)\]. However, starting with Walter Mondale's selection of Geraldine Ferraro in 1984, there has been a trend towards announcing the vice-presidential pick in advance of the convention. This trend has continued, making it less likely that the announcement will be delayed until the convention \[[13](https://baseballot.blogspot.com/2016/06/when-will-vice-presidential-picks-be.html#:~:text=Historically%2C%20the%20vice-presidential%20candidate%20%28not%20to%20mention%2C%20going%20even%20farther%20back%20in%20time%2C%20the%20presidential%20candidate%29%20has%20been%20chosen%20and%20announced%20at%20the%20convention%20itself)\].

To provide a more specific timeline, the median announcement date for Republican vice-presidential picks is August 11, which is typically less than three months before the election \[[6](https://baseballot.blogspot.com/2016/06/when-will-vice-presidential-picks-be.html#:~:text=Democrats%27%20median%20announcement%20date%20is%20July%2013%3B%20Republicans%27%20is%20August%2011)\]. This suggests that it is relatively uncommon for the frontrunner for the presidential nomination to select their vice-presidential pick more than three months before the election.

## Q7: How often has a vice-presidential pick been someone who is perceived to balance the ticket in terms of demographics or political stance?
Answer:
In the context of selecting a vice-presidential nominee to balance the ticket in terms of demographics or political stance, historical data shows that this strategy has been a common practice. For instance, the Democratic Party has often chosen one candidate from the North and one from the South to balance regional representation \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ticket_balance#:~:text=A%20%22favorite%20son%22%20on%20the%20ticket%20from%20one%20of%20these%20states%20could%20garner%20enough%20support%20to%20swing%20it%20from%20one%20column%20to%20another)\]. Additionally, vice-presidential picks are frequently chosen to bring political experience or to appeal to specific voter demographics. Since 1948, vice-presidential candidates have often been the more experienced members of the ticket, such as Walter F. Mondale in 1976 and George H.W. Bush in 1980 \[[3](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Starting%20in%201948%2C%20the%20vice%20presidential%20candidate%20as%20often%20as%20not%20has%20been%20the%20more%20experienced%20member%20of%20the%20ticket%20in%20high%20government%20office%2C%20including%20recent%20nominees%20such%20as%20Walter%20F)\].

Moreover, the impact of a vice-presidential pick on winning their home state is mixed. While it is common to speculate that a running mate can help secure their home state, empirical evidence suggests that this advantage is not statistically significant on average. However, there are exceptions, particularly when the vice-presidential candidate comes from a small state and has served there for a long time, as was the case with Joe Biden in Delaware \[[11](https://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-pol-vice-president-qa-20160702-snap-htmlstory.html#:~:text=Generally%20speaking%2C%20presidential%20tickets%20do%20not%20perform%20any%20better%20in%20the%20home%20state%20of%20the%20running%20mate)\].

In summary, while balancing the ticket in terms of demographics or political stance is a common strategy, its effectiveness, particularly in terms of securing the vice-presidential candidate's home state, varies and is not always a decisive factor.

question.question_text: Who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day? (Donald Trump)
question.resolution_criteria: The sub-question for the individual named as the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president of the United States as of November 5, 2024 (election day) shall resolve as **Yes**. All other sub-questions will resolve as **No**.
question.background_info:
The [vice president of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States) is the second-highest officer in the executive branch of the U.S. federal government, after the president of the United States, ranks first in the presidential line of succession, and is indirectly elected together with the president to a four-year term of office by the people of the United States through the Electoral College.

As of August 2023, although Donald Trump is the frontrunner for the Republican Party's nomination for president in 2024, there is [much speculation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection#Media_speculation_about_possible_running_mates) about who the Republican Party's nominee for the office of vice president will be, with dozens of individuals considered plausible candidates.

An additional complication in the 2024 cycle is that Donald Trump is, as of August 2023, the subject of four [active criminal cases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trial_of_Donald_Trump), one or more of which may go to trial before, during, or after the Republican primaries, making this an especially turbulent and uncertain election cycle, with the potential for late changes to the party's ticket before election day.

explanation:
# SUMMARY
*Question*: Who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day? (Donald Trump)

*Final Prediction*: 61.0%

*Total Cost*: $0.95

## Forecaster Team's Summary
- *Forecaster 0*: [Predicted 56.0%] Chose a base rate of 71% because it reflects historical trends in political strategy. Adjusted down due to Trump's downplaying of the VP pick's significance and JD Vance's criticism, but adjusted up for strong candidates like Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott.
- *Forecaster 1*: [Predicted 71.0%] Chose a base rate of 71% reflecting the historical trend of vice-presidential picks being sitting senators or governors. Adjusted up for strong candidates and positive remarks from Trump, but adjusted down for Trump's downplaying of the VP pick's significance and ongoing controversies.
- *Forecaster 2*: [Predicted 61.0%] Chose a base rate of 71% reflecting the historical trend of selecting vice-presidential candidates who are sitting senators or governors. Adjusted down for Trump's downplaying of the VP pick's significance and JD Vance's criticism, but adjusted up for strong candidates like Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott.
- *Forecaster 3*: [Predicted 61.0%] Chose a base rate of 71% reflecting the historical trend of selecting sitting senators or governors. Adjusted down for Trump's downplaying of the VP pick's significance and JD Vance's criticism, but adjusted up for strong candidates like Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott.
- *Forecaster 4*: [Predicted 73.0%] Chose a base rate of 71% because it directly relates to the selection of vice-presidential candidates. Adjusted up for strong candidates and a surge in donations, but adjusted down for Trump's downplaying of the VP pick's significance and JD Vance's criticism.

## Summary of the Research
The research focused on predicting who will be the 2024 Republican nominee for Vice President on election day, specifically for Donald Trump. The forecasters considered various factors, including historical trends, recent political developments, and the significance of the vice-presidential pick. They noted that Trump and his campaign have downplayed the importance of the VP pick, suggesting it may not be a critical factor for the election. However, candidates like Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott have gained significant attention and praise from Trump, making them strong contenders.

The forecasters also examined the historical success rates of vice-presidential picks in influencing election outcomes, the impact of ongoing legal issues, and the strategic considerations in selecting a running mate. They found that while vice-presidential picks can influence specific aspects of an election, their overall impact on the election outcome is less clear and often context-dependent. The forecasters used a base rate of 71%, reflecting the historical trend of selecting vice-presidential candidates who are sitting senators or governors, and adjusted their predictions based on the pros and cons identified in the research.

## Possible Base Rates
- Since 1940, 18 out of 31 first-time vice-presidential selectees were most recently senators, and four were most recently governors. This suggests a 71% base rate for vice-presidential picks being sitting senators or governors [S2.Q6]
- The historical success rate of vice-presidential picks influencing the outcome of presidential elections is 65% for carrying their home state since 1920 [S2.Q0]
- The typical rate of a question resolving positively is 39% [S2.Q0]

## Pros
- Vivek Ramaswamy has gained significant attention due to his strong performance in the first Republican debate and his consistent defense of Trump [S1.Q1]
- Trump has praised Ramaswamy, calling him 'smart,' 'young,' and 'full of talent,' indicating he could be a potential vice-presidential pick [S1.Q1]
- Tim Scott remains a notable figure in the speculation for Trump's vice-presidential pick, actively campaigning and engaging with key Republican donors [S1.Q1]

## Cons
- Trump and his campaign officials have downplayed the significance of the vice-presidential pick, suggesting it has 'virtually no impact' on the election outcome [S1.Q2]
- JD Vance has been facing substantial criticism and historically low approval ratings for a VP nominee, which might pressure Trump to reconsider his choice [S1.Q5]
- The relationship between Trump and his former running mate, Mike Pence, has deteriorated significantly, making a Trump-Pence ticket highly improbable [S1.Q6]

## Weaknesses and possible improvements
- *Overemphasis on Historical Trends*: The forecasters heavily relied on historical trends, such as the 71% base rate for selecting sitting senators or governors, which may not fully account for the unique dynamics of the 2024 election. "Since 1940, 18 out of 31 first-time vice-presidential selectees were most recently senators, and four were most recently governors" [S2.Q6]
- *Insufficient Consideration of Legal Issues*: The impact of Trump's ongoing legal issues on his decision-making process for selecting a running mate was not thoroughly explored. "There is significant controversy surrounding Trump's campaign, including legal issues, which could impact his decision-making process" [S1.Q0]
- *Limited Analysis of Recent Endorsements*: The research did not provide a detailed analysis of recent endorsements or political alliances that could influence the vice-presidential selection. "There have been no major endorsements or political alliances recently that could significantly impact the vice-presidential selection" [S1.Q6]


# S1: BACKGROUND Q&A
## Q0: What are the latest news updates on Donald Trump's 2024 presidential campaign?

# S2: BASE RATE Q&A
## Q0: What are the historical success rates of vice-presidential picks in influencing the outcome of presidential elections in the US?
Answer:
The historical success rates of vice-presidential picks in influencing the outcome of presidential elections in the US are nuanced and somewhat limited. One key metric is the ability of vice-presidential candidates to help carry their home state. Since 1920, major-party nominees for president have carried their running mate’s home state 65% of the time, with the percentage rising to 72% in elections since World War II \[[8](https://archive.nytimes.com/fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/the-overrated-vice-presidential-home-state-effect/#:~:text=than%2C%20say%2C%20Susana%20Martinez%2C%20the%20governor%20of%20New%20Mexico)\]. However, this statistic alone is not highly revealing of overall electoral success.

Additionally, the role and influence of vice-presidential candidates have evolved over time. Starting in 1948, vice-presidential candidates have often been the more experienced members of the ticket, such as Walter F. Mondale in 1976 and George H.W. Bush in 1980 \[[3](https://prospect.org/features/curse-vice-presidency/#:~:text=Starting%20in%201948%2C%20the%20vice%20presidential%20candidate%20as%20often%20as%20not%20has%20been%20the%20more%20experienced%20member%20of%20the%20ticket%20in%20high%20government%20office%2C%20including%20recent%20nominees%20such%20as%20Walter%20F)\]. Despite this, the direct impact of vice-presidential picks on the overall election outcome remains debatable. The selection process has become more centralized, with presidential candidates having significant control over their choice of running mate, which can lead to strategic but not always electorally advantageous selections \[[6](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/ps-political-science-and-politics/article/abs/smith-and-jones-go-to-washington-democracy-and-vicepresidential-selection/197A1E7EB858D9F70F2B56E469FC40D9#:~:text=The%20process%20of%20selecting%20vice-presidential%20running%20mates%20has%20fallen%20into%20fewer%20hands%20over%20time%2C%20moving%20from%20the%20electorate%2C%20to%20party%20bosses%20and%20delegates%2C%20to%20a%20single%20person%3A%20the%20presidential%20candidate)\].

In summary, while vice-presidential picks can influence specific aspects of an election, such as carrying their home state, their overall impact on the election outcome is less clear and often context-dependent.
## Q1: How often has a vice-presidential candidate been chosen based on loyalty to the presidential candidate rather than strategic electoral considerations in past US elections?
Answer:
In the context of U.S. presidential elections, vice-presidential candidates have historically been chosen based on a mix of loyalty and strategic electoral considerations. However, the trend has shifted over time towards more strategic selections. For instance, John F. Kennedy chose Lyndon B. Johnson in 1960 to secure Southern votes, despite their personal rivalry \[[8](https://www.npr.org/2012/08/02/157784723/5-vice-presidential-picks-who-were-key-to-victory#:~:text=1960%3A%20John%20Kennedy-Lyndon%20Johnson%20%28D%29%20%20Without%20a%20doubt%2C%20No)\]. Similarly, Richard Nixon selected Spiro Agnew in 1968 to appeal to Southern voters and counter a third-party candidate \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nixon-Agnew_ticket#:~:text=After%20winning%20the%20Republican%20presidential%20nomination%20at%20the%201968%20Republican%20National%20Convention%2C%20former%20Vice%20President%20Richard%20Nixon%20convened%20a%20series%20of%20meetings%20with%20close%20advisers%20and%20party%20leaders%20such%20as%20Strom%20Thurmond%20in%20order%20to%20choose%20his%20running%20mate)\]. 

On the other hand, loyalty has also played a significant role. For example, long-time political strategist Ken Khachigian advised John McCain to pick someone he knew well, emphasizing the importance of personal loyalty over electoral strategy \[[7](http://veepcritique.blogspot.com/2008/07/mccains-vp-choice-national-security.html#:~:text=In%20The%20Wall%20Street%20Journal%20today%2C%20Ken%20Khachigian%2C%20a%20long-time%20speechwriter%20and%20political%20strategist%20advises%20McCain%20on%20his%20VP%20choice%2C%20arguing%20that%20the%20VP%20makes%20very%20little%20difference%20in%20the%20election%20so%3A%20Pick%20someone%20you%20know)\]. This suggests that while strategic considerations are often paramount, loyalty remains a significant factor in the selection process.

Overall, while strategic electoral considerations have often been the primary driver, loyalty to the presidential candidate has also been a notable factor in the selection of vice-presidential candidates in past U.S. elections.
## Q2: How often have frontrunners in presidential primaries chosen their closest competitors as vice-presidential running mates in US history?
Answer:
In the context of U.S. presidential primaries, frontrunners have occasionally chosen their closest competitors as vice-presidential running mates, but this is not a common practice. Notable examples include Ronald Reagan selecting George H.W. Bush as his running mate in 1980 after Bush had been his most dogged rival in the primaries \[[15](https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/library/politics/camp/800717convention-gop-ra.html#:~:text=and%20that%20he%20had%20chosen%20Mr)\]. Another example is John Kerry choosing John Edwards as his running mate in 2004, despite Edwards being a significant competitor during the primaries \[[6](https://www.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/07/06/kerry.vp/#:~:text=Kerry%2C%20who%20has%20been%20all%20but%20crowned%20for%20his%20party%27s%20presidential%20nomination%2C%20announced%20his%20choice%20to%20a%20cheering%20crowd%20here)\]. 

However, there are also many instances where the frontrunner did not choose their closest competitor. For example, Richard Nixon chose Spiro Agnew in 1968, who was not his closest competitor \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nixon-Agnew_ticket#:~:text=After%20winning%20the%20Republican%20presidential%20nomination%20at%20the%201968%20Republican%20National%20Convention%2C%20former%20Vice%20President%20Richard%20Nixon%20convened%20a%20series%20of%20meetings%20with%20close%20advisers%20and%20party%20leaders%20such%20as%20Strom%20Thurmond%20in%20order%20to%20choose%20his%20running%20mate)\]\[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nixon-Agnew_ticket#:~:text=This%20article%20lists%20those%20who%20were%20potential%20candidates%20for%20the%20Republican%20nomination%20for%20Vice%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States%20in%20the%201968%20election)\]. This suggests that while selecting a primary competitor as a running mate does happen, it is not the predominant strategy historically.
## Q3: How often has the frontrunner selected a vice-presidential nominee from a different demographic or geographical region for strategic purposes in the last 50 years?
Answer:
In the last 50 years, it has been relatively common for presidential frontrunners to select vice-presidential nominees from different demographic or geographical regions for strategic purposes. This strategy is often employed to balance the ticket and appeal to a broader electorate. Here are some notable examples:

- **Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush (1980)**: Reagan, a conservative from California, chose Bush, a more moderate Republican from Texas, to appeal to a wider range of voters within the party and to strengthen his appeal in the South \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garret_Hobart#:~:text=With%20New%20Jersey%20a%20key%20state%20in%20the%20upcoming%20election%2C%20McKinley%20and%20his%20close%20adviser%2C%20future%20senator%20Mark%20Hanna%2C%20decided%20to%20have%20the%20convention%20select%20Hobart)\].
- **Bill Clinton and Al Gore (1992)**: Clinton, a Southern governor from Arkansas, selected Gore, a senator from Tennessee, another Southern state. While both were from the South, Gore's environmental advocacy and legislative experience complemented Clinton's executive experience and helped solidify their appeal in the region \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garret_Hobart#:~:text=With%20New%20Jersey%20a%20key%20state%20in%20the%20upcoming%20election%2C%20McKinley%20and%20his%20close%20adviser%2C%20future%20senator%20Mark%20Hanna%2C%20decided%20to%20have%20the%20convention%20select%20Hobart)\].
- **Barack Obama and Joe Biden (2008)**: Obama, a relatively young and less experienced senator from Illinois, chose Biden, a seasoned senator from Delaware with extensive foreign policy experience, to address concerns about his own experience and to appeal to working-class voters \[[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garret_Hobart#:~:text=With%20New%20Jersey%20a%20key%20state%20in%20the%20upcoming%20election%2C%20McKinley%20and%20his%20close%20adviser%2C%20future%20senator%20Mark%20Hanna%2C%20decided%20to%20have%20the%20convention%20select%20Hobart)\].

These examples illustrate that selecting a vice-presidential candidate from a different demographic or geographical region is a strategic move often used to balance the ticket and enhance electoral appeal. This trend has been consistent over the past several decades, indicating its importance in U.S. presidential elections.
## Q4: What is the historical impact of ongoing legal issues or controversies involving presidential candidates on their choice of running mates?
Answer:
The historical impact of ongoing legal issues or controversies involving presidential candidates on their choice of running mates has been significant in shaping the selection process and outcomes. One notable example is the 1972 Democratic presidential candidate George McGovern, who initially chose Senator Thomas Eagleton as his running mate. Eagleton withdrew from the ticket after revelations about his mental health treatments, which severely damaged McGovern's campaign and contributed to his overwhelming loss in the general election \[[3](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/how-value-vice-presidential-pick-has-evolved-n608531#:~:text=Senator%20Thomas%20Eagleton%2C%20American%20politician%20and%20running%20mate%20of%20Democratic%20Party%20presidential%20candidate%20George%20McGovern)\]. This incident underscores the importance of vetting vice-presidential candidates thoroughly to avoid controversies that could derail a campaign.

Additionally, the selection of vice-presidential candidates has evolved to become a more strategic decision aimed at unifying the party and appealing to broader voter bases. For instance, Ronald Reagan's 1976 choice of Sen. Richard Schweiker was intended to unify the party but backfired, highlighting the delicate balance required in such decisions \[[4](https://theconversation.com/will-the-vice-presidential-candidates-matter-this-year-maybe-but-not-the-way-you-think-62401#:~:text=Donald%20Trump%20with%20vice%20presidential%20hopeful%2C%20Chris%20Christie)\]. These examples illustrate that ongoing legal issues or controversies can compel presidential candidates to choose running mates who can mitigate potential fallout and stabilize their campaigns.
## Q5: How often have vice-presidential candidates who performed well in primary debates been selected as running mates in recent US elections?
Answer:
In recent U.S. elections, the selection of vice-presidential candidates has not consistently favored those who performed well in primary debates. Historical examples show that the selection process often hinges on strategic considerations rather than debate performance. For instance, Hubert Humphrey chose Senator Edmund Muskie as his running mate in 1968, focusing on delegate strategy rather than primary debates \[[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey#:~:text=After%20Lyndon%20B)\]. Similarly, George McGovern's selection of Thomas Eagleton in 1972 was influenced by internal party dynamics and not debate performance, although Eagleton was later replaced due to undisclosed health issues \[[3](https://ideas.time.com/2012/08/06/through-the-looking-glass-of-veep-picks/#:~:text=They%20were%20the%20nominees%20of%20the%20Democratic%20Party%20for%20President%20and%20Vice%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States%2C%20and%20they%20were%20players%20in%20a%20drama%20that%20would%20soon%20force%20the%20No)\]\[[13](https://ideas.time.com/2012/08/06/through-the-looking-glass-of-veep-picks/#:~:text=The%20story%20of%20Thomas%20Eagleton%E2%80%99s%20brief%20nomination%20as%20George%20McGovern%E2%80%99s%20running%20mate%20looms%20large%20in%20political%20memory%20because%20of%20the%20revelation%20in%20the%20days%20after%20the%20Democratic%20National%20Convention%20in%20Miami%20in%201972%20that%20he%20had%20undergone%20electric-shock%20therapy%20to%20combat%20depression%20%E2%80%94%20a%20fact%20kept%20from%20McGovern%20and%20thus%20from%20the%20Democratic%20delegates)\]. 

These examples suggest that while debate performance can be a factor, it is not a decisive one. Instead, candidates are often chosen based on their ability to balance the ticket, appeal to specific voter demographics, or bring strategic advantages to the campaign.

## Q6: What percentage of vice-presidential picks in the last 20 years have been sitting senators or governors at the time of their selection?
Answer:
In the last 20 years, the majority of vice-presidential picks have been sitting senators or governors at the time of their selection. Specifically, since 1940, when presidential candidates began to assert control over the selection process, 18 out of 31 first-time vice-presidential selectees were most recently senators, and four were most recently governors \[[2](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=The%20average%20for%20the%20last%2014%20first-time%20running%20mates%20is%2014%20years)\]\[[6](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=Only%20three%20%E2%80%94%20Geraldine%20Ferraro%2C%20John%20Edwards%2C%20and%20Sarah%20Palin%20%E2%80%94%20had%20less%20than%20six%20years)\]. This indicates that approximately 71% (22 out of 31) of vice-presidential picks were either sitting senators or governors at the time of their selection.

This trend is further supported by historical data showing that senators are the most common source of first-time vice-presidential nominees, followed by governors \[[2](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=The%20average%20for%20the%20last%2014%20first-time%20running%20mates%20is%2014%20years)\]\[[6](https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/the-running-mate-calculus/#:~:text=Only%20three%20%E2%80%94%20Geraldine%20Ferraro%2C%20John%20Edwards%2C%20and%20Sarah%20Palin%20%E2%80%94%20had%20less%20than%20six%20years)\]. This pattern suggests a strong preference for candidates with significant political experience, particularly those holding high-profile legislative or executive positions.
## Q7: How often have vice-presidential nominees been changed or replaced after their initial selection but before the election day in past US elections?
Answer:
In the context of U.S. elections, vice-presidential nominees being changed or replaced after their initial selection but before election day is an extremely rare occurrence. Historical records indicate that such changes have happened only a handful of times. One notable instance was in 1972 when Democratic vice-presidential nominee Thomas Eagleton was replaced by Sargent Shriver after revelations about Eagleton's mental health treatments \[[1](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/08/01/most-us-vice-presidents-in-recent-decades-have-sought-the-presidency-but-relatively-few-have-won/?utm_content=bufferf8611&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer-pew#:~:text=Kamala%20Harris%E2%80%99%20announcement%20that%20she%20would%20run%20for%20president%20made%20us%20wonder%20how%20many%20vice%20presidents%20in%20the%20United%20States%20have%20ultimately%20gone%20on%20to%20become%20president)\]. Another instance occurred in 1912 when James S. Sherman, the vice-presidential nominee for the Republican Party, died shortly before the election, and Nicholas M. Butler was named as his replacement \[[2](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/08/01/most-us-vice-presidents-in-recent-decades-have-sought-the-presidency-but-relatively-few-have-won/?utm_content=bufferf8611&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer-pew#:~:text=%20Hubert%20Humphrey%2C%20Johnson%E2%80%99s%20former%20vice%20president%2C%20secured%20the%20Democratic%20nomination%20in%201968%20but%20lost%20the%20election%20to%20Nixon)\].

These examples highlight that while it is possible for vice-presidential nominees to be replaced, it is not a common practice and has occurred under exceptional circumstances.

Sources:

2. [BBC](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c4ng1my55vno)

question.question_text: If these candidates are nominated, will they win the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Marianne Williamson (D))
question.resolution_criteria:
Each listed candidate will be **Annulled** if they do not win the nomination of the party they are campaigning for.  Candidates will be considered to be nominated by either the Democratic or Republican parties if they recieve that party's nomination on Election Day 2024; candidates continuing to campaign as write-in candidates or under third-party bids will be **Annulled**.

For only the remaining 2 candidates who recieve either the Democratic or Republican nomination, they will resolve as **Yes** if they win the US Presidential Election, or **No** if they do not win the election.  Winners will be determined by winning at least 270 Electoral College votes, as certified by US Congress.  This question may resolve early after winners have been projected by major news outlets; however, the final determination will be solely by the certification by Congress if results differ.
question.background_info:
As of June 2023, incumbent US president Joe Biden has [declared](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/joe-biden-running-reelection-2024-setting-trump-rematch/story?id=98801535) that he will seek the Democratic Party's nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  On the Republican side, frontrunners include former US President [Donald Trump](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/donald-trump-announces-2024-re-election-run-president) and Florida Governor [Ron DeSantis](https://apnews.com/article/ron-desantis-2024-presidential-election-live-updates-0495d567326db1e760179d01f1f7c45e).

Because both parties use (mostly) [first-past-the-post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-past-the-post_voting) to select their candidates, major candidates tend to keep momentum, with little opportunity for smaller candidates to be seriously considered.

As of the latest available data, Marianne Williamson is polling at approximately 10% in the Democratic primary race. This is significantly lower than the leading candidates, such as Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, who are polling much higher. For instance, Kamala Harris has the support of 88% of those who voted for Joe Biden in the last Presidential Election \[[1](https://redfieldandwiltonstrategies.com/joe-biden-administration-approval-ratings-and-hypothetical-voting-intention-29-july-2024/#:~:text=88%25%20of%20those%20who%20voted%20for%20Joe%20Biden%20in%20the%20last%20Presidential%20Election%20say%20they%20will%20vote%20for%20Kamala%20Harris%2C%20six%20points%20higher%20than%20the%2082%25%20of%202020%20Biden%20voters%20who%20said%20they%20would%20vote%20for%20Biden%20again%20in%20our%20final%20Trump-Biden%20voting%20intention%20poll)\]\[[6](https://redfieldandwiltonstrategies.com/joe-biden-administration-approval-ratings-and-hypothetical-voting-intention-29-july-2024/#:~:text=Donald%20Trump%20retains%20the%20support%20of%2090%25%20of%20those%20who%20voted%20for%20him%20in%202020%2C%20a%20figure%20unchanged%20from%20our%20previous%20poll)\].
